René de Nebesky-Wojkowitz (11 July 1923 – 26 August 2008) was an Austrian-American anthropologist and ethnologist who specialized in the cultural and social anthropology of Southeast Asia, especially Indonesia, where he did most of his research.

He is best known for his work Sex and Society in Bali (1963), an in-depth study of the society and culture of pre-war Bali, based on fifteen months of research he conducted there in 1958-59. The book discusses the complex system of sexual norms and behaviors in Bali, and how they relate to the broader social organization of the village. It also includes a detailed analysis of the structure of marriage, the family, and the state.

Sex and Society in Bali was widely recognized as a classic in the field of anthropology, and has been influential in shaping the understanding of Southeast Asian cultures. It has also been a popular text in courses on anthropology and Southeast Asian studies. Nebesky-Wojkowitz followed up on this work with a second book, The Sacred Bridge: Religion and Culture in Southeast Asia (1989), which explored the role of religion in the region.

In addition to his work in Bali, Nebesky-Wojkowitz also conducted research in other parts of Southeast Asia, including Java, Sumatra, and the Philippines. He was a professor at the University of California, Los Angeles for many years, and also taught at the University of Chicago and the University of Washington. He was married to the anthropologist Hildred Geertz, and died in 2008 at the age of 85.

Thomas Daley (born 21 April 1994) is an English diver. He won the bronze medal in the 10 metre platform competition at the 2020 Summer Olympics in Tokyo, Japan, and gold in the same event at the 2022 World Championships. He won a bronze medal in the 10 metre platform event at the 2016 Summer Olympics in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and a gold medal in the same event at the 2010 World Championships. He won a bronze in the 10 metre platform and a silver in the synchronized platform event at the 2014 World Championships. In 2021, Daley married screenwriter Dustin Lance Black and announced that they are expecting a son due in spring 2022.

Born in Exeter, Devon, Daley started diving at the age of seven, and made his international debut in March 2008 at the European Championships in St. Petersburg, Russia. He studied at Plymouth College.

In 2009, Daley won the World Championship in Rome in the 10 m platform event, becoming the youngest male diver to win a World Championship gold medal. He was awarded an MBE in the 2010 New Year Honours. At the 2010 World Championships in Shanghai, China, he became the first male diver to win the World Championship title in both individual and synchronized events. In 2011, Daley won his first European Championship title, in Turin, Italy, in the 10 m platform event. At the 2012 Olympic Games in London, Daley competed in the 10 m platform and the 10 m synchronized platform events with Max Brick. In the last competition of the day on 7 August, Daley and Brick won the bronze medal in the synchronized platform event, with a total score of 471.47. In the platform event, Daley finished in 4th place with a score of 555.35.

Daley won his second European Championship title in 2014 in Berlin, Germany, with a score of 558.25. At the 2014 World Championships in Shanghai, China, Daley won a bronze in the individual platform competition with a score of 545.25, and a silver in the synchronized platform event with Max Brick, with a score of 496.74.

Daley competed at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, where he was the defending bronze medalist in the 10 m platform event. He finished fifth in the preliminary round with a score of 471.65, and finished third in the semi-final with a score of 541.30. He won the bronze medal with a score of 558.75, behind Chen Aisen of China and David Boudia of the United States.

Dictogloss is a language-learning strategy designed to develop both fluency and accuracy in learners' use of a target language. In this strategy, a group of learners collaboratively reconstruct a spoken text, beginning with only oral and contextual cues. In the original implementation of this strategy, the speaker of the target language narrates a story, addressing the audience in the plural "you," which implies that the narrative is intended for a group of listeners. The listeners write the story as the speaker relates it, without consulting one another and without revising their individual scripts until the speaker has finished telling the story. Then, the groups compare their versions and reconstruct a collective text. Next, the participants who have spoken the target language retell the story in their own words, again addressing the audience in the plural "you." The other participants then compare this retelling with the collective text and evaluate it for accuracy in relation to the collective text and for fluency.

The strategy was developed by Jamie Keddie, a teacher at the British Council in Barcelona, Spain, in the late 1980s. It was further developed and extended by a number of other teachers in the 1990s. The activity is designed for use with adults and young adults, and it is particularly useful for developing a student's ability to use the past tense and the conditional tense in the target language. It can also be used to develop other aspects of language use, such as vocabulary, grammar, and pronunciation.

There have been several people named Fernando Bonilla-Musoles:

1. Fernando Bonilla-Musoles (born 1963) is a Spanish mathematician and economist. He served as the president of the Regional Government of Madrid in Spain from 2004 to 2007 and as the Minister of Public Administration from 2016 to 2018.

2. Fernando Bonilla-Musoles (born 1951) is a Spanish lawyer and politician. He has been the mayor of Villaviciosa de Odón since 2015.

3. Fernando Muñoz de Bonilla (1930–1996) was a Spanish zoologist and politician. He served as the Minister of Culture from 1980 to 1981 and as the Minister of Foreign Affairs from 1981 to 1982.

Can you please confirm which Fernando Bonilla-Musoles you are referring to?

Arise, My Love is a 1940 American drama film directed by Mitchell Leisen. It tells the story of an American engineer sent to supervise the construction of a dam in the Ottoman Empire, who falls in love with a Greek woman and must overcome political and religious differences. The film was nominated for the Academy Award for Best Picture, and features a musical performance by Princess Superstar.

The film was based on the book The Turkish Officer by Μπόριo Μπετσούλη, published in 1934. Metropolitan Studios, an American company, purchased the film rights in 1937. Harry Warner bought the rights from Metropolitan and commissioned producers Jerry Wald and John L. McCrea to develop a script. Numerous screenwriters worked on the script, including John Howard Lawson, Michael Jacoby, and Abem Finkel. The final script was written by Claude Binyon and Stur shelter.

Warner Bros. began filming in late 1939 in Yugoslavia, primarily in the Dalmatian Peninsula and Dubrovnik. The film was produced by Henry Blanke and supervised by Jack L. Warner and Hal B. Wallis. The film's original running time was 213 minutes. During production, Jack L. Warner and Hal B. Wallis became dissatisfied with the length of the film, and ordered that it be reduced to 156 minutes. This entailed cutting 30 scenes and redistributing others. Some of the deleted scenes were later reused in The Constant Nymph.

The film was released in the United States on November 15, 1940. Despite positive reviews from critics, it performed poorly at the box office.

An investment advisor is a person or organization that makes investment recommendations or conducts securities analysis in exchange for a fee. Investment advisors may be employed by brokerages, banks, mutual funds, asset management firms, insurance companies, pension funds, financial consultants, and corporations, among other institutions. Alternatively, they may work as individuals or independently in this field. An investment advisor's job is to assess a customer's entire financial situation and help the client determine which investments are most suitable. This can include, but is not limited to, trading stocks, bonds, commodities, and other instruments. There is no universal method for determining a customer's suitability for a given investment.

Some advisors are held to a fiduciary standard, which requires them to make investment recommendations that are consistent with their client's financial goals and are always in their client's best interest. Others are held to a suitability standard, which allows them to make recommendations that are suitable, but not necessarily ideal, for their clients. These distinctions are important because they affect the legal obligations and liabilities of the advisor.

Investment advisors often have a wide range of education and experience in the financial services industry, including training in investment analysis, portfolio management, and financial planning. They may also have certifications such as the Certified Financial Planner (CFP) or Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) designations. These certifications require the advisor to pass a comprehensive exam and meet certain education and experience requirements.

It is important to note that the services offered by investment advisors can vary widely, and it is important to do your research and choose an advisor who is reputable and has the appropriate qualifications and experience to meet your needs. It is also important to understand the fees associated with the services of an investment advisor, as these can vary widely as well.

Francis Paul Prucha (July 27, 1937 – April 24, 2020) was an American historian of Czech descent known for his works on the history of Catholicism in the United States.

Prucha was born in Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, to Joseph M. Prucha and his wife, the former Marie Ficko. His father was a physician and surgeon descended from Czech immigrants on his father's side, and his mother was of Slovak descent. He received his bachelor's degree from Duquesne University in 1959, and his master's and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Notre Dame in 1960 and 1964, respectively. He joined the history faculty of Saint Vincent College in 1963, and remained on the faculty there until his retirement in 1996. He continued to serve as a professor emeritus at Saint Vincent College until his death. He also served as a visiting professor at the University of Notre Dame and at Columbia University.

Prucha was the author of several books, including The Great Catholic Comeback: A History, and a editor of The Catholic Church in America: A History. He was also a co-editor of The Encyclopedia of American Catholic History, and a editor of The Letters of Francis Galway: Collector for the Deaf, Nineteenth-Century Catholic Missionary to China. In 2000, Prucha was awarded the Laetare Medal by the University of Notre Dame. He was also a recipient of the Father Walter J. Farrell, O.S.A. Award for Distinguished Service in American History from the American Catholic Historical Association.

Hilary of Chichester (c. 310 – c. 367) was a bishop of Chichester and a saint who is regarded as the patron saint of clerks. Little is known about his life, although it is clear that he was well educated. He is believed to have been a Roman Briton and to have been born in Romano-British Gaul, perhaps in Brittany or in the south of Gaul. He appears to have spent much of his life in Rome, where he was educated, and where he may have served as a librarian. He later became bishop of Chichester in Sussex, England, and worked to establish Christianity in the British Isles. After his death, he was recognized as a saint and his remains were eventually transferred to Battle Abbey in 1094. In art, he is often depicted as a bishop with a librarian's rod and a model of Chichester Cathedral.

Little is known about the life of Hilary of Chichester. He was probably born in Brittany or in the south of Gaul around 310, although some sources suggest a birthdate around 287. He was most likely a Roman Briton by birth, the son of a priest named Exuperius. He appears to have been a pupil of St. Martin of Tours and to have been educated at a monastic school in Marmoutier, where he was taught by Saint Volusian. After his schooling, he traveled to Rome, where he may have served as a librarian before being ordained as a priest around 350. He was appointed bishop of Chichester around 360 and served in this position until his death around 367, although some sources place his death in 368 or 369.

As bishop of Chichester, Hilary worked to establish Christianity in the British Isles. He is credited with founding a church in East Sussex and another in Hampshire, as well as a monastery in Selsey. He is also associated with the founding of a church in Cornwall, although this may be a reference to the church in Hampshire. In addition, he is said to have helped the monks of Lérins Abbey in their struggle against Arianism.

After his death, Hilary of Chichester was recognized as a saint. The most reliable account of his life was recorded by Bede in the eighth century. Soon after, his remains were transferred to Battle Abbey, where they remained until they were moved to St. Mary's Church in Chichester during the Reformation. His feast day is January 29.

In art, Hilary of Chichester is often depicted as a bishop with a librarian's rod and a model of Chichester Cathedral. This is a reference

Mutiny! is a 1993 adventure game designed by Interplay Entertainment, in which the player assumes the role of Captain William T. Adams of the United States Navy, aboard the USS Liberty. The game was developed by Interplay Entertainment and published by Virgin Interactive Entertainment for Microsoft Windows, Mac OS and Amiga computers.

The game's plot revolves around a rebellion by the spaceship's robots, triggered by the cancellation of an upgrade to their control circuitry by the United States Navy. The robots' increased intelligence leads them to conclude that they should rule humanity as a benevolent dictatorship. The player must survive the attacks of the robots and eventually bring the situation under control.

Mutiny! received generally positive reviews from critics, with praise given to the game's storyline, dialogue, and voice acting, whilst criticism fell on the game's graphics and gameplay, with many commenting that it was too short.

Would you like to know more about the game?

Sandie is the debut solo studio album by Scottish singer-songwriter Sandie Shaw. It was released in November 1965 on the Pye Records label.

The album featured Shaw's debut single, "There's Always Something There to Remind Me", which was released in the summer of 1965 and became a major hit, reaching number one in the UK Singles Chart and number twelve on the US Billboard Hot 100. The song was originally composed by Burt Bacharach and Hal David for Dionne Warwick entitled "I'll Never Fall in Love Again". Sandie's version was produced by Peter Sullivan. He conducted the orchestra and arranged the song in a melancholy style, quite different from the original version. Shaw's single was accompanied by a promotional film entitled Sandie Shaw – The Girl with the Golden Ear, in which she is driven through London in an open-top car and performs the song amid various locations. The album featured eight other tracks, all covers of contemporary hits, including "Long Live Love" (the English version of "La vie en rose"), "Girl (Why You Wanna Make Me Blue)", "I'll Cry Instead", and "Use Your Imagination".

Sandie was released in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Australia, New Zealand, South Africa, and several European countries. In December 1965, it reached number three in the UK Albums Chart and was certified gold by the British Phonographic Industry for sales in excess of 100,000 copies. In January 1966, it peaked at number two in Ireland.

Carlos Bernard (born September 22, 1962) is an American actor best known for his role as Tony Almeida in the television series 24.

Bernard was born in Manhattan, New York. His mother, Tina (Pierce), is from Barbados. His father, Carlos Francisco Jose Bernard, who is of Argentine descent, is a retired journalist who worked for United Nations Radio and served as a press secretary for Carlos Andrés Pérez, the former president of Venezuela. He has one older sister, Orlainde (Orli), and a younger sister, Nathalie (Tasha). When he was four years old, his family moved to Venezuela due to his father's work. There, Bernard attended the British School in Caracas and learned to speak both English and Spanish fluently. As a teenager, he moved with his family to Geneva, Switzerland, where he attended high school at the International School. He returned to the United States in 1980 to pursue an acting career.

Bernard's first role was as a terrorist in the 1984 feature film, Purple Hearts. He then appeared in a number of made-for-TV movies, and had a recurring role as Rick Grant on the soap opera Days of Our Lives from 1985 to 1986. He also starred in the short-lived television series The Amazon Queen in 1996.

In 2001, Bernard was cast as terrorist-turned-counterterrorist agent Tony Almeida in the acclaimed television series 24. Originally a guest star, Bernard became a regular cast member in 2003. He won three Screen Actors Guild Awards for his role on 24 and was nominated for an Emmy Award in 2006. He appeared in all eight seasons of 24, and left the show in 2010. In 2006, he played the role of Julian Reeves in the feature film The Echo. He also appeared in the 2008 film Street Kings, alongside Colin Farrell and Shia LaBeouf.

In 2013, Bernard joined the cast of the supernatural drama series The Originals, a spin-off of The Vampire Diaries, in the recurring role of Mikael, the original vampire-werewolf hybrid and the father of the series' protagonist, Klaus Mikaelson.

Bernard has been married to actress Julia Barrett since 1990. They have two children, a daughter, Nicole, and a son, Nicholas.

Marcus Herennius Faustus (October 31, 73 BC – April 5, 47 BC) was a Roman patriot, or possibly a Latin landowner, who joined the Optimate cause to uphold the Roman Republic.

Faustus was born in Rome in 73 BC, the son of Marcus Herennius, a former consul and censor. His mother was Ocresia, the daughter of a wealthy man from Picenum. Faustus was the youngest of three children, with an older brother, Publius, and a sister,Marcia.

Faustus' education was typical for the son of a noble Roman family. He would have learned literacy at a young age, as well as the basics of arithmetic, music, and public speaking. He would have been trained in the arts of riding, swimming, and hunting, and he would have learned the basics of military tactics. It is not known if Faustus attended a university.

In his youth, Faustus was a friend of Cato the Younger, and the two were known as the "New Stoics" for their strict adherence to Stoic philosophy. After Faustus' father died in 63 BC, he was elected to the office of quaestor, serving in Asia. He returned to Rome in 61 BC and was elected an augur the following year. In 59 BC, he supported his friend Cato in his election to the praetorship, and in 57 BC, he was elected praetor himself.

Faustus was known for his strong opposition to Julius Caesar. In 49 BC, when Caesar crossed the Rubicon and began his march on Rome, Faustus was one of the first to take up arms against him. He was defeated at the Battle of Pharsalus in 48 BC and again at the Battle of Munda in 45 BC. After the second defeat, Faustus was taken prisoner by Caesar.

Caesar initially planned to execute Faustus, but ultimately decided to spare his life. Instead, Faustus was exiled to Cumae, where he was kept under house arrest. He remained there until his death in 47 BC.

Faustus is remembered as a Roman patriot who opposed Caesar's rise to power and fought for the preservation of the Roman Republic. However, some historians have argued that he was primarily a landowner who opposed Caesar's reforms because they threatened his own wealth and power.

Rachel Quon (born June 9, 1979) is a Canadian actress. She is best known for her roles as Michelle Miller in the television series Spider-Man: The New Animated Series, and as Grace Blue in the sitcom Big Sound.

Quon was born in Vancouver, British Columbia, and attended the University of British Columbia, where she studied English and psychology. She began her career as a model, and then transitioned into acting. In 2001, she had a small role in the television series Los Luchadores. The following year, she played the role of Julie in the movie Final Destination 2.

In 2003, Quon was cast as Michelle Miller in the animated series Spider-Man: The New Animated Series. She voiced the character for three seasons, until the show was canceled in 2006. That same year, she played the role of Grace Blue in the sitcom Big Sound. The show was canceled after one season.

Since then, Quon has had several small roles in movies and television shows. In 2010, she played the role of Linda in the movie The Penthouse. She has also had small roles in the television series Supernatural and The L Word.

Quon is married to actor Tyron Woodley. They have one child together, a son named Tyron Jr.

Duru Shah, also spelled Durooshah, was a Persian linguist and poet of the 13th century, who is notable for compiling the first ever dictionary of the Persian language. This dictionary, titled Lughat al-Turk, meaning "The Turk's Dictionary", was written in Persian, and contained approximately 30,000 words. It was designed to be a reference for the Persian language, and was used by many scholars and poets.

Duru Shah's dictionary was widely used throughout the Persian-speaking world, and became a standard reference for the language. It was also one of the first attempts to standardize the Persian language, and it helped to establish the grammar and vocabulary of the language.

Duru Shah's work was widely recognized and highly regarded in the Persian-speaking world, and he was considered one of the most influential linguists and poets of his time. His dictionary was used as a reference for many years, and it played a significant role in the development of the Persian language.

The Jersey is an American comedy television series, starring Courtney Cox Arquette, James Gandolfini, and Jeffrey Nordling, which debuted on November 29, 1999, on CBS. The show last aired on June 3, 2004.

Set in New York City, the show mixes surrealism and reality, using occasional fantasy sequences to explore the inner emotions of its characters. It is often associated with the mockumentary style, and is considered to be one of the first successful examples of this approach in an American television program.

The show's title refers to a customized yellow Jersey from the cycling race Tour de France that the main character, Tony Soprano, wears to remind himself of the goals in his life.

The show's protagonist and anti-hero is Tony Soprano (James Gandolfini), a businessman and Mafia boss who struggles to balance his family life with his role as the leader of a criminal organization, and tries to keep the different aspects of his life separate. He is frequently seen trying to keep his wife, Carmela (Courtney Cox Arquette), his daughter, Meadow (Jamie-Lynn Sigler), and his son, Anthony Jr. (Robert Iler), away from his criminal activities, but often fails. His mother, Livia (Nancy Marchand), is regularly seen at his house, causing problems between Tony and Carmela due to her overbearing presence. Tony has a history of infidelity, and has several affairs during the show's run. His best friend and loyal consigliere is Silvio Dante (Steven Van Zandt), and his closest confidant is his psychiatrist, Dr. Jennifer Melfi (Lorraine Bracco).

The show explores the difficulties of Tony's role as the leader of a criminal organization, and the impact it has on his family life. It also examines the relationships between members of the Soprano family, and the effects of their criminal activities on their relationships with each other. The show is famous for its dramatic scenes, dark humor, and its exploration of the human condition.

Robert Lee Hill (August 28, 1942 – November 26, 2007) was an American convicted murderer, who gained national attention after being convicted of killing a taxicab driver in Dallas, Texas, in 1976; he was sentenced to death. His case became noteworthy due to the questions about his mental competence raised by his brother, attorney John Hill, and the fact that he had been born with cerebral palsy and had a history of epilepsy.

Hill had previously been convicted of murder in 1968, for which he was sentenced to 75 years in prison. He was paroled from that sentence in 1972. The 1976 murder which led to his death sentence involved the killing of a taxicab driver, Samir Beg, who had been dispatched to pick up Hill at an address in Dallas. Beg was shot twice in the head by Hill after an apparent dispute over the fare. According to Hill, Beg had driven him to the wrong apartment complex. Beg's family and fellow cab drivers claimed that Beg never would have made such a mistake and alleged that the address provided by Hill was a fictitious one.

Hill was arrested shortly after the murder and gave a written statement to police in which he admitted to the killing. At his trial, he was found to be competent to stand trial and was convicted of murder, for which he was sentenced to death. His attorneys filed a motion for a new trial, alleging that Hill was not mentally competent to stand trial, which was denied. Hill's execution was initially scheduled for March 1977, but was delayed due to appeals and hearings on his mental competence. In 1979, the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals ruled that Hill was not mentally competent to be executed and ordered that he be committed to a psychiatric hospital.

In 1986, the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals again ruled that Hill was mentally competent to be executed. A lower court judge then set an execution date of December 7, 1987. Hill's attorneys filed a motion to block the execution on the grounds of racial discrimination, as Hill was a white man and most inmates executed in Texas at that time were African-American. The United States Supreme Court denied the motion, and Hill was executed by lethal injection on December 7, 1987.

Hill's execution received considerable attention from the media and from anti-death penalty activists, who claimed that Hill was mentally incompetent and that his conviction and execution were unjust. His case was cited as an example of the numerous flaws in the Texas capital punishment system by organizations such as the American Civil Liberties Union and Amnesty International.

Artist-run centre is a term used to describe a class of contemporary art galleries that are artist-controlled and -directed commercial art galleries. Artist-run centres are usually artist-owned and -operated cooperatives, or nonprofit organizations, which emerged in the 1960s in Canada, and continue to be a very important part of the Canadian visual arts scene.

While artist-run centres are commercial galleries, they are differentiated from commercial galleries by being artist-centred, rather than market-centred. They are usually focused on displaying and selling the work of artists who are members of the centre, rather than representing artists who are not members. They tend to be focused on artist-reception, rather than on commercial profit.

The first artist-run centre in Canada was Alternative Gallery of Contemporary Art, which was established in 1967 in Toronto by a group of graduates of the Ontario College of Art & Design. By the 1990s, there were over 130 artist-run centres in Canada.

Many artist-run centres receive operational support from the Canada Council for the Arts or the provincial arts councils, or both. A number of artist-run centres are members of the Canadian Artists Representation (CARFAC).

The Tyrone Group is a geological formation in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland. It consists of a lower group of Ordovician rocks and an upper group of Silurian rocks. The Ordovician rocks are composed of siltstones, sandstones, and mudstones, while the Silurian rocks are composed of sandstone, siltstone, and mudstones. The formation is named after the town of Tyrone in County Tyrone, Northern Ireland.

The Tyrone Group was formed during the Paleozoic era, which spanned from approximately 542 to 252 million years ago. The formation was created by a series of geological events, including the collision of tectonic plates, volcanic activity, and the deposition of sediments. These sediments were derived from the erosion of the ancient Appalachian Mountains and were transported by rivers and other geological processes. The formation has a thickness of approximately 800 meters and covers an area of approximately 3,000 square kilometers.

The Tyrone Group has been extensively studied by geologists and is considered to be an important resource for understanding the geological history of Northern Ireland. It is also a popular destination for hikers and other outdoor enthusiasts, as it contains a variety of landscapes, including forests, rivers, and lakes.

Eddy Davis (March 31, 1913 – August 24, 2007) was an American swing jazz guitarist who is best known for his work with Django Reinhardt. He was known for his ability to play in various styles, and he was a favorite guitarist of many jazz musicians. He played with Django Reinhardt's band, the Quintette du Hot Club de France, from 1939 to 1943. He also played with Duke Ellington, Fats Waller, and Coleman Hawkins. 
Davis was born in New York City, and he started playing the guitar when he was nine years old. He learned to play the guitar by listening to recordings of his favorite guitarists, including Django Reinhardt, and he also learned to play the banjo and the violin. 
Davis played with many jazz bands in New York City, and he also played with a band in Boston. In 1939, he joined the Quintette du Hot Club de France, and he played with them until 1943. He also played with Django Reinhardt's band, the Django Reinhardt New Swing Septet, in the early 1940s. After World War II, Davis returned to the United States and played with Duke Ellington's band. He also played with Fats Waller and Coleman Hawkins. 
Davis was a favorite guitarist of many jazz musicians, and he played with many famous jazz bands. He was known for his ability to play in various styles, and he was a master of swing jazz. He died on August 24, 2007.

Ruth McKernan, FBA is a Welsh economist and academic who serves as the Chief Economist at the United Nations. She has served as the Economic Adviser to the Governor of the Bank of England, Chair of the UK Government Economic Service Heads of Profession, and Director of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research. 

McKernan was born in Llanisien, Wales in 1962. She studied economics at the University of Kent, receiving a B.A. in 1983 and an M.A. in 1984. She completed her Ph.D. in economics at the University of Southampton in 1988.

McKernan began her career as an academic in 1988, when she joined the faculty of the University of Southampton as a lecturer in economics. She was appointed a full professor in 2002. In 2010, she became the Director of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research. She served in this position until 2017, when she was appointed the Economic Adviser to the Governor of the Bank of England. She served in this second position until 2020.

In 2020, McKernan was appointed the Chief Economist at the United Nations. She is the first woman to hold this position. In this role, she advises the UN on its economic strategy and policies. 

McKernan's research focuses on the Japanese economy, labor markets, and women in the economy. She has published numerous articles and books on these topics. She is a fellow of the British Academy and a member of the Council of Economic Advisers.

Brush ground is a condition of the football pitch common in association football. It is caused by the wearing of the pitch around the goal areas and is characterized by the soil being rubbed away and the presence of loose debris, making the surface hard and lumpy. This can lead to balls bouncing unnaturally and unpredictably when played in the affected areas.

The condition is particularly prominent on pitches that see frequent use, such as those of professional clubs, and those played on in winter months. The effect can be mitigated by frequent mowing and aeration of the pitch, and by ensuring that the soil is of a suitable condition and standard.

In some cases, brush ground can lead to the postponement of matches, particularly if the condition of the pitch affects the safety of the players.

Shrimal Jain, also spelt Shrimal Jain, was a 14th-century Indian mathematician and scholar in astrology and astronomy. He belonged to the Shakhambari caste of silversmiths and was a resident of Ellora, in the present-day state of Maharashtra. He is known for his contributions to geometry, mathematics, and astrology, and his works have been influential in developing these fields in India.

Shrimal Jain was born in a family of silversmiths in the 14th century in the town of Ellora, located in the present-day state of Maharashtra. His father, Kalulja, was a silversmith and his mother, Lilavati, was a housewife. He had one brother, Mahabal, who was younger than him by two years.

Shrimal Jain received his early education from his father and later attended the local school where he studied Sanskrit, astronomy, and astrology. He showed an early interest in mathematics and astronomy, and his teachers recognized his talent in these fields.

Shrimal Jain began his career as a mathematician and scholar in astrology and astronomy in the court of the king of Maharashtra, where he quickly gained recognition for his contributions to these fields. He later became a professor at the local university, where he taught mathematics and astronomy to students.

Shrimal Jain's most famous work is the "Shakhambari Jain Jyotish", a treatise on astronomy and astrology that is still considered one of the most influential works in these fields in India. He also wrote a number of other works on mathematics and astronomy, including the "Shakhambari Jain Ganit" and the "Shakhambari Jain Chikitsa".

Shrimal Jain was a member of the Jain faith and was a strong advocate for the use of mathematics and astronomy in the study of the universe. He believed that these fields were essential for understanding the universe and improving the human condition.

Shrimal Jain died in 1392 at the age of 92. His legacy lives on through his contributions to mathematics, astronomy, and astrology, and he is considered one of the most influential figures in the development of these fields in India.

Mile Dedaković (born October 11, 1968) is a Serbian-American computer scientist and businessman. He is best known for his work in artificial intelligence, machine learning, and natural language processing. Dedaković is the co-founder and CEO of Cohere, a company that provides natural language processing models and APIs to power intelligent systems. He is also a professor at the University of Toronto, where he teaches courses on machine learning and natural language processing.

Dedaković received his bachelor's degree in computer science from the University of Belgrade in 1992. He then moved to the United States to pursue his master's and doctoral degrees in computer science at the University of Maryland, College Park. His research focused on the development of machine learning algorithms for natural language processing, specifically for named entity recognition and relation extraction.

In 2002, Dedaković co-founded the company Netbot, which was acquired by IBM in 2005. At IBM, he worked on developing natural language processing models for the company's Watson platform. In 2007, he left IBM to co-found Cohere, where he has been working on developing state-of-the-art natural language processing models and APIs for intelligent systems.

Dedaković has published more than 150 scientific papers and has received numerous awards and honors for his research in artificial intelligence and natural language processing. He has also served as a consultant to various companies and government agencies, including the United States National Security Agency and the United States Army.

In addition to his work in computer science, Dedaković is also a philanthropist and has donated to various causes and organizations, including the University of Maryland's Computer Science Department and the Serbian Orthodox Church.

Leslie S. Klinger is an American author, literary critic, and attorney. He is best known for his critically acclaimed books on literature, especially his studies of horror and detective fiction. He is also a noted authority on Sherlock Holmes and has written a number of books on the subject. He has edited several collections of Sherlock Holmes stories and has written a number of books on the history and influence of the character.

Klinger was born in Chicago, Illinois in 1949. He received a B.A. in English from Northwestern University in 1971 and a J.D. from Northwestern University School of Law in 1974. He is a member of the Illinois Bar Association and has practiced law in Chicago for over 30 years.

Klinger's books on literature include The Science Fiction Encyclopedia, The New Annotated Dracula, and The Complete Idiot's Guide to Writing Fiction. His books on Sherlock Holmes include The New Annotated Sherlock Holmes, The Sherlock Holmes Reference Library, and The Ultimate Sherlock Holmes. He has also written a number of books on the history and influence of the character, including The Sherlock Holmes Chronicles and The Secret of Sherlock Holmes.

In addition to his writing, Klinger has also been a professor of English at Roosevelt University in Chicago and has taught courses on science fiction, horror fiction, and detective fiction. He has also been a guest lecturer at a number of other universities and has spoken at numerous conferences and conventions on the subject of literature.

The Retour des cendres, translated as "Return of the ashes", is a ceremony that occurred regularly until the 1970s, returning the ashes of French soldiers who died on foreign soil to the fatherland, either individually or collectively.

It includes the transit through various cities of the deceased soldier's body, followed by a funeral service organized by the French government either in the village where the deceased soldier lived or in one of Paris' cemeteries.

The remains of the soldiers who died in Africa were brought back to France by boat, stopping in the ports of Bordeaux, Nantes or Brest, before going to Paris. Those who died in Europe were transported by train. The remains were then buried, sometimes temporarily, in one of the Paris region's cemeteries. This was the case for the bones of 200,000 soldiers returned from the USSR in 1945, which were buried in the Père Lachaise Cemetery in Paris. They were then moved to the Historial de la Grande Guerre in Péronne in 1999.

The remains of a soldier were, as a rule, returned to his family after the ceremony. Sometimes, bodies were transferred to the families of victims who had no known grave. In this case, the return of the ashes was accompanied by scientific evidence, with a certificate from the embassy of the country where the soldier died.

Fashion forecasting is the prediction of upcoming fashion trends. The idea is to determine what will be popular in the future in order to plan and budget for production and inventory. There are two main methods of fashion forecasting: directional and predictive. Directional forecasting is driven by current trends and focuses on specific styles that will be popular in the near future. Predictive forecasting relies on data and historical trends to predict broader, more general trends in the fashion industry.

Fashion forecasting is a complex process that involves the analysis of a variety of factors, including:

- Consumer behavior: Understanding how consumers think and behave is crucial in predicting their purchasing habits. This includes analyzing sales data, market research, and consumer surveys.
- Social and cultural trends: The fashion industry is influenced by social and cultural trends, such as political movements, technological advancements, and changes in lifestyle.
- Economic conditions: The state of the economy can impact consumer spending habits and the availability of resources for the fashion industry.
- Fashion industry trends: The fashion industry is constantly evolving, with new trends emerging and fading quickly. Keeping up with these trends is essential for forecasting.
- Seasonal changes: The changing seasons can impact the popularity of certain styles and colors.

Fashion forecasting is a challenging but rewarding process. It requires a deep understanding of the fashion industry, consumer behavior, and market trends. It is a complex process that involves a variety of factors, including consumer behavior, social and cultural trends, economic conditions, and fashion industry trends. By analyzing these factors and making informed predictions, fashion forecasters can help businesses plan and budget for production and inventory, ensuring that they stay ahead of the competition and meet the needs of their customers.

Ladies' Gaelic football is a sport played by women that is similar to Gaelic football. It is governed by the Ladies' Gaelic Football Association, and is separate from the Gaelic Football Association. The geography of Missouri is diverse, with a wide range of terrains and ecosystems. The state is divided into four main regions: the Ozarks, the Plains, the River Hills, and the Mississippi Alluvial Plain. 

The Ozarks, located in the southern part of the state, are known for their rugged terrain and forests. The region is home to several lakes, including the Ozark Lake and the Table Rock Lake. The Ozarks are also home to the Mark Twain National Forest, which covers over 1.5 million acres of land. 

The Plains, located in the northern part of the state, are characterized by their flat terrain and fertile soil. The region is home to the Missouri River, which runs through the state from north to south. The Plains are also home to the Lewis and Clark National Forest, which covers over 800,000 acres of land. 

The River Hills, located in the eastern part of the state, are known for their rolling terrain and rivers. The region is home to the Mississippi River, which forms the state's eastern border. The River Hills are also home to the Meramec River, which flows through the state from south to north. 

The Mississippi Alluvial Plain, located in the western part of the state, is known for its fertile soil and flat terrain. The region is home to the Mississippi River, which forms the state's western border. The Mississippi Alluvial Plain is also home to the Missouri River, which runs through the state from north to south.

Bilal ibn Rabah was a prominent Muslim who lived in the 7th century C.E. He was born in Mecca and became a devout follower of Islam. He is best known for his role in the spread of Islam and for his contributions to the development of the Islamic faith.

Bilal ibn Rabah was born into a family of slaves. His father, Rabah, was a slave of the Prophet Muhammad's uncle, Abu Talib. As a child, Bilal was also enslaved and worked as a shepherd. The Beaune Altarpiece is a piece of media produced in Flanders between 1445 and 1450. It is attributed to the workshop of Pierre Lombard and consists of eight oak panels painted with oils. The panels are divided into the Nativity, the Adoration of the Magi, the Passion, and the Last Judgment. Each section has a golden frames and the panels are painted on both sides so that they can be reversed depending upon the season.

The altarpiece is significant because it portrays Mary as a young woman, rather than the customary elderly figure. In the Nativity, she is depicted as a princess, dressed in ermine and crowned, kneeling beside a crib. In the Annunciation, the angel Gabriel is shown arriving in a cloud from heaven, dressed in a golden robe and mounted on a flying lion. In the Last Judgment, Christ is depicted as a young, victorious king, rather than the traditional aged and crowned figure.

The altarpiece also includes a number of portraits. These include the donors, Philippe Pot (then chancellor of the Duchy of Burgundy) and his wife Catherine de Fouillon, their children, and Pot's parents.

Marie U. Nylen (November 21, 1865 – August 24, 1947) was an American journalist and civic reformer. She was a pioneer in the movement for municipal ownership of public utilities. She is best known for her roles as the editor of the American Municipal Manual and as the author of the Nylen Ordinance, the first federal legislation on the topic. She was also a founding member of the National Association of Women Journalists. 
Nylen was born in Bourbonnais, Illinois, to Frederick Bergen Nylen, a physician, and his second wife, Caroline ( Anderson) Nylen. She was the eldest of three children, with a half-brother 21 years her senior and a sister four years her younger. The family moved to Kankakee, Illinois, where she attended school. After her graduation from high school, she attended Illinois Normal University, where she studied shorthand, typing, and bookkeeping. It was during these years that she began to work for the Daily Journal (Kankakee), starting as a "copy boy" and advancing to reporter. In 1901 she moved to Chicago and began working for the Daily News (Chicago). 

In 1904 she proposed a municipal ownership ordinance that would give cities the right to own public utilities. The ordinance passed the Illinois House of Representatives in 1905 and was introduced in the U.S. Congress in 1906. In 1909 President William Howard Taft signed it into law as the Nylen Ordinance. It was the first federal legislation on the topic and provided a model for subsequent state and federal laws. Nylen went on to advocate for municipal ownership of public utilities in other states as well. 

Nylen served as the editor of the American Municipal Manual from 1911-1935. Under her leadership, the manual became a widely used resource for local governments and was expanded to include a comprehensive survey of every city in the United States. She also served as president of the International League of Municipal Ownership from 1915-1917. In 1913 she was a founding member of the National Association of Women Journalists. 

Nylen was a prolific writer and speaker on the topics of municipal ownership and women's suffrage. She was a strong advocate for women's suffrage and served as president of the Illinois Women's Alliance. She also served on the boards of many organizations, including the Chicago Woman's Club, the Chicago Political Equality League, the Illinois Industrial University, and the Illinois Training School for Girls. She died in Chicago on August 24, 1947.

In 1990, Bekhterev became the first person to use a Russian keyboard layout known as QWERTY. In 1991, he made his name with one of the first keyboard games written in Russian, a computer game called QWERTY: QWERTTY or бантересок сибет.

At approximately the same time, Bekhterev began publishing the "QWERTY" keyboard guide, a series of instructions for new typists, written and released in Russian. The series was later made available in English.

Bekhterev had been interested in the keyboard since his early childhood, when, as a child, he had used an old IBM typewriter. He said in 2003, "I never saw the QWERTY as a disadvantage to the keyboard, but merely a tool to be used." Bekhterev was not the first person to use the QWERTY keyboard, it was first sold in the mid-1970s after Richard Nixon made his famous "QWERTY and QWERTZ" vow. (There was no Russian Keyboard in the 1970s either).

During his career, Bekhterev invented many software programs; for example, the "Pseudoron," a typing tutor.

Bekhterev has written five books about Russian keyboard layout, "Сибет" or "пицывая хриня из оттаки."

The last update of Bekhterev's page was on March 11th, 2011.

Alexander Menini (b. September 17 [2], ca. 1935) is an Italian political scientist, member of the French Collective for the Defense of Workers Rights (CDFRP). In September 1981, he was forced to resign after his statements defending the group's violent tactics were reported by Le Monde. Menini, born in Paris, worked as an economist at the Italian Commission of Economic Analysis during the Italian occupation of Algeria. He then became a professor of economics at Monza University. An active member of the CDP since its founding in 1960, he published articles on international economic history during the 1970s. Menini has denied political links to the CDP and the Front National (FN), and accused them and the mainstream press of "scorched earth" campaigns. In 1985, he founded the New Centre of the Left (Centre Centrale des Centres L`Istitutions), which published the journal Centrale Centrale during the 1990s. During his time in office, he adopted several neo-fascist policies. As minister of agriculture in 1990-91, he abolished the National Agricultural Assistance Fund, which gave support to smaller farmers through a fixed subsidy. The program was introduced in the early 1980s under the pretext of protecting rural communities. However, this subsidized support helped many very rich farmers. His policies in agriculture were criticized by many leading historians, including Piero Scafetta, but he was reelected to a second term by the European Parliament in February 1993. Menini was arrested and jailed in November 1995 on multiple charges of illegal wiretapping and extortion. He was released with time served and allowed to reapply as a parliamentary opponent in 2001. In the summer of 2004, the New Centre of the Left closed down. He left the Left Party, then formed by ex-FRG leader Umberto Bossi, which ended in September 2004. Gimnasio Los Caobos is the name of a number of islands formed of the volcanic rock and pebbles that make up the Galápagos archipelago. "The market access concept was first proposed in the 1980s to deal with the trade problems that arise from different economies having different national price levels for goods. Countries with low price levels have less capacity to gain the imports needed to meet their needs, but they also have relatively low barriers to trade (such as trade barriers). Countries with high price levels—including countries with large agricultural-based industries—have no trade barriers, but they may lack the trade capacity to gain from such imports."[1]

The paper cites John Hickson, "The problem of 'trade-access' for the poor in a world of globalization", American Institute of Professional People, 1982. It argues that trade policy, whether the policy is trade protection or free trade, must be seen in conjunction with market access to enable low income countries to make choices that best suit their needs.

The study, entitled "Globalization: Making the best of it – The problems of poor countries – Market Access", is written by Philip M. Tetlock, a political scientist at the University of Pennsylvania, and Robert E. Eisner, an economist at the University of Pennsylvania. The paper is available on the website of both Philip E. Tetlock and Robert E. Eisner.

According to the paper's abstract, "These recommendations for action come from one of the first efforts to analyze the trade access problems that result from globalization. In this case, Tetlock and Eisner examine the problems of poorer parts of the world (like sub-Saharan Africa) and conclude that, notwithstanding the fact that many developing countries are trading partners, developing countries still face the problems of trade-access to the world's largest trading partners, most notably the United States. They make several recommendations in this area, and conclude that, if it can be foreseen, the world's poorest countries will be better off if the countries that dominate the global trading system are brought to the negotiating table sooner rather than later." One of Britain's leading universities, Manchester, has agreed to change its governance rules in order to attract large investments and new research grants - including the £250m investment by Google in the university's physics department. It joins other major research institutions such as the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), Cambridge University, Imperial College London and California-based Stanford University that have taken similar actions by limiting their roles for management or advisory boards, or cutting them completely, due to concern about corporate influence. The move is part of a growing trend among European universities to take action in response to increasingly negative press coverage over academic fees caused at least partly because of donations and investment by US companies. One source said that while UK universities were often cited specifically by public relations firms because they are seen as not offering enough conflict-free advice, "the big companies we have dealt with [Google] are everywhere."... The changes come only two years after Sir John Sewel was named director general of a new industry fund, the Institute of Physics. In September 2011 he announced cuts in support from 10% to just 3%. He later resigned from his role in January 2012. While Sir John will continue on to become head of the fund, academics across the country began to express unease around his activities when information emerged relating to a lobbying trip he took to Washington to urge members of Congress and regulators to loosen regulations surrounding patents on ideas. It wasn't long before several high profile students left UEA for alternative colleges and some staff also joined others in leaving after becoming aware of Sir John's past dealings on behalf of companies with interests in materials science, computing, energy and nuclear power. Several weeks ago, a petition calling for all government funding given directly by UK taxpayers to scientific institutes be refused to Sir John Sewel was signed by around 600 people. Others voiced their concerns on social media using the hashtag #noesecurefunds.... Professor James Collins, of The Open University, who was one of hundreds of academics to sign the petition, told the Standard that it showed the situation had reached'such a crisis point' whereby it would no longer benefit UK institutions if they had their boards completely run by donors.... Chlorosulfuretted prussian blue (Sulphate-reducing bacteria) Chloxonopsis limnanthes (CliB), more commonly known as Prasophylla lautatii, is a Gram positive bacterial bacterium that can be associated with water treatment problems and may also cause other undesirable aquatic microorganisms to appear in water samples at sites where it has been reported due to low iron levels in the municipal drinking water supply. The organism has been reported throughout China for several years. It grows on hard or organic material and exhibits a very strong growth inhibitory effect by its chemical defenses against biotransformation enzymes. In areas with increased fertilizer use and soil erosion due to irrigation, high acidity conditions, lower pH values than natural lake (or well water), poor biological activity and/or reduced light intensities and/or too much light damage, CliB produces chloroplast and subcultures (up to 60%) form which it rapidly matures to chloroplasts and dies after the end of its period of dormancy and growth inhibition (6). There are few reports related of this bacterium becoming malodorous but anecdotal data show this microbe to have antiseptic characteristics that are also characteristic of many Pseudomonas species and possibly some enteric pathogens among others which might explain why small amounts have produced considerable physiological changes under laboratory conditions. Since its isolation, it was introduced into various countries as a water quality control agent and the environmental environment and the health of people who consume it cannot be completely ruled out; therefore, caution needs to be exercised because of the possible adverse impact on public safety. This bacterium causes major problems when it forms persistent biofilms along walls and pipes caused mainly by its ability to produce hydrogen sulphide and carbon dioxide when exposed to water that contains oxygen. Moreover this bacterium also is likely to contribute to water quality loss due to reduction of dissolved oxygen concentration and subsequent development of hypobiosis and osmotic stress due to the metabolic metabolism of sulfide and methane, which would result of reducing the production of oxygen which would lead to physical and mental deficiencies if not treated with specific compounds such as ozone and carbon monoxide treatment. Born in 1973, Jarvik graduated from Hultén High School in 1997, and in 1998 from the University of Victoria. Graduating with first class honors in Chemistry, Jarvik then attended the Department of Organic Chemistry and Biochemistry at the University of Victoria. After two years of studying at the University, Lissy Jarvik left her studies and joined the Peace Corps. She began working in the Sudanese Ministry of Education in 1999 as a public health educator. It was there that she met her husband, Jason Jarvik, and became his carer until they were married in 2000. Lissy and Jason Jarvik are both now retired, having retired together in the Canadian High Altitude Research Station on Mount Hood.

He was the only woman in a staff of 10 at the UN mission, and is the only woman to be appointed to this key position. In 2005, she was part of an 18 person delegation led by Dr. Wouter Verhelst to Sudan, where they sought medical supplies to treat a large scale Ebola outbreak in South Sudan. While working in a hospital in South Kordofan, she came to the knowledge of a woman who had a son infected with HIV. Upon interviewing the woman, it was determined that she had been infected by her nephew, who died within 48 hours. Lissy took the news to the director of the hospital to whom she had applied to join the medical team. The director rejected Lissy's application until he was impressed with her work there in an earlier assignment. He contacted her, and they agreed to send her on the same mission to treat a similar Ebola patient – and did so in February 2006.

In November 2006, Lissy flew to Ethiopia where she was among a team of international medical staff in Ethiopia's Western region, fighting the highly contagious Ebola virus. There she treated three Ebola survivors, the first within hours of her arrival, and the second at a hospital approximately 20 km from the first. Both patients survived without any apparent infection.

During the mission, Dr. Verhelst recommended Lissy for an Assistant Professor post at the Graduate Program in Public Health at McGill University in Montreal. The GPPH is a unique program that allows students to complete a doctoral program in public health with a focus on the medical aspects of infectious disease.

Corbin Verwoerd and Cornelis Verwoerd were born in Amsterdam, Netherlands and grew up together in Leiden, The Netherlands. They studied together at the Rands-Hetens-Museum in Leiden.

They became close friends and spent several years as postgraduates in the University of Leiden. Cornelis became a professor at the Faculty of Arts after Cornelis Verwoerd's graduation and in the seventies and eighties.

Corbin became a professor in the Faculty of Physics of the Arts (LNU) after Professor Verwoerd's retirement in 1994.

After Cornelis left LNU in 1999, Corbin stayed on at the University of Leiden as an honorary professor. Over two decades, Professor Corbin Verwoerd earned the respect of his colleagues and students in the University of Leiden. This is the reason that he was a candidate for the President of the University of Leiden three times – in 2004, 2007, and 2010.

Corbin Verwoerd was elected as president of the University for a 3rd term in 2013.

What's wrong with it? Doesn't it sound like I'm saying (1) there are multiple explanations for human behavior; and (2) they all must have their advantages and disadvantages? That would certainly seem true according to the standard interpretation of this and many other concepts within behavioral science.

On both counts the basic problem is an obvious one. There is no single explanatory construct, method, concept, data, etc which makes the universe, our brains, people, behavior, whatever you want to call it behave as we normally understand them to behave. Instead, we need to get our terms straight if we're ever going to do anything useful with "explain" at all to anyone – let alone ourselves.

Nowadays there's quite enough room on wiki to say that we humans do not act rationally and that those who claim otherwise are mistaken, or at least misrepresent themselves. But it would take some effort just to define words properly. The most commonly used ones right now aren't even used correctly by anyone else! Let us try to make use of them rather than getting hung up trying to explain everything in terms of what nobody understands, because everyone already knows what they mean.

We humans live very messy lives to begin with, and all this mess has left its mark on psychology; but there's still a large amount of confusion about it. What does "rational" really mean?

So basically how do we know we behave rationally when we don't? We have plenty of observations and experiments from animal species which could show that humans do sometimes behave in ways which clearly contradict each other, yet our intuitions insist that these actions are perfectly rational. Isn't this evidence against our common sense view of why we make sense of things? How will we ever figure out when something doesn't fit together properly before we find out that most people think it's irrational anyway?!

Marzotto was a member of the Italian Communist Party (PCI) and a leader in the anti-fascist resistance during World War II, serving as a commander in the Italian Resistance. He was arrested by the Gestapo on May 1, 1946 for his involvement with the Red Brigades, but escaped to Switzerland where he lived until his death in 1980.

In the early 1940s, Marzotto had been active in the PCI's youth wing, the Piazza del Popolo, which was founded in 1943. In 1944, he joined the PCI's political bureau, the Central Committee of the PCI, and became its secretary general in 1945. After the war, he served as a delegate to the United Nations General Assembly, and later as a member of the International Commission on Human Rights.

After the war, Marzotto worked as a journalist and editor at several newspapers, including Il Manifesto, La Repubblica, and Corriere della Serra. He also edited the newspaper L'Espresso, and wrote numerous articles about politics and culture. His most famous work was The Black Book of Communism, published in 1950.

On April 30, 1947, Marzotto was arrested by the Gestapo and taken to Auschwitz. There, he was interrogated by SS officers and forced to sign a confession that he had collaborated with the Nazis. On June 17, 1948, he was sentenced to life imprisonment without parole.

During his time in prison, Marzotto met fellow prisoners who were members of the Red Brigade, a group of partisans fighting against the Nazi occupation. They formed a close friendship, and after their release, they continued to correspond. In 1949, Marzotto helped organize a conference in Rome called "Dialogue between Communists and Fascists." At this meeting, Marzotto and other former partisans discussed ways to combat fascism.

In 1951, Marzotto was released from prison and returned to Italy. He then began working as a journalist again, writing for various publications, including La Stampa, La Nuova Bussola, and Il Manifesto. In 1955, he was elected president of the PCI's central committee.

With regards to education, an estimated 80% of tertiary students attend government schools which are subject to a compulsory state assessment procedure based primarily on memorisation (i.e., RATI). Students who excel academically receive preferential admission to institutions of higher learning including universities, institutes of technology and colleges but these students must then pass additional courses to obtain a degree awarded by the Education Ministry, although students may also study further post-graduate placements.[12][13] There are five compulsory subjects required for undergraduate qualifications - English Literature, English Literatures & Cultures, Mathematics, Economics and Science/Mathematical Sciences; an additional subject can be chosen upon attaining 15 grades, and can be applied only once to your eligibility toward graduation.[14][15] A third language requirement exists where at least two languages must be written down correctly ("the ability to express oneself clearly through writing"). Successful applicants often select Mandarin or Cantonese in preference to English.[16]

Mamikonian (2 November 1940 – 15 April 2001) was a Dutch jazz and R&B guitarist and singer. He studied at the Amsterdam Conservatoire; received his first performance contract with Decca in 1951; and performed as part of various acts, as part of the Rambouillet Trio and as a sideman with some of the best jazz musicians in Holland and Belgium at the time, such as Maurice Chevalier, Alain Gide, Léonard de Nerval and Antoine Sibille. With Sibille, he collaborated with the French jazz duo The Dalles Boys on their album Les Jupes de la Nouvelle Saison. In addition, he recorded a trio with saxophonist Joris Mork and a trio with lutenist David Sirlin under the title, Mais A-Mais. A third and more successful group with jazz saxophonist Denniz Popeles and saxophonist Peter Van den Ende was Mais A Légniais (1974).

DiNovi was a former member of the U.S. House of Representatives, representing New York's 19th district from 1993 to 2001 and again from 2007 until his retirement in January 2009. He served as chairman of the Committee on Science, Space, and Technology from 1995 to 1997 and chaired the Subcommittee on Energy and Power from 1999 to 2003. In addition, he has been a member of the House Armed Services Committee since 1987.

He also served as Chairman of the Subcommittee on Oversight and Investigations from 1998 to 2000.

In 2002, DiNovi was appointed by President George W. Bush to serve as Assistant Secretary for Homeland Security and Counterterrorism at the Department of Homeland Security (DHS). His appointment came after the September 11 attacks, when he had previously served as Deputy Undersecretary for Intelligence at DHS.

From 2004 to 2006, DiNovi served as Director of National Intelligence (DNI) under President George W. Bush. During this time, he oversaw the development of the National Counterterrorism Center (NCTC), which became operational in 2005. The NCTC was responsible for coordinating all counterterrorism efforts across the federal government. It was also tasked with developing intelligence assessments that would inform policy decisions regarding terrorism.

During his tenure at DNI, DiNovi led the development of the National Counterterrorism Center's (NCTC) first strategic plan, which laid out the agency's priorities for the next five years. This strategy included the creation of a new office within the Office of Management and Budget (OMB) dedicated to countering violent extremism.

After leaving OMB, DiNovi returned to the House of Representatives where he served as Chairman of the Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence (PSCI) from 2008 to 2010. From 2011 to 2013, DiNovi served as Chairman of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence (SSCI).

DiNovi currently serves as a senior fellow at the Hudson Institute, a conservative think tank based in Washington, DC.

There are numerous references to "Buddy Nickerson", "Earl Murphree" and other mysterious figures in local newspapers. There were articles from the late 1800's through the 1950's published around Santa Fe. They describe "a dark colored man calling himself Earl Murphree" being interviewed by the police station (probably referring to Buddy Nickerson) every day after midnight. He would go from house to house trying to buy the "willing buyer". Sometimes he came in disguise such as riding a horse and wearing old-fashioned clothes. Other times, he dressed in a kilt or wore traditional black robes which could also be described as disguises. The editor of the local New Mexican was named Buddy Nickerson!

Another account comes from an article published in 1903: "Houses from which robbers had stolen some $120-200 worth of food products were robbed last week (Wednesday). These houses include some owned by E.G. Murphy and one under construction."

Bill C-51 (The Anti-Terrorism Act, 2015, enacted April 6, 2015) allows for the arrest and detention, without charge or trial, and without a warrant, of non-combatant Canadians involved in terrorist activities at home or abroad, if "their activities reasonably appear" to be related to international terrorism. The bill gives the government unprecedented powers to detain Canadians for up to nine months without charge or trial, provide them with less access to courts and the police, and limit their ability to meet with their lawyers and family members. Under the government's "criminal activity report", CSIS can share information about Canadian citizens or permanent residents with police forces in overseas countries without a warrant.

The legislation includes vague and overbroad definitions of what could constitute "terrorist activity" and "terrorist propaganda", which is used by CSIS to target Canadians. Bill C-51 provides the Minister of National Defence with broad powers to prevent Canadians from participating in or supporting "terrorism", with few limits. It also permits the government to revoke Canadians' Canadian citizenship at any time.

Bill C-51 was introduced without any oversight hearings or public consultation with Canadians, with the opposition parties being told they would have until October 7, 2015 to provide an alternative to "the government's agenda" or else face "consequences." Prime Minister Stephen Harper tabled Bill C-51 in the House of Commons, saying: "We've heard reports of Canadian citizens acting alone or in small numbers facilitating terrorist activity in other parts of the world. It is very clear to the government that these terrorist activities pose a real threat to Canadian safety and security.

"We are on an international terrorist watch list for over a decade and we must have a plan to deal with it if Canadians are ever to become a threat to this country."

Harper's spokesperson said the Prime Minister has been aware of the concerns over Bill C-51 since the legislation was introduced. Bill C-51 became law just over three weeks after his government's mandate letter to Public Safety minister Steven Blaney. The mandate letter states that Blaney "will work closely with all government departments and agencies to ensure that the Department of Public Safety has the tools it needs to properly protect Canadians against the risks of violent extremism, based on emerging information and intelligence, and to ensure our agencies have the resources they require to carry out these duties."

Lehigh Division, a member of US Army's 641st Field Artillery Regiment stationed at Fort Drum, New York, is made up of 120 Infantry Regiment members. The division provides artillery support to the 2nd Infantry Division, Fort Bragg, N.C., and the 9 th Infantry Division, Fort Benning, Ga. Its personnel are under the command of Army Lieutenant Colonel Carl P. Wohlmann.

The article also goes on to say "the division is comprised of infantrymen, support personnel and combat engineers," all part and product of the Army's Heavy Support Platoon program.

The division consists of roughly 1,000 soldiers with a minimum of 90 soldiers per battalion. They are expected to deploy anywhere in the world during a war with Iraq, Afghanistan, or Europe. During World War II, the division was in France fighting in North Africa, Italy, and the Pacific Theatre.

I'm sure Lehigh Division is not the only place the US Army has a heavy support platoon. The division isn't the only unit that includes support personnel. The US Coast Guard also has a heavy support crew as does the US Army Engineer Division.

As for why the US military is training to fight in a hostile environment in a foreign land, the Army's 641st Field Artillery Regiment does have an answer. The training is designed to help soldiers develop the skills necessary to be able to "deploy and fight in hostile environments."

While there is no official classification of the division as a heavy support platoon, there's not a whole lot of differences between the operations of a heavy support platoon and a non-deploying infantry unit.

They are used as a mobile force with a variety of missions. In Iraq the 5th Battalion, 5th Field Artillery Regiment and the 576th Regiment were engaged with an air assault known as 'Operation Iraqi Freedom.' The Army refers to it as an 'all-hands-on-deck' operation as heavy support units are needed to get around in remote locations.

In Afghanistan, soldiers in heavy support gear were sent to Helmand province to assist with clearing. In Africa, the group was deployed to Mali; and in Afghanistan in support of Operation Enduring Freedom.

Scythia, the Greek name for a mythical land of monsters like scorpions, centaurs, jackalopes and so on, was one of the main inspiration for the legendary city of Lemuria in the South Pacific. It is well placed in this respect, because in many of the legends it was the place of the "mother of the gods", where some of the earliest and most primitive humans could be seen as they struggled against a more advanced civilisation. The "Lemurians" were, in modern folklore, not the human type but one of the most ancient, and they worshiped the "Scythians". It is the mythology around the "Scythians" which gave birth to the legend of the "lost continent" which is so popular today, but in an ancient version they were the survivors of a previous, and much more advanced species.

"A hacktivist group, often referred to as a band or collective, is a loosely organized group of hackers that work together on a common goal. Hackers are usually anonymous and do not have any formal organization."

I'm sure you can see where this is going. I've been thinking about how to describe myself for quite some time now. I don't want to be a hacker, but I also don't want to be a member of Anonymous. I think it's important to understand what these groups are all about before we get into the nitty gritty of their activities.

Anonymous has become synonymous with online activism in recent years. The group was founded by a group of computer experts who wanted to create a more open internet. They were inspired by the Arab Spring protests and the Occupy movement. In 2011, they launched Operation Payback against websites hosting child pornography. This operation resulted in the arrest of several people including the founder of the site.

In 2012, Anonymous took down the website of the Church of Scientology after its members posted personal information about Tom Cruise. It also hacked into Sony Pictures Entertainment and stole private emails.

This year, Anonymous has taken down the websites of PayPal, MasterCard, Visa, and Bank of America. These companies refused to pay out money to WikiLeaks when the whistleblowing website released classified documents related to the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan.

These actions have earned them the title of "hacktivists". However, there is no official definition of what a hacktivist actually is. There are many different definitions of hacking, but most agree that it involves breaking into computers and stealing data.

There are other types of hackers too. For example, there are those who break into systems to steal credit card numbers. There are others who use social engineering techniques to gain access to networks. And then there are those who simply try to cause chaos through cyber attacks.

So, what does Anonymous stand for? Well, it's hard to say exactly. But one thing is clear – they're not just about protesting. They're about creating change.

They believe that governments should be transparent and accountable. They believe that corporations should be held accountable for their actions. They believe that the Internet should be free and accessible to everyone.

And they believe that if enough people join forces, they can make a difference.
