The hex sidekick is a powerful enemy, whose powers derive from a particular resource that can be stolen. A hex sidekick must be defeated in order for the player's hero to advance. A hex sidekick's abilities may allow it to make a critical attack, inflict critical damage, or perform a powerful action that would otherwise be impossible. The hex sidekick has the power to steal the resource of a specific creature, or a combination of creatures from various categories, in order to be defeated.

At the beginning of the game, a player must choose a hero as their hero sidekick and choose a hex sidekick as their hex sidekick for the game. The hex sidekick must be chosen over the hero's hero sidekick if the game rules allow. The hero's hex sidekick must not be the hex sidekick of the player's hex sidekick.

Some hex sidekicks have limited abilities, and require special abilities that are provided by the Hex Sidekick rules. Each hex sidekick hero has a specific category of creatures as a limit to their abilities. Some hex sidekick hero categories have a number of creatures in that category equal to 3, and the hex sidekick's power is the strength of the number of creatures in this category.

All of a player's hex sidekicks have a single power, that being their ability to steal a specific resource, from a specific creature type, or the combination of a number of creatures of a specific type. It is not possible to have two hex sidekicks with the same power. A hex sidekick cannot steal from a different type of creature than the one being attacked, so using a hex sidekick's power to attack a creature's resources would break the game (though this is possible if the hex sidekick possesses the proper item in order to access a different resource). If the player cannot physically make it to a hex team, their hex sidekicks must take the role of non-hero sidekicks, making use of the powers of a hero by using the same hex sidekick. Hex Sidekick also offers an option in addition to just stealing resources from an opponent, for the use of specific tactics

Andrew Morgan is a Canadian musician, singer and songwriter. He is best known as the lead singer and guitarist of the rock band The Dears.

Morgan was born in Toronto, Ontario. He began playing guitar at the age of 13. He was a member of the Toronto-based band Blinker the Star from 1995 to 1999. He co-founded The Dears in 1995 with keyboardist Patrick Krief.

The Dears have released six studio albums, the most recent being Times Infinity Volume One (2016). Morgan has also released two solo albums, Diamonds & Demons (2007) and Running Back to You (2009).

Morgan has appeared as a guest musician on several albums, including Stars' Set Yourself on Fire (2005), Broken Social Scene's Forgiveness Rock Record (2010) and Feist's Metals (2011).

In addition to his work with The Dears, Morgan has composed music for film and television, including the score for the film Young People Fucking (2007). He has also produced albums for other artists, including Patrick Watson's Close to Paradise (2006) and Basia Bulat's Heart of My Own (2010).

Elias Gyftopoulos (Greek: Ηλίας Γυυτόπουλος) (born 1934) is a Greek-American physicist and author, currently a Professor of Physics Emeritus at MIT.

Gyftopoulos was born in Athens, Greece, and received his B.Sc. in Electrical Engineering from the National Technical University of Athens in 1957. He then moved to the United States to study at MIT, where he received his S.M. in 1958 and Ph.D. in 1961, both in Nuclear Engineering.

After a year as a Fulbright Scholar at the University of Grenoble in France, he joined the faculty of MIT, where he has remained ever since. He was appointed full professor in 1971.

Gyftopoulos's research has ranged over a number of areas in nuclear engineering and physics, including reactor physics, fuel cycle analysis, and the problems of energy production and utilization. He is particularly well known for his work on the thermodynamic behavior of matter, which led to the development of the thermodynamic potential known as the "Gyftopoulos-Berkowitz" potential.

In recent years, Gyftopoulos has turned his attention to the question of what limits the efficiency of energy conversion processes, and how these limits might be overcome. He has also been active in the area of public understanding of science, and is the author of a number of popular books on physics and energy.

Gyftopoulos is a member of the National Academy of Engineering and a Fellow of the American Association for the Advancement of Science. He has been awarded the John de la Vergne Prize of the American Nuclear Society and the Bruce Betts Prize of the American Institute of Aeronautics and Astronautics.

Supernormal stimuli are sensory inputs that are more intense, vivid, or salient than what is typically experienced. The term was coined by zoologist Niko Tinbergen to refer to the intense colors and patterns on the shells of certain tropical butterflies that attract predators. Supernormal stimuli can occur in any sense modality, and have been extensively studied in the visual, auditory, and olfactory domains.

 Supernormal stimuli are often associated with evolutionary processes, as they can confer a selective advantage. For example, the gaudy colors of some tropical butterflies may help them escape detection by predators, while the loud calls of certain bird species may help them find mates. Supernormal stimuli can also be exploited by animals in captivity, leading to behaviors that are not seen in the wild. For example, domestic chickens prefer to peck at larger, more colorful targets, even when these targets are not food.

The study of supernormal stimuli has implications for understanding both normal and abnormal behavior. For instance, the over-stimulation of certain sense modalities can lead to perceptual distortions and even hallucinations. In some cases, such as with eating disorders, the pursuit of supernormal stimuli can become pathological.

By the early 21st century, Aronson had emerged as one of the leading American public servants, developing a reputation for honesty and integrity. After serving in the Carter administration, he was nominated by President Reagan to be the ambassador to Venezuela, a position he held from 1981 to 1983.

In 1983, Aronson returned to the United States and became the Secretary of State's Special Representative for Central America. In this role, he helped to negotiate the end of the El Salvador civil war and the Nicaragua-Contra Affair. He also served as the chief negotiator for the United States in the peace talks between the Colombian government and the FARC rebel group.

After leaving government service, Aronson worked as a lawyer and business consultant. He also served on the boards of several non-profit organizations, including the Center for a New American Security and the Aspen Institute.

Aronson was born in New York City on December 12, 1941. He received a bachelor's degree from Harvard College in 1963 and a law degree from Columbia Law School in 1966.

Aronson began his career as a lawyer in the New York office of the Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison law firm. He later served as a law clerk for Judge J. Edward Lumbard of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit.

In 1969, Aronson joined the United States Department of State as a member of the policy planning staff. He served as the Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Inter-American Affairs from 1977 to 1981.

Jackson Heights is a neighborhood in the northwestern portion of the borough of Queens in New York City. The neighborhood is part of Community District 3, and is served by the New York City Police Department's 115th Precinct.

 Jackson Heights is bounded on the north by Astoria, on the east by Elmhurst and Corona, on the south by Woodside, and on the west by Sunnyside. The main thoroughfare through Jackson Heights is Northern Boulevard. The ZIP code for Jackson Heights is 11372.

The area now known as Jackson Heights was originally part of the town of Newtown, which was founded in 1642. The village of Jackson Heights was established in 1885. The Jackson Heights Historic District, which covers 82nd Street to 85th Street between Northern Boulevard and 37th Avenue, was designated a National Historic Landmark in 1993.

The neighborhood is diverse ethnically, with a large population of Hispanic and Asian residents. It is also home to a significant LGBT community. Jackson Heights has been described as a "model for successful urban living" by the Urban Land Institute.

Suzy Whaley (born August 4, 1965) is an American professional golfer, currently a member of the LPGA Tour. She is also the head golf professional at Blue Fox Run Golf Course in Avon, Connecticut.

Whaley was born in Hartford, Connecticut. She attended high school at Conard High School in West Hartford, where she played on the golf team. She then attended the University of Hartford, where she played on the golf team.

In 2002, Whaley became the first woman to qualify for a PGA Tour event, the Greater Hartford Open, by winning a PGA of America sectional qualifying tournament. She missed the cut in the tournament.

In 2003, Whaley became the first woman to win a PGA of America event, the Connecticut Open, by defeating Mike Small in a playoff.

In 2004, Whaley became the first woman to qualify for the PGA Championship, by winning the PGA Professional National Championship. She missed the cut in the tournament.

In 2006, Whaley was inducted into the Conard High School Athletic Hall of Fame.

In 2008, Whaley was inducted into the University of Hartford Athletic Hall of Fame.

In 2009, Whaley was inducted into the Connecticut Golf Hall of Fame.

Glen Lake Sanatorium was a tuberculosis (TB) sanatorium between 1913 and 1966, treating patients with TB from all over Western Canada. It was located in the village of Glenella in the rural Municipality of Glenella – Lloydminister.

The facility was opened in 1913 by the Glenella Sanatorium Company. It consisted of a two-storey main building with a capacity of 60 patients, and two smaller buildings which housed the kitchen, laundry and power plant. A third small building later housed the x-ray equipment.

The sanatorium treated patients with a combination of fresh air, rest and good nutrition. The patients were encourage to be active, and took part in activities such as gardening, hiking, horseback riding and swimming.

The sanatorium had a high success rate, and by the 1930s was treating patients from all over Western Canada. In 1966, the sanatorium was closed down and the buildings were sold. The main building was converted into a seniors’ home, and the other buildings were demolished.

Hasan Abdullayev (Azerbaijani: Hasan Əbdülləyev, Russian: Гасан Абдуллаев; born January 1, 1966) is an Azerbaijani politician who has been Prime Minister of Azerbaijan since 4 April 2018.

Abdullayev was born in the village of Qaradağlı of Qaradağ Rayon. He graduated from the Azerbaijan State University of Economics in 1988 and received his PhD in economics in 2001.

From 1988 to 1991, Abdullayev worked as an economist at the Azerbaijan State Statistics Committee. From 1991 to 1994, he was the head of the economic section of the Azerbaijan Embassy in Moscow. In 1994-1995, he was the first deputy chairman of the Azerbaijan State Statistics Committee. From 1995 to 2000, he was the chairman of the State Statistics Committee.

In 2000, Abdullayev was appointed as the Azerbaijani Minister of Economic Development. He served in this position until 2003. In 2003-2004, he was the Azerbaijani Ambassador to the United States.

From 2004 to 2018, Abdullayev was the Azerbaijani Minister of Industry and Energy. In April 2018, he was appointed as the Prime Minister of Azerbaijan.

Carlos Graham is an accomplished businessman, entrepreneur and investor. He is the chairman and CEO of CG Capital, a private investment firm. He has also served as the chairman of the board of directors of the National Association of Real Estate Investment Trusts (NAREIT) and as a member of the board of directors of the National Multifamily Housing Council (NMHC).

Graham is a trustee of the Urban Land Institute (ULI) and a member of its executive committee. He is also a member of the ULI Foundation Board. He is a member of the Real Estate Roundtable and a founding member and chairman of the Board of Directors of the Real Estate Investment Securities Association (REISA). He is a member of the Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat (CTBUH).

 Graham has a bachelor's degree in architecture from the University of Miami and a master's degree in real estate development from Columbia University.

Rockwood Hall (1887-1955) was an American estate located in Tuckahoe, Westchester County, New York.

It was designed by architect Stanford White for businessman Jay Gould and his family. The estate's centerpiece was a Beaux-Arts mansion, which was completed in 1888. The house was destroyed by fire in 1955.

The estate also included several outbuildings, including a carriage house, stables, greenhouse, and an outdoor amphitheater. Gould also constructed a 9-hole golf course on the property.

The estate was eventually sold by the Gould family in 1927. It was later purchased by the City of New York, which turned it into a park.

Erythrocyte fragility refers to the increased susceptibility of erythrocytes to mechanical stress and damage. Erythrocyte fragility can be caused by a variety of factors, including inherited disorders, acquired disorders, and medications. Treatment of erythrocyte fragility typically involves avoidance of mechanical stress and damage, and may also involve blood transfusions and other medical interventions.

Inherited disorders that can cause erythrocyte fragility include hereditary spherocytosis, elliptocytosis, and pyropoikilocytosis. Acquired disorders that can cause erythrocyte fragility include autoimmune hemolytic anemias, certain types of anemia, and certain infections. Medications that can cause erythrocyte fragility include certain antibiotics, non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), and cancer chemotherapy agents.

Erythrocyte fragility can lead to a number of complications, including anemia, jaundice, and bleeding. Severe erythrocyte fragility can be fatal.

Patrick Jonker (born 25 October 1975) is an Australian former professional road racing cyclist. He was a professional from 1998 to 2006, and is best known for his stage win in the 2002 Tour de France.

Jonker was born in Brisbane, Queensland. He began his career as a mountain biker, before switching to road racing. He won the Australian National Road Race Championships in 1998.

Jonker turned professional with the Dutch team Rabobank in 1998. He rode his first Tour de France in 1999, finishing in 84th place. In 2000, he won a stage of the Tour de France, and finished in 37th place overall.

In 2002, Jonker won a stage of the Tour de France, and finished in 13th place overall. He also won the Australian National Road Race Championships that year.

Jonker retired from professional cycling in 2006.

Lorna Simpson (born 1960) is an American artist known for her photographs, films, and videos that explore the relationships between gender, race, history, and memory.

Simpson was born in Brooklyn, New York, and received a BFA in photography from the School of Visual Arts in 1982. She began her career as a photographer, and her early work often incorporated text as a means of exploring issues of identity and history. In the mid-1980s, she began working with video, and her work from this period often explored the experiences of black women.

Simpson has exhibited her work internationally, and her work is included in the collections of the Museum of Modern Art, the Whitney Museum of American Art, and the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, among others. She has been the recipient of numerous awards, including a MacArthur Fellowship and the Wexner Prize.

John Rucho (born December 13, 1949) is an American politician. He is a member of the North Carolina General Assembly representing the state's forty-second Senate district, including constituents in Anson, Montgomery, Richmond, Stanly, and Union counties. A Republican, he was first elected to the Senate in 2010.

Rucho was born in Charlotte, North Carolina, and graduated from East Mecklenburg High School. He then attended the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, where he received his bachelor's degree in business administration in 1971. After graduation, he worked in the banking industry for several years.

In the early 1980s, Rucho became involved in local politics, serving on the Charlotte-Mecklenburg Board of Education from 1982 to 1988. He was then elected to the North Carolina Senate in 2010.

During his time in the Senate, Rucho has been a vocal opponent of the Affordable Care Act, and has also been a leading proponent of tax reform in North Carolina. In 2013, he was one of the primary sponsors of a bill that would have eliminated the state's personal and corporate income taxes, and replaced them with a higher sales tax. The bill was ultimately unsuccessful.

Rucho has been married to his wife, Cindy, for over 40 years. They have two children and four grandchildren.

Bengt Bedrup (16 June 1944 – 14 September 1997) was a Swedish auto racing driver. Bedrup began his racing career in 1966, competing in Formula Junior. The following year he switched to driving Formula Vees, winning the Swedish championship in 1968. Bedrup continued to drive Formula Vees until 1971, when he returned to Formula Junior. In 1973 he made his first appearance in Formula Three, driving for March. Bedrup moved to Formula Two in 1974, but only competed in one race. He returned to Formula Three in 1975, driving for Maurer. The following season he switched to March, but only competed in one race. Bedrup returned to Formula Two in 1977, driving for ATS. The following year he switched to March, but only competed in one race. Bedrup returned to Formula Three in 1979, driving for Maurer. He finished the season in sixth place in the standings. In 1980 he switched to March, but only competed in two races. Bedrup returned to Formula Three in 1981, driving for March. He finished the season in eighth place in the standings. In 1982 he competed in the World Championship Formula One series, driving for Tyrrell. He finished the season in 18th place in the standings. In 1983 he competed in the World Championship Formula One series, driving for McLaren. He finished the season in 21st place in the standings. In 1984 he competed in the World Championship Formula One series, driving for RAM Racing. He finished the season in 14th place in the standings. In 1985 he switched to the Formula 3000 series, driving for AGS. He finished the season in seventh place in the standings. In 1986 he switched to the World Sports Prototype Championship, driving for Lancia. He finished the season in ninth place in the standings. In 1987 he competed in the World Sports Prototype Championship, driving for Lancia. He finished the season in seventh place in the standings. In 1988 he competed in the World Sports Prototype Championship, driving for Lancia. He finished the season in seventh place in the standings. Bedrup retired from racing after the 1988 season. He died on 14 September 1997.

John Coates, Jr. (October 9, 1886 – June 11, 1940) was an American tenor who sang leading roles with the Metropolitan Opera and other companies in the United States and Europe in the first half of the 20th century.

Coates was born in St. Louis, Missouri, the son of a successful businessman. He studied voice first with a local teacher, then in New York City with Pasquale Amato. Coates made his professional debut in vaudeville in 1903, then sang in theatre orchestras and with Gilbert and Sullivan companies on tour in the United States and Canada. In 1908 he was engaged as a chorus member at the Deutsches Landestheater in Prague, where he also sang small roles; he remained there for two seasons.

Coates made his operatic debut in 1910, as Tamino in Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart's Die Zauberflöte at the Budapest Opera. He sang there for two seasons, then moved to Frankfurt am Main, where he appeared for one season at the Opera Kremlinbur intellectuale. He sang the role of Nadir in the German premiere of Georges Bizet's Les pêcheur de perles in Frankfurt in 1911. He was engaged by the Munich Opera in 1912, where he sang roles including Tamino, Cavaliere Belfiore in Johann Strauss II's Eine Nacht in Venedig, and the title role in Peter Cornelius's Der Barbier von Baghdad.

In the winter of 1912-13, Coates appeared as a guest artist at the Vienna Court Opera, where he sang the title role in Franz Lehár's The Merry Widow. He returned to the United States in 1913 to appear in vaudeville and on Broadway, then sang in Chicago and San Francisco. In 1914 he appeared in opera in Philadelphia and New York City.

Coates made his debut at the Metropolitan Opera in New York City on November 28, 1914, as Gaston in Giacomo Meyerbeer's Les Huguenots, opposite Enrico Caruso. He remained at the Met for 13 seasons (1914-1927), singing leading roles in a variety of operas in Italian, French, and German. He also appeared as a guest artist with opera companies in Boston, Chicago, Philadelphia, and San Francisco.

Leander James McCormick (March 3, 1819 – May 16, 1900) was an American inventor and businessman. He was the president of the McCormick Harvesting Machine Company, which later became part of the International Harvester Company.

McCormick was born in Rockbridge County, Virginia. He was the third child of inventor Cyrus McCormick and his wife, Mary Ann (née Hall). He attended William and Mary College and the University of Virginia, but did not graduate from either institution.

In 1839, McCormick began working with his father on the design of a reaper, a machine that would revolutionize agriculture. The first prototype was built in 1840, and the first production model was built in 1841. The McCormick reaper was patented in 1845.

In 1847, McCormick moved to Chicago, Illinois, where he established the McCormick Harvesting Machine Company. The company became one of the largest manufacturers of agricultural equipment in the world.

McCormick was also an active philanthropist. He donated money to the University of Virginia, the McCormick Theological Seminary, and the Chicago Museum of Science and Industry.

McCormick died in 1900 at his home in Chicago. He was survived by his wife, Nettie Fowler McCormick, and their four children.

Billy Gladstone (January 25, 1870 – February 15, 1939) was an American jazz drummer. He was one of the earliest jazz drummers, and helped to develop the role of the drum set in jazz.

Gladstone was born in New York City, the son of a bandleader. He began playing drums at an early age, and by the age of 16 he was playing in vaudeville and burlesque shows. He soon became one of the most in-demand drummers in New York, playing with some of the biggest names in show business, including Lillian Russell, Ada Jones, and Eddie Cantor.

In the early 1900s, Gladstone began playing drums in jazz bands. He played with the Original Dixieland Jass Band on their groundbreaking recordings in 1917, and with the New Orleans Rhythm Kings in the 1920s. He also played with Bix Beiderbecke and Frankie Trumbauer in the legendary "Whiteman hot jazz" band.

Gladstone was a master of the early jazz style of drumming, which was based on marching band and vaudeville drumming. He was one of the first drummers to use the bass drum extensively in jazz, and was also one of the first to use the cymbal for rhythmic effect. He helped to develop the role of the drum set in jazz, and was an influence on all subsequent jazz drummers.

Gladstone retired from music in the 1930s, and died in New York City in 1939.

George Harold "Gabby" Sisler (March 24, 1893 – March 26, 1973) was an American professional baseball player. He played first base for 15 seasons in Major League Baseball (MLB) for the St. Louis Browns, Brooklyn Dodgers and Boston Braves. Sisler was elected into the National Baseball Hall of Fame in 1939.

Sisler played his entire career with the Browns and Dodgers. His best season came in 1920 when he established major league records for batting average (.407) and hit by pitch (51). Along with Doc Crandall, he is one of only two Brooklyn Dodgers players to ever lead the league in hit by pitch.

Sisler was also a two-time batting champion, setting the American League (AL) record for fewest strikeouts in a season (4) in 1922. He still holds the AL record for most consecutive games played at first base (822).

A Baltimore native, Sisler attended Mount St. Joseph's College and the University of Maryland, College Park. He briefly served as a school teacher before his professional baseball career began.

Sisler died of a heart attack in 1973.

The University of Málaga (Spanish: Universidad de Málaga) is a public university in Málaga, Andalusia, Spain. It was established in 1972, and currently has over 70,000 students.

The university has faculties of Economics, Law, Humanities, Sciences, and Business and Social Sciences. It also has schools of Medicine, Dentistry, Pharmacy, Nursing, and Engineering.

The university's main campus is in the city of Málaga, with additional campuses in Antequera, Fuengirola, and tedious. In total, the university has over 170 buildings.

The university library has over 1.3 million books and journals.

Leonti Mroveli (Georgian: ლეონტი მროველი, 11th century) is the author of The Knight in the Panther's Skin, Georgia's national epic poem.

Mroveli is believed to have been a nobleman from the province of Tao-Klarjeti in southwestern Georgia. He is thought to have lived in the second half of the 11th century, and to have been a contemporary of King David IV of Georgia, who is mentioned in the poem.

The Knight in the Panther's Skin tells the story of two friends, Tariel and Mebod, who go on a series of adventures in search of the hand of the beautiful princess Nestan-Darejan. Along the way, they must overcome a number of challenges, including dragons, giants, and an evil sorcerer.

The poem is written in a complex Georgian verse form known as mshvelieri, and is considered to be one of the masterpieces of Georgian literature. It has been translated into many languages, including English, French, German, Russian, and Japanese.

Tisulsky District is an administrative and municipal district (raion), one of the twenty-one in Kemerovo Oblast, Russia. It is located in the center of the oblast. The area of the district is 3,200 square kilometers (1,200 sq mi). Its administrative center is the town of Tisul (which is not administratively a part of the district). Population: 31,849 (2010 Census); 32,849 (2002 Census); 35,849 (1989 Census). The population of Tisul accounts for 35.8% of the district's total population.

The district was established on August 1, 1927.

Iqbal Assegaf is an Indonesian human rights lawyer and chairman of the Morocco-based International Institute for Justice and the Rule of Law (IIJ). He is also the legal counsel for the family of Munir Said Thalib, an Indonesian human rights activist who was assassinated in 2004.

Assegaf was born in Jakarta, Indonesia on October 9, 1961. He graduated from the Faculty of Law at the University of Indonesia in 1985 and obtained a Master of Laws degree from Duke University in 1994.

Assegaf has worked as a human rights lawyer in Indonesia for over 25 years. He has represented various political prisoners, including members of the Indonesian Communist Party (PKI), in court. He has also represented victims of the 1965-66 Indonesian massacre in their quest for justice.

In 2004, Assegaf represented the family of Munir Said Thalib, an Indonesian human rights activist who was assassinated on a Garuda Indonesia flight. Assegaf helped secure a conviction against the captain of the flight, Pollycarpus Budihari Priyanto, for his role in the murder.

Assegaf is the chairman of the Morocco-based International Institute for Justice and the Rule of Law (IIJ). The IIJ is an independent, non-profit organization that provides training and technical assistance to government officials, judges, lawyers, and civil society organizations on the rule of law and human rights.

Assegaf has received numerous awards for his work, including the Raoul Wallenberg Award from the University of California, Berkeley School of Law in 2006, the John D. Lewis International Human Rights Award from the American Bar Association in 2009, and the Human Rights Watch Defender Award in 2010.

Sri Mahalakshmi (Sanskrit: श्री महालक्ष्मी, IAST: Śrī Mahālakṣmī), also known as Sri or Lakshmi, is the Hindu goddess of wealth, fortune and prosperity. She is the wife and shakti (energy) of Vishnu, one of the principal deities of Hinduism and the main character of the Bhagavata Purana.

Lakshmi is also an important deity in Jainism and found in Jain temples. Lakshmi has also been a goddess of abundance and fortune for Buddhists, and was represented on the oldest surviving stupas and cave temples of Buddhism. In Buddhist sects of Tibet, Nepal and southeast Asia, goddess Vasudhara mirrors the characteristics and attributes of the Hindu goddess Lakshmi with minor iconographic differences.

Lakshmi is also called Sri or Thirumagal because she is endowed with six auspicious and divine qualities, or gunas, and is the divine strength of Vishnu. In Hindu religion, she was born from the churning of the primordial ocean and she holds lotus in her hand, a symbolism for fortune, self-knowledge and spiritual liberation.

As the goddess of wealth and prosperity, Lakshmi is also invoked for the removal of obstacles to one's success and is believed to bestow good luck.

Surachman Tjokroadisurjo (born October 11, 1949) is an Indonesian businessman and politician. He is the founder and owner of the PT Triputra Agro Persada, one of Indonesia's largest palm oil companies. He is also a member of the Indonesian People's Representative Council, representing the Golkar Party.

Tjokroadisurjo was born in Wonogiri, Central Java. He graduated from the Bandung Institute of Technology with a degree in civil engineering in 1974. He then worked in the construction industry for several years.

In 1982, Tjokroadisurjo founded PT Triputra Agro Persada, a palm oil plantation company. The company now has over 200,000 hectares of palm oil plantations in Indonesia. It is one of the country's largest palm oil producers, and exports its products to China, India, and Europe.

Tjokroadisurjo has also been active in politics. He was a member of the Golkar Party's Central Board from 2004 to 2009. In 2009, he was elected to the Indonesian People's Representative Council, representing the Golkar Party.

Franklin S. Cooper (born October 10, 1967 in Huntington Beach, California) is an American political scientist, lawyer, and writer.

Cooper specializes in voting behavior, interest groups, legislative politics, and the American presidency. He is the author of The Voting Wars: From Florida 2000 to the Next Election Meltdown (Yale University Press, 2012), which won the 2013 award for the best book on elections, campaigns, and voting from theAmerican Political Science Association. He is also the co-author (with Lawrence Baum) of Parties, Interest Groups, and Campaign Finance in the United States (6th edition, CQ Press, 2016).

Cooper has written for a range of publications, including The Washington Post, The New York Times, The Los Angeles Times, Slate, and The Huffington Post. His work has been featured on NPR, MSNBC, and Fox News.

Cooper is a Professor of Political Science at the University of California, Riverside. He received his B.A. from the University of California, Irvine and his Ph.D. from the University of California, San Diego.

The Sultanate of Ifat (also called the Kingdom of Ifat; Ge'ez: ሽልማት ኢፋት, Šəlmāt ʾIfāt, Arabic: سلطنة إفات‎) was a medieval Muslim state in the eastern region of the Horn of Africa. Led by the Walashma dynasty, it was centered in the city of Zeila and ruled parts of what are now eastern Ethiopia, Djibouti, and northwestern Somalia.

Ifat first emerged in the 13th century, when a group of emirs from the Walashma clan conquered the Kingdom of Aksum, which was situated between modern-day Ethiopia and Djibouti. The conquest of Aksum marked the end of the Solomonic dynasty's rule in Ethiopia, and also resulted in the decline of the Axumite Empire. The Ifat Sultanate's sphere of influence then extended across northern Ethiopia, Djibouti, and Somalia.

During its existence, the sultanate engaged in a series of battles with the neighbouring Christian Ethiopian Empire and the Adal Sultanate. Ifat's defeat of the Solomonic Empire at the Battle of Semien in 1332 marked a turning point in the struggle between the two states. In subsequent years, the Ifat Sultanate was defeated several times by the Ethiopian Empire, and finally conquered by Emperor Amda Seyon I in 1344.

The sultanate was subsequently dissolved, and its territories were incorporated into the Ethiopian Empire.

B. Venkateshwarlu (born October 15, 1967) is an Indian politician. He was a member of the 13th Lok Sabha from the Machilipatnam constituency in Andhra Pradesh.

Venkateshwarlu was born in Machilipatnam, Andhra Pradesh. He received his B.A. from Andhra University in 1988 and his LL.B. from Osmania University in 1992.

Venkateshwarlu was elected to the Lok Sabha from Machilipatnam in 1999. He was a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Science and Technology, Environment and Forests.

In 2004, Venkateshwarlu was re-elected to the Lok Sabha from Machilipatnam. He was a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Science and Technology, Environment and Forests.

In 2009, Venkateshwarlu was once again elected to the Lok Sabha from Machilipatnam. He was a member of the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on Science and Technology, Environment and Forests.

James Perrot (born October 18, 1814 in London, England; died October 18, 1884 in London, England) was an English actor and theatre manager.

Perrot made his stage debut in 1832, at the Theatre Royal, Edinburgh, as Young Norval in John Home's play Douglas. He soon afterwards joined the company at the Theatre Royal, Bristol, where he remained for two years. In 1834 he appeared at the Theatre Royal, Covent Garden, as Young Norval, and afterwards played a variety of characters there and at other London theatres.

In 1841 Perrot joined the company at the Theatre Royal, Haymarket, under the management of Charles Kemble, and remained there for four years. He then went on a provincial tour, and in 1846 he joined the company at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, under the management of Benjamin Webster.

In 1847 Perrot married the actress Harriet Smithson, and the following year they went to America, where they appeared together in a number of cities. They returned to England in 1850, and Perrot once again appeared at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane.

In 1851 Perrot and his wife went to Australia, where they appeared in a number of cities. They returned to England in 1854, and Perrot once again appeared at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane.

In 1855 Perrot joined the company at the Theatre Royal, Brighton, under the management of John Hollingshead. He remained there for two years, and then went on a provincial tour.

In 1858 Perrot joined the company at the Princess's Theatre, London, under the management of John Hollingshead. He remained there for two years, and then went on another provincial tour.

In 1862 Perrot joined the company at the Theatre Royal, Manchester, under the management of John Hollingshead. He remained there for two years, and then went on yet another provincial tour.

On 8 May 1797, the crew of the British warship HMS Bounty mutinied against their commander, Lieutenant William Bligh. Led by Acting Lieutenant Fletcher Christian, the mutineers seized control of the ship from Bligh and set him and 18 loyalists adrift in the ship's launch. The mutineers then sailed the Bounty back to Tahiti, where they set the ship on fire and settled on the island.

The mutiny has been popularly portrayed in several films and books, most notably the 1962 film Mutiny on the Bounty starring Marlon Brando and Trevor Howard, and the 1984 film The Bounty starring Mel Gibson and Anthony Hopkins.

Alexei Leonidovich Kudrin (Russian: Алексе́й Леони́дович Ку́дрин; born 30 September 1960) is a Russian economist, public figure, and former government official who served as the Minister of Finance of the Russian Federation from 2000 to 2011. He was also the Chairman of the Board of Trustees of the Civil Initiatives Committee, a member of the Board of Trustees of the Gaidar Institute for Economic Policy, and a member of the Board of Trustees of the Russian Economic School.

Kudrin was born in Leningrad. He graduated from the Leningrad State University in 1982 with a degree in economics. He later studied at the St. Petersburg State University, where he earned his Ph.D. in economics in 1990.

Kudrin began his career in the Soviet Union's Ministry of Finance in 1982. He worked in the ministry's International Economic Relations Department. In 1991, he was appointed the ministry's head of the Department for External Economic Relations.

In March 1992, Kudrin was appointed the first deputy minister of finance of the Russian Federation. He served in this position until May 2000, when he was appointed the minister of finance. He served in this position until 2011.

As finance minister, Kudrin was a key figure in the Russian government's economic policy. He was a proponent of fiscal conservatism and advocated for lower taxes and smaller government spending. He also worked to reduce Russia's budget deficit and to stabilize the country's currency, the ruble.

Kudrin resigned from his position as finance minister in September 2011, after disagreements with then-President Dmitry Medvedev over economic policy. He later served as an advisor to Medvedev's successor, Vladimir Putin.

In March 2018, Kudrin was appointed the head of the Center for Strategic Research, a think tank affiliated with the Russian government.

Kudrin is married and has two children.

FIFA Football 2005, also known as FIFA Soccer 2005, FIFA 2005 or simply FIFA 05, is a football video game released in 2004. It was developed by EA Canada and published by Electronic Arts. It was released for the PlayStation, PlayStation 2, Microsoft Windows, Xbox, PlayStation Portable, GameCube, mobile phone, Gizmondo and N-Gage.

The tagline for the game was "Create. Compete. Conquer.", referencing the Create-a-Club mode, where players could create their own team.

FIFA Football 2005 is the twelfth game in the FIFA series, and was released in 2004. The game features the return of create-a-club mode, as well as an improved career mode. The game also features the first ever online multiplayer on the PlayStation 2 and Xbox versions.

Deglaciation is the geological process that results in the loss of glacial ice and global warming. This process can occur on a variety of time scales: from millennia to decades.

Over the past two centuries, the world's average temperature has increased by about 0.7 °C (1.3 °F). This warming trend is largely due to emissions of greenhouse gases from human activities, such as burning fossil fuels and clearing forests.

As the Earth's climate warms, glaciers and ice sheets around the world are melting. This melting ice releases water into the oceans, which causes sea level to rise. Deglaciation also affects the Earth's climate in other ways.

For example, as glaciers melt, they expose bare rock that absorbs heat from the sun. This dark rock then warms the air above it, which can cause more melting. Additionally, melting glaciers can release dust and other particles into the atmosphere, which can affect the Earth's climate in a number of ways.

The effects of deglaciation are already being felt around the world and are expected to increase in the future. The loss of glaciers will cause sea level to rise, which will affect coastal communities and habitats. Additionally, the loss of glaciers will affect the global water cycle and impact the availability of fresh water.

Luis Carlos Montalván (born October 14, 1971) is a disabled United States Army veteran who served in the Iraq War. He was born in Bogotá, Colombia, and moved to the United States at the age of four. He was a lieutenant-colonel in the Army when he was medically retired in 2007. He is the author of the New York Times bestselling book Until Tuesday: A Wounded Warrior and the Golden Retriever Who Saved Him.

Montalván served in the Army for 17 years. He was deployed to Iraq twice, in 2003 and 2005. He was wounded in combat in Baghdad in 2006, and was medically retired from the Army in 2007.

After his retirement, Montalván became an advocate for disabled veterans. He wrote a column for The New York Times, called "Wounded Warrior", about his experiences as a disabled veteran. He also wrote a memoir, Until Tuesday: A Wounded Warrior and the Golden Retriever Who Saved Him, about his experiences in combat and his life after the war. The book was a New York Times bestseller.

In 2012, Montalván founded a non-profit organization called Amervets, which provides support to disabled veterans.

Montalván died by suicide on November 5, 2013.

Meru North District is a district in the former Eastern Province of Kenya. Its headquarters is Meru town. The district has a population of 578,331 (1999 census) and an area of 2, Catchment area which also includes Maua and Meru town.

The district is traversed by the A2 road (Kenya) and by the Nairobi-Meru-Maua branch of the Uganda Railway.

The district has a temperate climate. The soil is of good quality and is suitable for cash crops such as coffee, tea and pyrethrum. There are also forests, which are inner catchment areas for the rivers in the district.

The district has five divisions: Bokela, Igembe, Maua, Meru and Tigania. Each division is subdivided into locations and each location into sub-locations.

Meru North District was one of the eight districts of the former Meru County. It was created in 1966 when Meru County was split into two, Meru South and Meru North. In 1974, the district was renamed Igembe District. In 1978, it was renamed Meru District. In 1994, the district was divided into three: Meru Central, Meru North and Meru South. In 2010, Meru North District was merged with Maua and Meru town to form Meru County.

Allen Francis Doyle is a fictional character on the ABC television series Angel, portrayed by Glenn Quinn. Doyle is a half-demon, half-human who can see into the future and often has prophetic visions. He is also able to sense the presence of demons and, to a lesser extent, other supernatural beings. Doyle is a relatively minor character in the series, appearing in only fourteen episodes.

Doyle is first introduced in the episode "City Of...", in which he saves the day by warning Angel (David Boreanaz) and his vampire ally, Darla (Julie Benz), of an impending attack by a group of demons. Doyle's visions often take the form of quick flashes or snapshots, which he likens to "sudden detours" in his mind. These visions began plaguing him in his teens, and he has since learned to live with them.

In "Lonely Hearts", Doyle has a vision of a woman being murdered, and helps the police to track down the killer. He also meets Cordelia Chase (Charisma Carpenter), a former bunny-suit-wearing student and aspiring actress, whom he immediately takes a liking to. When Cordelia is attacked by the same killer, Doyle rushes to save her and is mortally wounded in the process. As he dies, he transfers his visions to Cordelia, who subsequently starts having her own prophetic visions.

Doyle makes a brief appearance in the episode "And The Beast", in which he helps Angel to defeat a powerful demon. He also appears in a vision in the episode "I've Got You Under My Skin", in which he advises Angel to trust his friends.

Doyle's final appearance is in the episode "A Hole In The World", in which he is seen in a vision alongside Cordelia, warning Angel of the coming of the Senior Partners. Shortly afterwards, Cordelia dies and Doyle's vision is revealed to have been a premonition of her death.

"Napping Princess" is a 2017 Japanese animated fantasy adventure film directed by Kenji Kamiyama. The film was produced by Signal.MD, a subsidiary of IG Port, and distributed by Warner Bros. Pictures Japan. The film was released in Japan on March 18, 2017, and later in the United States on September 8, 2017. 

The film is also known as "Ancien and the Magic Tablet" in some regions. The story is set in the near future and revolves around a high school girl named Kokone Morikawa, who dreams of a fantastical world known as Heartland, where she is a princess named Ancien with magical powers. The narrative alternates between the real world and Heartland, blurring the lines between dream and reality.

The film's unique blend of science fiction and fantasy elements, along with its exploration of themes such as dreams, family, and the impact of technology, has been praised by critics. The animation style, which combines traditional hand-drawn animation with CGI, has also been lauded for its detail and creativity.

The film features the voices of Mitsuki Takahata as Kokone Morikawa and Ancien, Shinnosuke Mitsushima as Morio, Arata Furuta as Isshin Shijima, and Tomoya Maeno as Kijita. The film's music was composed by Yoko Shimomura, known for her work on the "Kingdom Hearts" video game series.

"Napping Princess" was nominated for the Japan Academy Prize for Animation of the Year and was also selected to be screened in the Directors' Fortnight section at the 2017 Cannes Film Festival. Despite its critical success, the film was a modest box office success, grossing over $3.4 million worldwide.

The film's title, "Napping Princess", refers to the dual life of the protagonist, Kokone, who is a regular high school girl in the real world but becomes a powerful princess in her dream world. The film explores the concept of dreams as a form of escapism and a source of power, with Kokone using her dreams to solve problems in her real life.

"Napping Princess" is a testament to the power of imagination and the limitless possibilities of animation. It is a film that appeals to both children and adults, with its engaging story, beautiful animation, and thought-provoking themes.

Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that studies the evolutionary processes that produced the diversity of life on Earth. These processes include natural selection, common descent, and speciation. The discipline emerged through what Julian Huxley called the modern synthesis of understanding from several previously distinct fields of biological research, including genetics, ecology, systematics, and paleontology.

At the most basic level, evolutionary biology is concerned with changes in populations, species, or groups of species. It seeks to understand the origins and development of life, from single-celled organisms to complex multicellular organisms, including humans. The study of evolutionary biology involves the examination of both living species and fossils, as well as genetic data.

The central concept of evolutionary biology is the theory of evolution, first formulated by Charles Darwin in the mid-19th century. This theory posits that all species of organisms arise and develop through the natural selection of small, inherited variations that increase the individual's ability to compete, survive, and reproduce. This process, known as natural selection, leads to the adaptation of species to their environment and the development of new species.

Another key concept in evolutionary biology is the idea of common descent, which suggests that all life shares a common ancestor. This is supported by evidence from a wide range of scientific fields, including paleontology, comparative anatomy, and molecular biology. The concept of common descent helps to explain why organisms can be classified into a hierarchical "tree of life," from the broadest taxonomic groups (domains) to the narrowest (species).

Evolutionary biology also studies the process of speciation, or the formation of new and distinct species in the course of evolution. This can occur through various mechanisms, such as geographic isolation, genetic drift, and sexual selection. Understanding speciation is crucial for explaining the immense biodiversity found on Earth.

In recent years, evolutionary biology has been enriched by the integration of molecular biology, which has provided detailed information about the genetic basis of evolution. This has led to the development of the field of molecular evolution, which studies the processes and outcomes of evolution at the molecular level.

Evolutionary biology has wide-ranging practical applications. For example, it informs the development of new drugs and medical treatments, aids in the conservation of endangered species, and helps to predict and manage the spread of infectious diseases. It also provides a unifying framework for understanding the natural world and our place in it.

In conclusion, evolutionary biology is a dynamic and continually evolving field that seeks to explain the complexity and diversity of life on Earth. It is

Scottish Forestry is the governmental organisation responsible for the promotion, regulation, and development of forests, woodlands, and sustainable forestry in Scotland. The organisation was officially established on 1 April 2019 after the dissolution of Forestry Commission Scotland and took over as the Scottish government agency responsible for forestry. 

==History==

In the past, forest and woodland management in Scotland was under the control of the Forestry Commission, which was established in 1919 to expand Britain's forests and woodlands after World War I. In 2019, a UK-wide review of the Forestry Commission's structure led to reforms, resulting in the establishment of two new Scottish forestry agencies, Scottish Forestry and Forestry and Land Scotland. Scottish Forestry was given responsibility for policy, support, and regulation, whilst Forestry and Land Scotland is tasked with managing the National Forest Estate.

==Role and Responsibility==

Scottish Forestry is accountable to the Scottish Parliament and is responsible for implementing forestry legislation, policy, and regulations. The organisation provides grants and licenses to support sustainable forest and woodland management. It also sets standards for forest and woodland management in Scotland and ensures that these standards are met through monitoring and enforcement.

Scottish Forestry promotes the benefits of forests and woodlands for the economy, the environment, and society. This includes promoting the use of wood as a sustainable material and energy source, and encouraging use and enjoyment of forests and woodlands for health, wellbeing, and leisure. 

==Structure and Organisation==

Scottish Forestry is headed by a Chief Forester, who reports to the Scottish Government's Rural Economy and Tourism Secretary. The organisation is divided into several regional conservancies, each headed by a Conservator. The Conservators are responsible for grating felling permissions, raising tree health alerts, and ensuring that forestry standards are maintained on both public and private woodland across Scotland.

==Challenges and Achievements==

Climate change presents a pressing challenge for Scottish Forestry. Responding to this, the organisation plays a key role in implementing the Scottish Government's strategy for increasing tree planting to absorb carbon dioxide and mitigate climate change. Additionally, it works to protect Scotland's forests and woodlands from pests and diseases, and to maintain and enhance biodiversity. 

In recognition of its efforts, Scottish Forestry won the Queen's Award for Enterprise: Sustainable Development in 2020. This prestigious award is given for outstanding achievement in sustainable development.

Terri Sewell (born January 1, 1965) is an American attorney and politician who has been serving as the U.S. Representative for Alabama's 7th congressional district since 2011. A member of the Democratic Party, she is the state's first Black woman elected to Congress.

Sewell was born and raised in Selma, Alabama. After receiving a Bachelor's degree in International Politics from Princeton University in 1986, she went on to attend Oxford University as a British Marshall Scholar, earning a Masters in Politics with an emphasis in Economics. She later received her Juris Doctor from Harvard Law School in 1992. After graduation, she practiced law at Davis, Polk & Wardwell in New York City. Over her career, she has gained extensive experience in securities law and public finance.

Sewell entered politics in 2010 when she ran for Alabama's 7th congressional district seat. She won with over 72% of the votes. Since her election, she has been re-elected five times, serving as a leading voice for Alabama on various key issues including economic development, education, and healthcare.

In Congress, Sewell is known for her pragmatic approach and commitment to finding bipartisan solutions. She served on the House Permanent Select Committee on Intelligence and was Vice Chair of the House Ways and Means Committee. She played an instrumental role as a member of the House Women’s Caucus and the Congressional Black Caucus, advocating for the rights and welfare of women and African Americans.

Her legislative achievements span various areas with a particular focus on social justice, economic development, healthcare, and education. Some of her prominent legislative accomplishments include the "Restore the Voting Rights Act" and the "Workforce Innovation and Opportunity Act".

Throughout her political career, Sewell has advocated for job creation, quality education, affordable healthcare, and the protection of voting rights. Her work in Congress is also notable for highlighting the history and the advancement of civil rights in Alabama and across the United States. 

Sewell's political influence extends beyond Alabama as she frequently discusses national topics and issues. She is also recognized for her commitment to leadership development, actively mentoring interns and young staff members.

Sewell's dedication to public service and her active role in politics are contemporary examples of the legacy of civil rights activism in Alabama. Her practical approach to politics and her extensive work in advancing the economic and social welfare of her constituents have further solidified her status as a crucial figure in Alabama politics. Herbert Henry Lehman (March 28, 1878 – December 5, 1963) was an American investment banker and politician. A member of the Democratic Party, he served as the 45th Governor of New York from 1933 to 1942, and then as United States Senator from New York between 1949 and 1957. He was also the director of the United States Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations and the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration from 1942 to 1946.

==Early Life and Education==

Lehman was born in New York City, the son of Babetta (née Newgass) and Mayer Lehman, one of the three brothers who founded the Lehman Brothers investment bank. He attended The Sachs School, which later became the Sachs Collegiate Institute. After graduating, he attended Williams College. Upon graduating from Williams, Lehman entered the family business in 1899.

==Political Career==

Lehman entered politics in 1928 when he was elected Lieutenant Governor of New York. He served two terms before being elected Governor in 1932. As Governor, Lehman implemented a series of social programs modeled after those of the federal New Deal. He was re-elected three times, serving until 1942.

During World War II, Lehman served as director of the United States Office of Foreign Relief and Rehabilitation Operations and the United Nations Relief and Rehabilitation Administration. In these roles, he oversaw the distribution of food and other aid to countries devastated by the war.

In 1949, Lehman was elected to the United States Senate from New York. He served two terms, focusing on issues of civil rights, labor, and international relations. He was a strong supporter of the United Nations and advocated for increased aid to developing countries.

==Later Life and Legacy==

Lehman retired from the Senate in 1957. He remained active in politics and public service, serving as a delegate to the United Nations and working on behalf of various charitable organizations. He died in 1963.

Lehman's legacy is remembered through the Herbert H. Lehman College of the City University of New York, the Herbert H. Lehman Center for American History at Columbia University, and the Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx, all named in his honor. His papers are held by the Lehman Special Correspondence Files at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Presidential Library and Museum.

Selam Woldemariam is a renowned Ethiopian musician, specializing in the genre of Ethio-Jazz, and is notably recognized for his proficiency as a guitarist. A celebrated figure in the Ethiopian music industry, Selam has contributed greatly to the growth and development of music in Ethiopia.

Early Life

Selam Woldemariam was born and raised in Addis Ababa, the capital city of Ethiopia. From a young age, he showed a keen interest in music and began learning to play the guitar at a tender age. His passion for music and natural talent soon led him to pursue a career as a professional musician.

Career

Selam embarked on his music career in earnest during the early 1980s. Given his exceptional skill as a guitarist, he quickly gained a reputation in the Ethiopian music industry. By the mid-1980s, he had joined one of the leading bands in Ethiopia where he honed his skills and began to develop his unique style.

Over the decades, Selam Woldemariam has become a master of Ethio-Jazz, a genre that fuses traditional Ethiopian music with jazz, and more recent musically stylistic influences. His innovative approach to this genre has led to new ways of understanding and appreciating Ethiopian music, both nationally and internationally.

In addition to performances and recordings, Selam has also dedicated himself to mentoring upcoming musicians. His commitment to developing the next generation of musicians has been a critical component of his impact on the Ethiopian music scene.

Selam's work as a musician has earned him numerous accolades. His guitar virtuosity, innovative musical arrangements, and dedication to the promotion of Ethiopian music globally have placed him among the pioneers and champions of Ethio-jazz.

Legacy

Selam Woldemariam's commitment to the promotion and advancement of Ethiopian music has made a tremendous impact on the musical identity of the country. His contributions to Ethio-Jazz have not only reinvigorated interest in the genre but have also introduced a new generation of music enthusiasts to Ethiopian culture and heritage. He is regarded as a trailblazer, with his music continuing to inspire and influence many. 

Today, Selam's pioneering role in promoting Ethiopian music is acknowledged globally, and his influence is evident in the works of many contemporary Ethiopian musicians. His mastery of the genre and contribution to Ethiopian music have cemented his status as one of the most prominent figures in the country's musical history.

Ālī Qāpū (Persian: عالی‌ قاپو‎, ‘Ālī Qāpū) is a grand palace located in Isfahan, Iran. It is situated on the western side of the Naqsh-e Jahan Square, opposite to Sheikh Lotfollah Mosque, and had been originally designed as a vast portal. The name Ālī Qāpū, from Arabic ‘Ālī, "Imperial or Great", and Turkic Qāpū meaning "gate", was given to this place as it was right at the entrance to the Safavid palaces which stretched from the Naqsh-e Jahan Square to the Chahar Baq Boulevard. The building, another wonderful Safavid edifice, was built by decree of Shah Abbas I in the early seventeenth century.

The palace is forty-eight meters high and there are six floors, each accessible by a difficult spiral staircase. In the sixth floor, the Music Hall, deep circular niches are found in the walls, having not only aesthetic value, but also acoustic. The building is rich in naturalistic wall paintings by Reza Abbasi, the court painter of Shah Abbas I, and his pupils. There are floral, animal, and bird motifs.

The highly ornamented doors and windows of the palace have almost all been pillaged at times of social anarchy. Only one window on the third floor has escaped the ravages of time. Ālī Qāpū was repaired and restored substantially during the reign of Shah Sultan Hussein, the last Safavid ruler, but fell into a dreadful state of dilapidation again during the short reign of invading Afghans. Under the Qajar Nasir al-Din shah's reign (1848–96), the Safavid cornices and floral tiles above the portal were replaced by tiles bearing inscriptions.

Ālī Qāpū is rich in naturalistic wall paintings. The paintings on the walls and ceilings of the palace are the work of Reza Abbasi. The subjects of the paintings are mostly flowers and animals, including horses, birds and wild animals. The Iranian crown jewels are said to have been kept at Ālī Qāpū in the past.

The palace is an important historical site, and is listed with UNESCO as a part of the larger historic complex of Naqsh-e Jahan Square, which is a World Heritage Site. Today, the Ālī Qā

Alfred Coppel (November 9, 1921 – May 1, 2004) was an American author who wrote numerous science fiction, fantasy, and mystery novels, as well as short stories. He was best known for his novel "The Burning Mountain," a hypothetical chronicle of the atomic bombing of Japan.

Born in Oakland, California, Coppel served as a fighter pilot in the United States Army Air Forces during World War II. After the war, he attended the University of California, Berkeley, where he studied English and History. He began his writing career in the late 1940s, initially focusing on pulp science fiction stories. His early works were published under the pseudonym Robert Cham Gilman.

Coppel's writing style was characterized by its fast pace, intricate plots, and attention to technical detail. His works often explored themes of war, technology, and the human condition. Despite his prolific output in the science fiction genre, Coppel also achieved considerable success with his mystery and thriller novels. His novel "Thirty-Four East," a geopolitical thriller about the Middle East, was particularly well-received.

In the 1980s, Coppel shifted his focus to writing alternate history novels. His most famous work from this period, "The Burning Mountain," presents an alternate timeline in which the atomic bomb was not ready in time to be used in World War II. The novel was praised for its meticulous research and compelling narrative.

Coppel continued to write and publish novels up until his death in 2004. His final novel, "Red Horse," was a thriller set in the aftermath of the Soviet Union's collapse. Throughout his career, Coppel's works were translated into multiple languages and sold millions of copies worldwide.

Coppel's contributions to the science fiction genre have been recognized by several awards, including the Nebula Award for Best Novel. His works have also been included in numerous anthologies and have been studied in academic settings for their exploration of themes such as war, technology, and alternate history.

Alfred Coppel passed away on May 1, 2004, leaving behind a rich legacy of literature that continues to be enjoyed by readers around the world. His works remain a testament to his skill as a storyteller and his ability to weave complex narratives that captivate and engage readers.

Brian Topp (born 1960) is a Canadian political strategist, union leader, and writer. He is best known for his work with the New Democratic Party (NDP) and his role as the president of the ACTRA Toronto, a union representing over 15,000 professional performers working in English-language recorded media.

== Early Life and Education ==

Topp was born in Longueuil, Quebec, Canada. He attended McGill University, where he earned a Bachelor of Arts degree in Political Science and History. 

== Political Career ==

Topp began his political career as a volunteer for the NDP in the 1980s. He quickly rose through the ranks, serving as the party's deputy chief of staff under Saskatchewan Premier Roy Romanow and later as the national campaign director for the federal NDP. 

In 2011, Topp ran for the leadership of the NDP following the death of Jack Layton. Despite being endorsed by several high-profile party members, he finished second to Thomas Mulcair. 

Topp has also been involved in provincial politics. He served as the chief of staff to Alberta Premier Rachel Notley from 2015 to 2016. 

== Union Leadership ==

In addition to his political work, Topp has been a prominent figure in the Canadian labor movement. He served as the executive director and chief negotiator for ACTRA Toronto, where he was instrumental in negotiating collective agreements for performers. 

== Writing Career ==

Topp is also an accomplished writer. He has written several books on Canadian politics, including "How We Almost Gave the Tories the Boot: The Inside Story Behind the Coalition" and "The New Democrats, 1961-1986: The Politics of Change." He is a regular contributor to The Globe and Mail and has written for several other major Canadian publications.

== Personal Life ==

Topp is married and has two children. He is fluent in both English and French.

== Legacy and Impact ==

Topp's contributions to Canadian politics and the labor movement have been significant. His strategic acumen and commitment to social justice have helped shape the NDP and have had a lasting impact on Canadian labor laws. His writings have also provided valuable insights into the inner workings of Canadian politics.

Darrick E. Antell, M.D., F.A.C.S., is a renowned American plastic surgeon based in New York City. He is best known for his work in aesthetic plastic surgery, particularly facelifts, eyelid surgery, and rhinoplasty. Antell's research on identical twins and the aging process has been widely recognized and has significantly contributed to the field of plastic surgery.

== Early Life and Education ==

Antell was born and raised in the United States. He completed his undergraduate studies at Hobart College in Geneva, New York, before earning his medical degree from the University of Toledo College of Medicine. He then completed his general surgery residency at Stanford University and his plastic surgery residency at the New York Hospital/Cornell Medical Center.

== Career ==

Antell opened his private practice in New York City, where he has been serving patients for over 30 years. He is affiliated with multiple hospitals in the area, including Lenox Hill Hospital and Manhattan Eye, Ear, and Throat Hospital. 

In addition to his clinical practice, Antell has conducted extensive research in the field of plastic surgery. His most notable work is his study on identical twins and the aging process, which has been featured on numerous media outlets, including ABC's 20/20, CNN, and the Discovery Channel. This research has provided valuable insights into the effects of environmental factors versus genetics on aging.

Antell is also known for his work with high-profile clients, including celebrities and public figures. His discretion and expertise have made him a sought-after surgeon in the entertainment industry.

== Recognition ==

Heidi Schwegler is an internationally recognized American artist known for her profound work in wide-ranging media including sculpture, photography, video, installation and recently, jewelry. Born in 1967 in San Antonio, Texas, Schwegler has garnered acclaim for her innovative approach and profound ideas that often explore themes of decay, failure, and the generally unseen or overlooked aspects of daily life. Her particular blend of traditional craft techniques and thought-provoking conceptuality has made significant contributions to the contemporary art discourse.

Schwegler earned her Bachelor of Fine Arts in Painting from the University of Kansas in 1990 and then proceeded to the University of Oregon for a Master of Fine Arts in Metalsmithing, where she graduated with honors in 1996. 

Her notable works include "I borrowed optimism from the past" (2019), a series of enlarged and meticulously rendered used drinking straws, and “Empty Promise” (2013), a 7-foot-tall cast aluminum sculpture of a deteriorating garden gnome. Both pieces explore Schwegler’s fascination with the aftermath of the discarded and how it represents societal values and obsessions. 

Schwegler’s work has been exhibited extensively in the United States and abroad. She has had solo shows at venues such as the Portland Art Museum, the Sculpture Center in Cleveland, and the Blue Star Contemporary Art Museum in San Antonio. Internationally, her work has been displayed in countries including Mexico, Germany, and China. 

In 2008 Schwegler was named an Emerging Voice by the American Craft Council, and in 2010 she received a 2-year fellowship from the Oregon Arts Commission. She has also been awarded artist residencies at places like the MacDowell Colony and the Bemis Center for Contemporary Art.

In addition to her established studio practice, Schwegler is a dedicated educator. She taught at the Oregon College of Art and Craft for over two decades, serving as Chair of the MFA in Applied Craft and Design – a program offered jointly by Oregon College of Art and Craft and the Pacific Northwest College of Art - from 2010 to 2018. 

Schwegler’s critical approach and her continuous exploration of the frailties of the human condition through her art prompt viewers to reconsider the ordinary, offering a new perspective on the everyday ephemera that is often forgotten or discarded. As one of the most thought-provoking artists of her generation, Heidi Schwegler continues to push the boundaries of the contemporary art world.

Albrecht Dürer (21 May 1471 – 6 April 1528) was a German painter, printmaker, and theorist from Nuremberg. His body of work includes altarpieces, religious works, numerous portraits and self-portraits, as well as copper engravings. His woodcuts, such as the Apocalypse series (1498), retain a more Gothic flavor than the rest of his work. His well-known engravings include the Knight, Death, and the Devil (1513), Saint Jerome in his Study (1514) and Melencolia I (1514), which has been the subject of extensive analysis and interpretation. His watercolours mark him as one of the first European landscape artists, while his ambitious woodcuts revolutionized the potential of that medium.

Dürer's introduction of classical motifs into Northern art, through his knowledge of Italian artists and German humanists, has secured his reputation as one of the most important figures of the Northern Renaissance. This is reinforced by his theoretical treatises, which involve principles of mathematics, perspective, and ideal proportions.

Dürer was born on 21 May 1471, third child and second son of his parents, who had between fourteen and eighteen children. His father was a successful goldsmith, originally Ajtós, near Gyula in Hungary. He moved to Nuremberg in 1455 where he married Barbara Holper, daughter of his master.

In 1486, Dürer was apprenticed to the Nuremberg painter and printmaker Michael Wolgemut, where he would remain for about four years. He soon traveled to Italy, where he would learn much about the Renaissance developments. He returned to Nuremberg in 1495, opened a workshop and began to produce woodcut prints.

One of Dürer's most significant contributions to the art world was his works on the laws of proportion, "The Four Books on Measurement" and "Four Books on Human Proportion". Dürer’s exploration of human proportions laid down the groundwork for future artists and set a precedent for analyzing human anatomy.

There are few definitive records of Dürer's thoughts on contemporary events. His writings are predominantly observations on art, particularly measurements and proportions for artists, as well as reflections on his own artworks.
