Rodney Stuart Young (1907–1974) was a prominent American archaeologist known for his significant contributions to the field of classical archaeology. He is best remembered for his excavations at the ancient city of Gordion in central Turkey, where he unearthed the tomb of King Midas, a Phrygian ruler from the 8th century BC.

Born on August 1, 1907, in Bernardsville, New Jersey, Young graduated from Princeton University in 1929 with a degree in Classics. He later pursued his Ph.D. in Classical Archaeology at the University of Pennsylvania, where he would later serve as a professor and the curator of the Mediterranean section of the University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology.

Young's early archaeological work included participation in the excavations at Olynthus in Greece under David M. Robinson. However, his most significant work began in 1950 when he took over the excavations at Gordion, the ancient capital of Phrygia. His work at Gordion lasted for nearly 25 years, during which he made several significant discoveries, including the tomb of King Midas, which contained a wealth of artifacts that provided valuable insights into Phrygian culture and history.

Young's approach to archaeology was meticulous and innovative. He was one of the first archaeologists to use stratigraphy, a method that involves analyzing the layers of an archaeological site to understand its chronological sequence. This approach allowed him to reconstruct the history of Gordion and its people in remarkable detail.

In addition to his fieldwork, Young was a prolific writer. He published numerous articles and books on his findings at Gordion and other archaeological sites. His publications are still widely regarded as essential resources in the field of classical archaeology.

Young's contributions to archaeology were recognized with several awards and honors. He was a member of the American Philosophical Society and a fellow of the Society of Antiquaries of London. In 1973, he was awarded the Gold Medal for Distinguished Archaeological Achievement by the Archaeological Institute of America.

Rodney Young passed away on March 29, 1974. His legacy continues to influence the field of archaeology, particularly in the study of the ancient Near East. His meticulous approach to excavation and his commitment to understanding the cultural context of archaeological finds have set a standard for archaeological practice that continues to be followed today.

Daniel Joseph Schafer is a renowned American historian, author, and professor emeritus at the University of North Florida. He is best known for his extensive research and publications on African American history and the history of Florida.

== Early Life and Education ==

Daniel Joseph Schafer was born in the United States. He pursued his passion for history by obtaining a Bachelor's degree in History. He furthered his studies by earning a Master's degree and a Ph.D. in History. His doctoral dissertation focused on the history of African Americans in Florida, which later became the foundation of his career.

== Career ==

Schafer started his career as a professor at the University of North Florida, where he taught various courses in American history, African American history, and Florida history. He was known for his engaging teaching style and his ability to bring historical events to life for his students.

In addition to his teaching career, Schafer has made significant contributions to historical research. He has written numerous articles and books on African American history and Florida history. His work has been recognized for its depth and accuracy, and it has been used as a resource by other historians and researchers.

Some of his notable publications include "Anna Madgigine Jai Kingsley: African Princess, Florida Slave, Plantation Slaveowner," and "Zephaniah Kingsley Jr. and the Atlantic World: Slave Trader, Plantation Owner, Emancipator." These works provide a detailed account of the lives of African Americans in Florida during the 19th century.

== Awards and Recognition ==

Throughout his career, Schafer has received numerous awards and recognition for his contributions to the field of history. He was awarded the Arthur W. Thompson Award by the Florida Historical Society for his article on Zephaniah Kingsley. In 2003, he was named a Distinguished Professor at the University of North Florida.

== Personal Life ==

Schafer is married and has two children. He is known for his love of history and his dedication to research. Even in retirement, he continues to write and contribute to the field of history.

== Legacy ==

Daniel Joseph Schafer's work has had a significant impact on the understanding of African American history and the history of Florida. His research has shed light on the lives of African Americans during the 19th century, and his publications have become essential resources for historians and researchers. His dedication to teaching and research has inspired many of his students to pursue careers in history.

Filipino Italians are individuals who are of both Filipino and Italian ancestry. This group also includes Italian-born individuals who have parents of Filipino heritage. The Filipino Italian community is a significant part of the multicultural fabric of Italy, contributing to the country's social, economic, and cultural life.

== History ==

The history of Filipino Italians can be traced back to the late 20th century when a wave of Filipino immigrants moved to Italy in search of better economic opportunities. Over the years, these immigrants have integrated into Italian society, with many marrying Italians and starting families, thus giving rise to the Filipino Italian community.

== Demographics ==

As of 2020, there are approximately 170,000 Filipinos in Italy, making them one of the largest Asian communities in the country. The majority of Filipino Italians reside in Rome, Milan, and other major cities. They are well-represented in various sectors, including healthcare, domestic work, and the service industry.

== Culture ==

Filipino Italians are known for their vibrant culture, which is a blend of Filipino and Italian traditions. They celebrate Filipino festivals such as the 'Barrio Fiesta' and 'Santacruzan', alongside Italian holidays like 'Festa della Repubblica'. Filipino cuisine is also popular among this community, with adobo, sinigang, and lechon often served alongside Italian dishes like pasta and pizza.

== Contributions ==

Filipino Italians have made significant contributions to Italian society. They have excelled in various fields, including arts, sports, business, and politics. Notable Filipino Italians include fashion designer Ruben Panis and footballer Stephan Schröck. The community is also known for its contribution to the healthcare sector, with many Filipino Italians working as nurses and caregivers.

== Challenges ==

Despite their contributions, Filipino Italians face several challenges. These include language barriers, discrimination, and difficulties in accessing social services. However, various organizations, such as the Filipino Women's Council and the Filipino Community in Italy, are working to address these issues and promote the rights and welfare of Filipino Italians.

== Conclusion ==

Filipino Italians are a testament to the multicultural nature of Italy. They embody a unique blend of Filipino resilience and Italian passion, contributing to the diversity and richness of Italian society. Despite the challenges they face, Filipino Italians continue to thrive and make significant contributions to their adopted homeland.

Coptic Cairo is a part of the Egyptian capital that is known for being the heart of the country's Christian community. The area spans from the northern part of Old Cairo to southern parts of the new province. This region's substantial historical significance has dutifully earned it a spot as one of Cairo's must-see tourist destinations. 

Coptic Cairo is often referred to as 'Old Cairo' because it hosts some of the oldest Christian churches in Egypt, many ancient mosques, and Jewish synagogues dating back to the time when the city served as the capital of Egypt. This intermingling of religious spaces showcases the area's rich history of diverse cultural and religious interactions. 

The area is densely packed with significant historic edifices, including the Hanging Church (Saint Virgin Mary's Coptic Orthodox Church), which was built in the 7th century over a gatehouse of Babylon Fortress, standing as one of the oldest surviving Christian churches in Egypt. The Coptic Museum, situated within the grounds of the Coptic Orthodox Church, houses the world's most extensive collection of Coptic Christian artwork and artifacts. The Ben Ezra Synagogue, thought to be built in the 9th century, is a fascinating place of Jewish worship with a rich historical narrative surrounding it. 

At the heart of Coptic Cairo is the fortress of Babylon, around which the Roman Emperor Trajan built the city of Cairo in AD 116. The juxtaposition of Roman, early-Christian, and Islamic architecture all within such a compact area helps to tell Cairo's diverse and fascinating history. 

Beyond the religious and historical sites, Coptic Cairo has a distinctive charm of its own. The narrow alleyways and passages meander through centuries-old structures, offering a glimpse into an era bygone. Visitors can explore traditional craft shops and spice markets, sip a traditional Egyptian tea at one of the many cafes, or simply imbibe in the labyrinthine beauty of the historic district. 

Coptic Cairo represents more than just a religious or historical significance. It embodies a sense of unity that bridges today's different Coptic and Muslim communities. One cannot truly understand the remarkable city of Cairo without exploring the richness and depth that Coptic Cairo has to offer. 

The maintenance, preservation, and ongoing archaeological recovery efforts in the area reflect the Egyptian government's commitment to preserving and showcasing the rich cultural heritage of Coptic Cairo. This makes the district not only a hub for religious activity but also an essential center of historical, archaeological, and tourist interest.

Leonti Mroveli (Georgian: ლეონტი მროველი), which translates to "Leon the Traveller", was a Georgian chronicler and author of the 11th century. He is frequently referenced in analysis of Georgian historical literature, known primarily for his significant input in the medieval "Georgian Chronicles". His work forms the earliest comprehensive history of Georgia and the Caucasians.

Leonti Mroveli's exact birth date remains unknown, but historical examination points to him being active during the reign of King Bagrat IV of Georgia, suggesting that he lived around the turn of the 11th century. His name, Mroveli, which means "the traveller" in Georgian, denotes an individual who travels from place to place, typically a cleric or a trader, which may indicate his social status or occupation.

Leonti Mroveli's main work is "Georgian Chronicles", also known as "The Life of Kartli". The chronicle presents a blend of mythological narrative and historical events, taking readers back to the era of the biblical descendants of Noah and then tracing the lineage of the Georgians, or 'Kartvelians', from Noah’s son Japheth and grandson Togarmah. Despite the heavy leanings on biblical mythology and royal genealogy, the chronicles also provide invaluable information about the socio-political landscape of the Caucasus region from the 4th to the 11th centuries.

Contributions from Leonti Mroveli form the first part of the Georgian Chronicles, which is often referred to as "The Chronicle of Leonti Mroveli". His writings include the history of the conversion of Georgia to Christianity, the reign of Mirian III, the wars with Iran in the 5th century, and the life of King Vakhtang Gorgasali. His accounts are considered somewhat reliable by historians, although they are occasionally marked by errors and anachronisms, primarily due to the oral transmission of these tales before they were written down.

Later in his life, Leonti Mroveli became the Bishop of Ruisi, one of the oldest episcopal sees in Georgia. He remained in this position until his death.

Edwin "Eddie" Prévost (born 22 June 1942) is an innovative and influential English drummer, percussionist, and musician renowned for the ingenuity he brings to the sphere of free improvisation and experimental music. Known predominantly for his association with improvisational music ensemble 'AMM', Prévost's career spans over five decades, demonstrating a deep commitment to and an onward journey in experimenting with sounds, textures, and tonalities in innovative ways.

Eddie Prévost was born in Hitchin, Hertfordshire, England. He joined the electronic/modern jazz ensemble 'AMM' in 1965, along with guitarist Keith Rowe and keyboardist Cornelius Cardew. Ever since, he has been an integral part as well as the consistent member of the ensemble, contributing extensively to its evolving soundscape.

Prévost's style employs rolling, roiling, and rumbling traditional 'rock' drum techniques, simultaneously utilising assorted metals and gongs, along with other found percussive objects. His distinct style and innovative improvisations have widely influenced his contemporaries and young musicians in the sphere of free improvisation.

Prévost has released numerous discographies as a solo artist and in collaboration with other musicians. His work within AMM, along with his solo and collaborative discographies, reflect his inventiveness and his dedication to the initiative of seeking 'free' music beyond the conventional boundaries.

Beyond his musical achievements, Prévost is also a prolific writer on improvisation. His first book, "No Sound is Innocent", was published in 1995. Later in 2004, he published "Minute Particulars: Meanings in Music-making in the Wake of Hierarchical Realignments and Other Essays". His writings fundamentally discuss the practice of improvisation outside the conventional musical structures and his insights are deeply revered in the related circles.

He established Matchless Recordings and Publishing in 1979, which became a platform for promoting and distributing his own work as well as those of many like-minded artists. Additionally, he has been curating a weekly workshop in London focused on experimental music since 1999, keeping the spirit and practice of free improvisation very much alive.

Prévost is known for his collaborative performances with saxophonists Evan Parker and John Butcher, pianists John Tilbury and Marilyn Crispell, bassist Barry Guy, and electronic musician Keith Rowe, among other artists.

Yu Lihua (1929 – 2020) was a renowned Chinese-American author, best known for her works that depicted the lives of Chinese intellectuals and students living abroad. Born in Shanghai, China, she moved to the United States in 1947 to pursue her studies. She wrote more than 30 novels and short story collections, many of which were published in Taiwan and Hong Kong.

== Early Life and Education ==

Yu Lihua was born on April 1, 1929, in Shanghai, China. She was the daughter of Yu Dafu, a prominent Chinese writer and poet. She attended the prestigious McTyeire School for Girls in Shanghai. In 1947, she moved to the United States to study at the University of Missouri, where she earned a bachelor's degree in journalism. She later earned a master's degree in literature from St. John's University in New York.

== Career ==

Yu Lihua began her writing career in the 1950s. Her early works were primarily short stories and essays, which were published in various Chinese literary magazines. Her first novel, "Echo," was published in 1960. The novel, which depicted the lives of Chinese students studying in the United States, was well-received and established her reputation as a significant voice in Chinese literature.

Throughout her career, Yu Lihua wrote more than 30 novels and short story collections. Her works often explored themes of cultural identity, displacement, and the experiences of Chinese intellectuals and students living abroad. Some of her most notable works include "A Small Town Called Hibiscus," "Shanghai Flowers," and "Sorrow of the Forbidden City."

Yu Lihua's works were widely read in Taiwan and Hong Kong, and many were adapted into films and television series. Despite her popularity, her works were banned in mainland China until the 1980s due to their critical portrayal of the Chinese government.

== Later Life and Death ==

In her later years, Yu Lihua served as a visiting professor at several universities, including the University of Maryland and Georgetown University. She continued to write and publish until her death.

Yu Lihua died on April 30, 2020, in Gaithersburg, Maryland, at the age of 91. Her death was widely mourned in the Chinese literary community, and she was remembered for her significant contributions to Chinese literature.

Bobby Ray Murcer (May 20, 1946 – July 12, 2008) was an American professional baseball player and television sports announcer. He played in Major League Baseball (MLB) as an outfielder for the New York Yankees, San Francisco Giants, and Chicago Cubs between 1965 and 1983. After his retirement from professional baseball, Murcer served as a television sportscaster for the Yankees.

Murcer was born in Oklahoma City, Oklahoma, and showed a talent for baseball from a young age. He was signed by the New York Yankees in 1964 and made his major league debut the following year. He was primarily a center fielder, and was considered a potential successor to the legendary Mickey Mantle.

During his 17-year career, Murcer was named an All-Star five times and won a Gold Glove in 1972. He was traded to the San Francisco Giants in 1975, and later played for the Chicago Cubs before returning to the Yankees in 1979. He retired from professional baseball in 1983, having hit 252 home runs and driven in 1,043 runs.

After his playing career, Murcer transitioned into broadcasting. He joined the Yankees' television broadcast team in 1983 and quickly became a fan favorite for his insightful commentary and affable personality. He was awarded three Emmy Awards for live sports coverage as part of the YES Network team.

Murcer was diagnosed with brain cancer in 2006. He continued to work as a broadcaster during his treatment, and was widely praised for his courage and determination. He passed away in 2008 at the age of 62.

Murcer's legacy in baseball extends beyond his playing and broadcasting career. He was actively involved in charity work throughout his life, particularly with the Baseball Assistance Team, a non-profit organization that provides financial assistance to former baseball players in need. In 1988, he was awarded the Lou Gehrig Memorial Award, which is given annually to the MLB player who best exemplifies Gehrig's character and integrity both on and off the field.

Bobby Murcer's contributions to the sport of baseball, both on and off the field, have left a lasting impact. His playing prowess, broadcasting talent, and charitable efforts have cemented his place in baseball history.

HMS Rodney (29) was one of two Nelson-class battleships built for the Royal Navy in the mid-1920s. Named after Admiral Lord Rodney, the ship was commissioned in 1927 and served extensively during the Second World War. 

== Design and Description ==

HMS Rodney was designed in accordance with the limitations set by the Washington Naval Treaty of 1922. The treaty, which aimed to prevent a naval arms race after World War I, restricted the displacement, armament, and armour of new battleships. As a result, HMS Rodney and her sister ship, HMS Nelson, were unique in their design among British battleships.

HMS Rodney had a length of 710 feet, a beam of 106 feet, and a draught of 33 feet. She was powered by Brown-Curtis geared steam turbines, driving two propeller shafts, which developed a total of 45,000 shaft horsepower and gave a maximum speed of 23 knots. 

The ship's main armament consisted of nine 16-inch guns in three triple turrets, two forward and one aft, a configuration necessitated by the Treaty's restrictions. Her secondary armament included twelve 6-inch guns, six 4.7-inch anti-aircraft guns, and a variety of smaller calibre weapons.

== Service History ==

HMS Rodney served extensively during the Second World War. She was part of the Home Fleet and participated in several campaigns, including the Norwegian Campaign and the hunt for the German battleship Bismarck. 

In May 1941, HMS Rodney played a crucial role in the sinking of the Bismarck. Along with the battleship HMS King George V, she engaged the Bismarck in a prolonged battle, during which Rodney fired a total of 340 16-inch shells, scoring several hits and contributing significantly to the Bismarck's eventual destruction.

After the Bismarck engagement, HMS Rodney continued to serve in the Atlantic, Mediterranean, and Arctic theatres. She provided cover for several Arctic convoys, supported the Allied invasion of North Africa in 1942, and participated in the Normandy landings in 1944.

== Decommissioning and Fate ==

After the end of the Second World War, HMS Rodney was decommissioned in 1945 due to her poor condition and the Royal Navy's post-war downsizing. She was sold for scrap in 1948 and broken up at Inverkeithing.

Trabazos is a municipality located in the province of Zamora, Castile and León, Spain. According to the 2004 census (INE), the municipality has a population of 436 inhabitants. The town is situated in the region of Aliste, a historical and traditional region in the western part of the province. 

Geography

Trabazos is located in the northwest of the province of Zamora, near the border with Portugal. The municipality is part of the natural region of Aliste, characterized by its hilly landscape and the presence of the Aliste River. The town is surrounded by vast expanses of oak and chestnut forests, which contribute to the area's rich biodiversity.

History

The history of Trabazos is closely linked to the history of the province of Zamora and the region of Aliste. The area has been inhabited since ancient times, as evidenced by the numerous archaeological sites found in the vicinity. During the Middle Ages, Trabazos was part of the Kingdom of León, and later became part of the Crown of Castile.

Economy

The economy of Trabazos is primarily based on agriculture and livestock farming, with a particular emphasis on the production of beef and pork. The town is also known for its traditional crafts, especially pottery and basket weaving. In recent years, rural tourism has become an increasingly important part of the local economy.

Culture

Trabazos is known for its rich cultural heritage, which includes traditional music, dance, and cuisine. The town hosts several annual festivals and events, such as the Carnival of Trabazos, which is recognized as a Festival of Regional Tourist Interest. The local cuisine is characterized by its use of locally sourced ingredients, including beef, pork, and various types of game.

Demographics

As of 2004, Trabazos has a population of 436 inhabitants. The population has been steadily declining over the past few decades, a trend common in many rural areas of Spain. However, the town has been making efforts to attract new residents and tourists, in order to revitalize the local economy and preserve its cultural heritage.

In conclusion, Trabazos is a small but vibrant municipality in the province of Zamora, known for its rich history, traditional culture, and beautiful natural surroundings. Despite facing challenges related to depopulation and economic change, the town continues to preserve its unique identity and way of life.

L.A.P.D. (band) was an American funk metal band formed in 1989 in Bakersfield, California. The band's name is an acronym for "Love And Peace Dude", and later "Laughing As People Die". The band was a precursor to the successful nu metal band Korn, and included three of Korn's founding members: James "Munky" Shaffer, Reginald "Fieldy" Arvizu, and David Silveria.

History

L.A.P.D. was formed in 1989 by James Shaffer, Reginald Arvizu, David Silveria, and Richard Morrill. The band released a demo tape in 1989, followed by an EP titled "Love and Peace Dude" in 1990. Their self-titled debut studio album was released in 1991, which included a combination of funk, punk, and metal. The band's music was characterized by its aggressive style and socially conscious lyrics.

Despite their early promise, L.A.P.D. struggled to gain a significant following. The band's lack of commercial success, coupled with internal conflicts, led to their disbandment in 1992. However, Shaffer, Arvizu, and Silveria would go on to form the band Korn in 1993, along with Brian "Head" Welch and Jonathan Davis. Korn would become one of the most influential bands of the nu metal genre.

Legacy

Although L.A.P.D. did not achieve significant commercial success, the band is notable for its influence on the nu metal genre. The band's aggressive style and fusion of funk, punk, and metal elements can be seen as a precursor to the sound that Korn would later popularize. Additionally, the band is notable for including three of Korn's founding members.

Discography

L.A.P.D. released one EP and one studio album during their active years. Their EP, "Love and Peace Dude", was released in 1990. Their self-titled debut studio album, "L.A.P.D.", was released in 1991.

Members

The band's lineup consisted of James "Munky" Shaffer on guitar, Reginald "Fieldy" Arvizu on bass, David Silveria on drums, and Richard Morrill on vocals. After the band's disbandment, Shaffer, Arvizu, and Silveria would go on to form Korn.

The AFL Dream Team is a fantasy football game based on the Australian Football League (AFL). It was launched in 2001 and is managed by the AFL in partnership with Telstra. The game allows participants to act as the coach and selector, choosing their own team of AFL players who earn points based on their real-life performances.

The AFL Dream Team competition runs concurrently with the AFL season, beginning with the first round and concluding at the end of the home-and-away season. Participants are required to select a team of 22 players within a set salary cap, with the team needing to consist of players from various positions including forwards, midfielders, defenders, and ruckmen. 

The scoring system in the AFL Dream Team is based on the actual statistical performance of the players in AFL matches. Points are awarded for kicks, handballs, marks, tackles, free kicks, goals, and behinds. The total points scored by all the players in a participant's team constitute the team's score for a round. 

Participants in the AFL Dream Team competition can compete against friends in private leagues or against other participants in public leagues. There are also overall rankings, with prizes awarded to the top-ranked teams at the end of the season. 

The AFL Dream Team has grown in popularity since its inception, with hundreds of thousands of participants each year. It has also contributed to the growth of fantasy sports in Australia, with similar competitions now existing for other sports. 

The AFL Dream Team game has undergone several changes since its launch. These include changes to the scoring system, the introduction of new player positions, and adjustments to the salary cap. These changes are often made in response to changes in the actual AFL competition or to improve the balance and competitiveness of the game.

In conclusion, the AFL Dream Team is a popular and engaging way for fans to interact with the AFL, allowing them to test their knowledge of the game and their ability to predict player performances. It has become an integral part of the AFL landscape, with many fans eagerly anticipating the start of the AFL Dream Team competition each year.

M. Muthaiah is a renowned Indian film director, predominantly working in the Tamil film industry. Luis Manuel Miquilena Hernández (29 July 1919 – 19 November 2016) was a Venezuelan politician who had a dynamic career, spanning over several decades within various prevalent political movements in Venezuela. His career and contributions cast significant influence on modern Venezuelan politics.

Linda Andrews (born 19 October 1973) is a Danish singer who gained prominence after winning the second season of the Danish version of The X Factor in 2009. Known for her soulful voice and powerful performances, Andrews has since established herself as a respected figure in the Danish music industry.

== Early Life ==

In 2010, Andrews released her second album, "Revealed". The album showcased a more mature sound, with Andrews co-writing several of the tracks. Despite receiving positive reviews, the album did not achieve the same commercial success as her debut.

The Whinchat (Saxicola rubetra) is a small migratory passerine bird that is categorized under the Old World flycatcher family, Muscicapidae. It is primarily found across Europe and Asia, with its winter habitats extending to Central and Southern Africa. The name "Whinchat" derives from the Anglo-Saxon word for the common gorse (whin) and "chat" that translates to a small bird.

The Whinchat is distinctive for its white supercilium, a line running from the bill to just behind the eyes, which is bordered with black. Males have rich brown upper-parts with dark streaks and pale buffy or orangish-yellow underparts, with wings featuring distinct white patches. Females, on the other hand, are more subdued in colour, being mostly buff and brown.

Whinchats prefer a range of habitats such as heaths, rough grasslands, and open country with shrubs and small trees. They feed primarily on insects which they catch after a brief aerial pursuit. During breeding seasons, they build a ground-level nest concealed in dense vegetation, laying between 4 to 7 eggs at a time, which are incubated by both parents.

These bird species have an extensive vocal range, delivering a series of soft whistling notes with a 'tacc-tacc-tacc' sound. They can also mimic the songs of other birds. Due to their distinct appearances and lovely singing, Whinchats are frequently spotted by birdwatchers and are much admired for their beauty.

Like other insects-eating birds, Whinchats are significantly affected by changes in farming practices, primarily the increased use of pesticides. The global population has been in decline, prompting conservation measures in several countries. Despite this, as of 2021, the International Union for Conservation of Nature (IUCN) has classified the Whinchat as a species of "Least Concern."

Agencies, such as the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds (RSPB) in the United Kingdom, are rolling out conservation initiatives to sustain the local populations by promoting bird-friendly farming practices. This involves leaving areas of rough grassland for foraging, delayed mowing and reducing pesticide usage.

Researched continuously by ornithologists, the Whinchat contributes significantly to the understanding of bird migration patterns. Their distinctive nature, coupled with their expansive habitats, provides an enormous range for study and understanding of various ecosystems. Helene von Engelhardt (1850–1910) was a prominent Russian-German writer and translator, known for her significant contributions to Russian and German literature during the late 19th and early 20th centuries. 

Born in 1850 in St. Petersburg, Russia, to a German family, von Engelhardt was exposed to a multicultural environment from an early age. This exposure greatly influenced her literary style and themes. She was educated privately and showed an early aptitude for languages and literature.

Von Engelhardt began her writing career in the 1870s, publishing her first novel, "The Heart of a Russian," in 1875. The novel was well-received and established her reputation as a writer of note. She went on to publish several more novels and short stories, many of which focused on the lives and struggles of women in Russian society.

In addition to her writing, von Engelhardt was also a skilled translator. She translated numerous works from Russian into German and vice versa, helping to bridge the gap between the two cultures. Her translations were praised for their accuracy and sensitivity to the nuances of both languages.

Von Engelhardt was also known for her activism. She was a vocal advocate for women's rights and education, and she used her writing to highlight the injustices faced by women in her society. She was also involved in various charitable activities, particularly those aimed at improving the lives of the poor and disadvantaged.

Von Engelhardt's work was widely recognized during her lifetime. She received several awards for her writing and translations, including the prestigious Goethe Medal for Art and Science. Despite facing numerous challenges as a woman in a male-dominated field, she managed to carve out a successful career and leave a lasting legacy in the world of literature.

Helene von Engelhardt died in 1910 in Berlin, Germany. Her work continues to be studied and appreciated today for its literary merit and its insightful portrayal of Russian and German society during a period of significant social and political change.

Hideki Tojo (30 December 1884 – 23 December 1948) was a Japanese politician and military leader who served as the Prime Minister of Japan and President of the Imperial Rule Assistance Association during much of World War II. He was among the most radical of Japan's leaders, advocating for the country's expansionist policies and leading it into the Pacific War against the Allies.

Born in Tokyo, Tojo was the third son of Hidenori Tojo, a lieutenant general in the Imperial Japanese Army. He followed in his father's footsteps, joining the army in 1905 and steadily rising through the ranks. He was a career military man, serving in various capacities including as Chief of Staff of the Kwantung Army in Manchuria from 1937 to 1938.

Tojo was appointed as Minister of War in the cabinet of Prime Minister Fumimaro Konoe in 1940. He was a strong advocate for Japan's alliance with the Axis Powers, which was formalized in the Tripartite Pact of September 1940. In 1941, following the resignation of Konoe, Tojo assumed the role of Prime Minister. He held this position until July 1944, when he was forced to resign due to Japan's deteriorating war situation.

As Prime Minister, Tojo was responsible for the attack on Pearl Harbor in December 1941, which led to the United States' entry into World War II. His government also carried out numerous war crimes, including the forced labor and mistreatment of prisoners of war, and the infamous Nanking Massacre.

After Japan's surrender in 1945, Tojo was arrested by the Allied forces and charged with war crimes. He was found guilty on eight counts, including waging wars of aggression, and war crimes against humanity. He was sentenced to death and executed by hanging in 1948.

Tojo's legacy is controversial. In Japan, he is often viewed as a symbol of Japanese militarism and its consequences. However, he also has his defenders, who argue that he was a patriot who did what he believed was necessary for Japan's survival. Internationally, he is best known as the face of Japanese aggression during World War II. His role in the war and his subsequent trial and execution have made him a significant figure in discussions about war responsibility and justice.

A "Liberal arts education" is a systematic approach to learning that focuses on multi-disciplinary knowledge, critical thinking, analytical reasoning, and comprehensive problem-solving skills. Dating back to the ancient Greeks, this broad learning model is the foundation of western education and is designed to produce well-rounded individuals with general knowledge in a variety of subjects.

Liberal arts education can be distinguished from vocational, technical, professional, and pre-professional education, which are more narrowly focused programs that generally prepare students for a specific career. The curriculum in a liberal arts program often includes humanities, social sciences, creative arts, and science and mathematics. This often includes literature, philosophy, languages, history, sociology, psychology, visual arts, and a basic understanding of the natural and social sciences.

Apart from offering a diverse range of subjects, the liberal arts education aims to develop the intellectual abilities of students. These abilities include analytical thinking, communication skills, problem-solving skills, and an understanding of ethical issues. It values the ability to comprehend and construct arguments, engage in a civil dialogue, and appreciate the value of different perspectives. 

In its classical form, the liberal arts included just seven subjects: grammar, rhetoric, logic (the "trivium"), along with arithmetic, geometry, astronomy, and music (the "quadrivium"). This illustrates the origin of liberal arts as a program designed around fostering rational inquiry, intellectual versatility, and the development of knowledgeable citizens.

The role and relevance of liberal arts education have been the subject of prolonged debate. Those who advocate for it argue that it produces well-rounded individuals who can respond to changes in the market better than those with a narrow discipline specialization. Critics, on the other hand, argue that a liberal arts education does not provide the specific skills needed for specific careers and may thus limit career opportunities.

However, it is generally agreed that a liberal arts education provides the tools to understand complex issues, evaluate arguments, and communicate effectively, critical skills in any profession. Additionally, elements of a liberal arts education are often integrated into specialized and professional degrees to broaden outlooks and enhance critical thinking skills.

In recent times, liberal arts education has been integrated into the curriculum of various international university models, such as those of some European and Asian universities. Nevertheless, it remains most associated with universities in the United States, where liberal arts institutions have continued to thrive.

Andrew Lynn Brasher (born May 20, 1981) is an American attorney and jurist serving as a United States Circuit Judge of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. Prior to his current appointment, he served as a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama.

Born in Milan, Tennessee, Brasher completed his undergraduate studies at Samford University in Birmingham, Alabama, where he graduated summa cum laude. He then proceeded to attain his Juris Doctor from the prestigious Harvard Law School, where he was a member of the Harvard Law Review. 

Following law school, Brasher served as a law clerk to Judge William H. Pryor Jr. of the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit. In 2011, Brasher joined the Alabama Attorney General's Office, where he first served as Deputy Solicitor General before his promotion to Solicitor General of the state in 2014.

On April 10, 2018, President Donald Trump announced his intention to nominate Brasher to serve as a United States District Judge of the United States District Court for the Middle District of Alabama. Upon confirmation by the Senate, he assumed office on May 1, 2019. 

President Trump announced his intent to elevate Brasher to the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit on November 6, 2019. He was confirmed by the Senate on May 21, 2020 and received his commission on June 30, 2020. 

Brasher has also developed a reputation as an expert in election law and civil rights, arguing cases before the United States Supreme Court, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eleventh Circuit, and the Alabama Supreme Court. He has argued and won cases involving the First Amendment, the Second Amendment, the Fourth Amendment, the Equal Protection Clause, and the Voting Rights Act, among other laws and constitutional provisions. 

He is a member of the Federalist Society, a professional organization of conservative and libertarian lawyers, law students, and legal scholars. His work and contribution to legal matters have consistently been highlighted in his career, with a strong emphasis on constitutional law.

Isaac Barr was born on October 25, 1834, in Chester County, Pennsylvania. He was the son of John Barr and Mary Ann (Huston) Barr. Barr attended the University of Alabama, graduating in 1857 with a degree in law. After college, he worked for several years as a clerk in his father's store before starting his own business.

He fought at the Battle of Shiloh and later became a quartermaster sergeant. After being wounded at the Battle of Stones River, he returned home and spent the rest of the war working in the commissary department in Montgomery.

Political Career:
After the war, Barr entered politics, serving as a member of the city council in Tuscaloosa from 1865 to 1867. In 1871, he moved to Birmingham, which had just been incorporated as a city, and opened a general merchandise store. He quickly became involved in local politics, serving as a member of the board of aldermen from 1872 to 1874. In 1874, he was elected as the first mayor of Birmingham, serving two terms until 1876. During his tenure, he oversaw the construction of the city's first waterworks system and the establishment of its first public school system.

Business Interests:
In addition to his political career, Barr also pursued various business interests. He founded the Birmingham Iron and Steel Company in 1881, which eventually became one of the largest steel producers in the South. He also organized the First National Bank of Birmingham

Retour des cendres (French for " Return of the ashes") is a symbolic ceremony in which a person's cremated remains are returned to their homeland or place of origin. The idea behind retour des cendres is that a person's spirit continues to reside in the place where their physical form once existed, and that by returning their ashes to this location, they can be reunited with their ancestors and cultural heritage. This belief is rooted in various cultures and religions around the world, including Native American, African, and Asian traditions.

There are several ways in which return des cendres can take place. In some cases, family members may choose to scatter the ashes themselves, either privately or during a formal ceremony led by community leaders or spiritual officials. Alternatively, groups may organize collective returns, where multiple individuals' ashes are brought back to their shared homeland or place of significance. Some families also opt for a combination approach splitting the ashes between a personal return journey and interment in a communal site.

Returning one's ashes to a specific location conveys significant meaning: it represents respect for one's beginnings while acknowledging the impact of diaspora experiences on shaping identity; furthermore, it celebrates belonging across generations through reconnection with kinship ties and rebuilding relationships within communities left behind. Evolutionary biology is a subfield of biology that focuses on the study of the evolution of species and the patterns and processes that have shaped the diversity of life on Earth. It is a multidisciplinary field that draws on concepts and techniques from genetics, ecology, paleontology, and other related fields to understand the evolution of species and the interactions between organisms and their environments.

The central idea of evolutionary biology is that all living organisms share a common ancestor and have evolved over time through the process of natural selection. This process, first described by Charles Darwin in his book "On the Origin of Species," posits that individuals with advantageous traits are more likely to survive and reproduce, passing those traits on to their offspring. Over time, these small changes can accumulate and result in the development of new species.

One of the key concepts in evolutionary biology is the idea of adaptation. An adaptation is a trait or feature that has evolved to improve an organism's chances of survival and reproduction in its environment. Adaptations can take many forms, such as physical features like wings or camouflage, behaviors like migration or mating, or physiological changes like the development of resistance to disease.

Another important concept in evolutionary biology is speciation, the process by which a new species emerges from an existing one. This can occur through a variety of mechanisms, such as geographic isolation, genetic isolation, or hybridization. Speciation is thought to have occurred many times throughout Earth's history, leading to the incredible diversity of life that we see today.

In addition to these core concepts, evolutionary biology also draws on a variety of other areas of study, including genetics, ecology, and paleontology. Genetics provides the tools to study the genetic variation within and between populations, while ecology helps us understand the interactions between organisms and their environments. Paleontology, the study of fossils, provides a window into the history of life on Earth and allows us to reconstruct the evolutionary history of extinct species.

Evolutionary biology has many practical applications in fields such as medicine

Introduction

Re-making and re-modeling are common practices in various art forms, including music, film, fashion, and visual arts. These terms refer to the process of taking an existing work or idea and transforming it into something new, often with a different perspective or meaning. This practice has been embraced by artists across different generations and disciplines, as it allows them to breathe new life into old ideas, challenge conventional norms, and explore new possibilities.

The Concept of Re-making and Re-modeling

Re-making and re-modeling involve deconstructing an original work and recreating it using new materials, techniques, and perspectives. This process can result in vastly different outcomes, ranging from faithful adaptations to radical transformations. The motivation behind this approach varies depending on the artist's intentions and goals. Some may aim to update a classic work for contemporary audiences, while others seek to subvert the original's meaning or question its relevance in modern society.

In some cases, re-making and re-modeling are driven by technological advancements that allow for new mediums and tools to be used. For example, a filmmaker may choose to recreate a classic movie using cutting-edge computer-generated imagery (CGI), providing a fresh visual experience for viewers. Similarly, musicians might re-record their earlier songs using newer instruments or production software, giving their old material a renewed vigor.

Artists who engage in re-making and re-modeling also have the opportunity to address issues such as cultural appropriation or representation. By updating problematic content or stereotypes, creators can produce more inclusive works that align better with contemporary values and sensitivities.

Supernormal stimuli refer to artificial or exaggerated versions of natural stimuli that can elicit an enhanced response in animals, including humans. The concept was first introduced by ethologist Nikolaas Tinbergen in the 1960s and has since been studied extensively in various fields, including animal behavior, neuroscience, and psychology.

Tinbergen observed that some species have innate behaviors that are triggered by specific stimuli, such as a bird's egg-laying behavior being triggered by the sight of a round, smooth object. However, he found that these behaviors could be fooled by supernormal stimuli, which are more intense or exaggerated versions of the natural stimulus. For example, a bird may be more likely to lay eggs on a giant, brightly colored egg than on a real egg.

The use of supernormal stimuli has helped researchers understand how the brain processes sensory information and how it triggers certain behaviors. By presenting animals with exaggerated versions of natural stimuli, scientists can observe how the brain responds to different aspects of the stimulus, such as its size, color, shape, and movement. This knowledge can then be applied to develop theories about how the brain works and how it controls behavior.

One of the key findings from studies on supernormal stimuli is that they can often elicit stronger responses than natural stimuli. This is thought to occur because the brain is wired to respond strongly to extreme or unusual versions of natural stimuli, as this would have been beneficial for survival in the wild. For example, a bird that is highly sensitive to large, brightly colored objects may be more likely to notice and respond to a predator or a potential mate.

In addition to their role in understanding brain function and behavior, supernormal stimuli have also been used in therapy and treatment. For example, some researchers have developed supernormal stimuli to treat phobias, where patients are exposed to gradually increasing levels of the feared stimulus until they become desensitized to it. Similarly, supernormal stimuli have been used to enhance learning and memory, particularly in individuals with neurological disorders such as autism.

Inpui Naga is one of the tribes belonging to the Naga people, who are indigenous to the north-eastern part of India and parts of Myanmar. The Inpui Naga tribe is settled mainly in the state of Manipur, in the districts of Ukhrul, Senapati and Tamenglong.

The Inpui Nagas speak the Inpui language, which belongs to the Tibeto-Burman language family. It is believed that they migrated from somewhere in Central Asia and gradually moved down to their present habitat in the hills and valleys of Manipur. They have their own distinct culture, customs and traditions. They celebrate festivals like Mithun festival (Ahuna), Kanguiding(King's festival) etc. Rice is their staple food and they also cultivate other crops like millets, maize, pulses, vegetables, fruits, etc. for consumption and sale. They have rich art and craft traditions including wood carving, basket weaving and pottery. Their dress consists of traditional costume with unique designs and colorful patterns. Men wear a long sleeved coat without collar called "Phiran" and women wear a skirt called "Khudei" or " Phanek". Both men and women adorn themselves with various types ornaments made of silver, gold, copper and beads.

They have strong beliefs in spirits and hold high reverence for them. Village wise or clan wise, they have their supreme house of God commonly known as "Amu lands", where festivals were performed by villagers through Village priest every year. Before the reign of British, the area was ruled by chiefs locally known as "Angamos . Later on, the British Colonial Rule took over the power from the Angamos, established by introducing the system of "The Kuki Hills District (Manipur State)" and later on it came under the control of Indian Government after Independence.

Earlier Inpui society had its won judicial system known as 'Khutsa'. However, during the time of British rule, this practice was abolished and people were encouraged to adopt the centralized court system; though it could not fully replace age

The 2009 Gojra riots refer to a series of violent clashes that took place in the town of Gojra, located in the Punjab province of Pakistan, in August 2009. The riots were sparked by allegations of blasphemy against the local Christian community, and resulted in the deaths of at least seven people, injury to many more, and widespread damage to property.

The local police were unable to control the crowd, and the situation quickly escalated into violence.

Over the course of several days, mobs of Muslim residents attacked Christian homes and businesses, setting fire to buildings and vehicles and causing widespread destruction. The police and military were eventually called in to quell the violence, but they were often outnumbered and outmatched by the rioters.

The violence continued until August 31, when the government imposed a curfew in the town and deployed additional security forces to restore order. By the time the riots had subsided, at least seven people had been killed, including two children, and many more had been injured. Hundreds of homes and businesses had been destroyed, leaving countless people without shelter or livelihoods.

The Gojra riots were widely condemned by human rights groups and religious leaders, who called for peaceful dialogue and reconciliation between the Muslim and Christian communities. The government also set up a relief camp for those affected by the violence and provided compensation to the families of those who had been killed or injured.

Despite these efforts, tensions between the two communities remained high, and there were reports of further violence and intimidation against Christians in the months that followed. Scotland Yard is the headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service, which is responsible for law enforcement in the City of London and the surrounding area. Located on Broadway in Westminster, London, Scotland Yard is one of the most famous police stations in the world and has been the site of many historic events.

The origins of Scotland Yard date back to the 17th century, when the Metropolitan Police Service was first established. At that time, the police force was based at a location called "The Old Police Office" in Whitehall. However, as the city grew and the police force expanded, it became clear that a new headquarters was needed. Transferable development rights (TDRs) are a tool used in land use planning and zoning to allow development rights to be transferred from one property to another. The concept of TDRs was first introduced in the United States in the 1960s as a way to preserve agricultural land and open spaces while still allowing for development to occur in urban areas.

The basic principle behind TDRs is that a property owner who owns land with development rights can sell those rights to another property owner who wants to develop their land in a way that would otherwise be prohibited by zoning regulations. The property owner who sells the development rights is typically required to permanently preserve their land in its natural state or for agricultural use, while the buyer can use the acquired rights to build more densely or for a different purpose than would have been allowed without the TDRs.

TDRs can be transferred in several ways, including:

1. Transfer of development rights (TDR): This is the most common form of TDR, where a property owner sells the right to develop their land to another property owner.
2. Development rights transfer (DRT): This is similar to TDR, but the transfer is done through a public or private entity, such as a local government or a land trust.
3. Density transfer: This allows for the transfer of development rights from one property to another within the same zoning district or area, often to encourage more compact and efficient development.
4. Development credits: This is a monetary incentive for property owners to sell their development rights, which can be used to fund conservation or infrastructure projects.

TDRs have several benefits, including:

1. Preservation of open spaces and agricultural land: By transferring development rights to another property, the original land can be preserved in its natural state or for agricultural use, while still allowing for development to occur in a more appropriate location.
2. Encouraging compact and efficient development: TDRs can help to promote more compact and efficient development patterns, which can reduce the need for sprawl and preserve open spaces.

Seodaemun Prison, also known as Seoul Prison or Gyeongseong Prison, was a prison located in Seoul, Korea during the Japanese colonial period (1910-1945). The prison was built in 1908 and operated until 1987. During its time, it was one of the largest prisons in Asia and housed many prominent figures who fought against Japanese colonization.

The prison was designed to hold up to 3,000 prisoners and was notorious for its harsh conditions. Prisoners were subjected to forced labor, physical abuse, and poor living conditions. Many prisoners died due to malnutrition, disease, and mistreatment by guards.

One of the most famous prisoners held at Seodaemun Prison was Kim Koo, a Korean independence activist who served as the president of the Provisional Government of Korea during World War II. Other notable prisoners included Park Chung-hee, who later became the President of South Korea, and various other politicians, intellectuals, and activists who opposed Japanese rule.

During World War II, the prison was used to house political prisoners and those who resisted conscription into the Japanese military. After Japan's defeat in the war, the prison was taken over by the United States Army Military Government in Korea and used to hold Japanese soldiers and collaborators.

In the years following the end of the war, Seodaemun Prison continued to operate under the government of South Korea. However, it was eventually closed down in 1987 due to concerns about human rights violations and overcrowding. Today, the site where the prison once stood has been turned into a park and memorial dedicated to the victims of Japanese colonialism.

Despite its dark history, Seodaemun Prison remains an important part of modern Korean history and serves as a symbol of resistance against oppression and fight for freedom. It is remembered as a place where many brave individuals sacrificed their lives for the cause of Korean independence and democracy.

Isaac Barr (1774-1834) was a prominent American lawyer, politician, and planter from Virginia. He served as a member of the United States House of Representatives and was a strong advocate for states' rights and the interests of the southern states.

Early Life and Education

Isaac Barr was born on October 15, 1774, in Culpeper County, Virginia, to a family of modest means. He received a basic education and went on to study law, being admitted to the bar in 1797. He quickly established himself as a skilled lawyer and began practicing in Culpeper County.

Political Career

Barr's political career began in 1800 when he was elected to the Virginia House of Delegates, where he served for several years. In 1809, he was elected to the United States House of Representatives, where he served for four years. During his time in Congress, Barr was a strong advocate for states' rights and the interests of the southern states. He opposed the tariffs and internal improvements policies of the federal government, believing that they infringed on the rights of the states and unfairly benefited the northern states.

Barr was also a prominent supporter of slavery and opposed any attempts to limit or abolish the practice. He argued that slavery was a necessary institution in the southern states and that it was protected by the Constitution.

Legal Career

In addition to his political career, Barr was also a successful lawyer. He was known for his skilled arguments and his ability to navigate complex legal cases. He represented several prominent clients, including Aaron Burr, who was tried for treason in 1807. Barr's defense of Burr was widely praised, and it helped to establish him as one of the leading lawyers in the country.

Later Life and Legacy

After leaving Congress, Barr returned to his plantation in Virginia, where he continued to practice law and manage his estate. He was a prominent member of his community, serving as a justice of the peace and a member of the board of visitors for the University of Virginia.

Alexandre Menini was born in Venice, Italy in 1964 and has lived in Rome since 1965. He graduated from the Faculty of Architecture of the University La Sapienza in 1995 where he currently teaches Architectural Design and Building Technology.

> Gregory Baum (born 1923) is a Canadian Catholic priest, philosopher and social activist who has been described as one of Canada's most influential intellectuals.^{[1]} He was born in Vienna, Austria to Jewish parents but converted to Roman Catholicism at age 16. In his youth he studied philosophy under Karl Jaspers and Martin Heidegger before emigrating to Montreal where he became a professor of sociology at McGill University. His work on liberation theology led him into conflict with the Vatican during the Second Vatican Council. After being excommunicated by Pope Paul VI for supporting ordination of women priests, he returned to the Church after John Paul II lifted the sanction against him.
>
> ## Early life[edit]
>
> Born in Vienna, Austria, Baum grew up in a secular home. At age 14, he began attending Mass regularly and soon thereafter decided to convert to Christianity. He chose Catholicism over Protestantism because it had more sacraments and rituals that appealed to him. When he told his father about this decision, his father responded, "You are not going to become a Christian."^{[2]} However, when Baum turned sixteen, he went ahead with his conversion anyway. This caused a rift between himself and his family; they did not speak to each other again until after World War II ended.^{[3]}
>
> ## Education[edit]
>
> Baum attended high school in Vienna and then moved to Paris to study philosophy under Karl Jaspers and Martin Heidegger. During this time, he also worked as a journalist for Le Monde Diplomatique.^{[4]} In 1950, he immigrated to Canada and enrolled at McGill University where he earned degrees in both history and sociology.^{[5]} While studying at McGill, he met Dorothy Canning, whom he married in 1957.^{[6]} They have two children together: David and Anne-Marie.^{[7]}

Charlie Wagner (1 April 1873 – 19 December 1918) was a U.S. football player and coach, a professional baseball player, and a sports promoter. Born in Detroit, he earned a degree in chemical engineering from Ann Arbor's University of Michigan, was a member of the Psi Upsilon fraternity, and represented the Wolverines as the team's chief "captain" from 1895 to 1897. He was a three-year letter winner in football at the university. Wagner was an All-American tackle in 1896, and was selected as a consensus All-American in the middle of the line in 1897. In 1897 Wagner was also chosen as the team's captain. He also played professional baseball with the Detroit Tigers for five years. After coaching football at the University of Chicago for a few years, he returned to Ann Arbor for the school term of 1902–03. He was named "captain" of the squad for the 1902 season. Michigan's line was nicknamed the "Charlie Wagner machine" that season in Wagner's own memory. Wagner coached Michigan to a 10–1 record and an 18–0 victory over the Big Ten Conference rival Penn State on October 31, 1902, and to an 11–0 win over the Western Conference (predecessor to the Big Ten Conference) champion Wisconsin on November 15. In 1902–03 Wagner taught a freshman mathematics course, with an enrollment of 130 students, and coached baseball, which he called "my favorite sport," for one year. In 1903 Wagner coached the UM basketball team to a 6–3 record, 2–1 Big Ten record, and the Western Conference championship. He was elected President of the Detroit Baseball League for 1905, 1906, and 1907. Wagner was a member of the National Football Foundation College Football Hall of Fame. HMS Rodney (29) was a British Royal Navy battleship, the second ship of the Nelson class. She was named after Admiral Lord Nelson, who had commanded the British fleet at the Battle of Trafalgar. Rodney was laid down at the Cammell Laird shipyard in Birkenhead on 15 November 1922, launched on 28 November 1925, and commissioned on 20 December 1927.

> James Naismith (November 6, 1861 – November 28, 1939) was a Canadian physical educator and sports coach who invented basketball in December 1891 while working as a teacher at the International Young Men's Christian Association Training School (YMCA), now Springfield College, in Springfield, Massachusetts.[1] He also created the first rules for volleyball in 1895. In addition to his work with these two games, he developed early forms of hockey on roller skates, lacrosse, and football.
>
> ## Early life[edit]
>
> Born in Almonte, Ontario, Canada, Naismith was raised by his mother after his father died when he was six years old. His family moved to Ramsay Township near Ottawa where he attended school until age fourteen. At that time, he left home to attend McGill University in Montreal, Quebec. After graduating from McGill in 1887, he went to the YMCA training college in Springfield, Massachusetts, United States, where he received a Bachelor of Physical Education degree in 1890. While there, he met Maude Sherman whom he married in 1894. They had three children together before she passed away in 1923.
>
> ## Basketball[edit]
>
> ### Creation[edit]
>
> On October 19, 1891, Naismith wrote down twelve rules for a new game called "Basket Ball". These were published in the January 15, 1892 issue of the Triangle, the student newspaper of the YMCA Training School. The original basket ball rules are displayed in the National Museum of Health and Medicine in Silver Springs, Maryland.
>
> According to Naismith, the idea came to him during a brainstorming session about how to keep athletes fit during winter months. A number of indoor athletic activities were suggested including gymnastics, wrestling, and tumbling. However, none of them seemed appropriate for the purpose. Viktor K. Jirsa (born 1967) is a Czech-American mathematician and computer scientist. He is a professor of mathematics at the University of California, Irvine.

Jirsa was born in Prague, Czechoslovakia. He received his Ph.D. in 1993 from the Czech Technical University in Prague. He was a postdoctoral fellow at the University of California, Berkeley, and a visiting assistant professor at the University of California, Los Angeles. He joined the faculty of the University of California, Irvine in 1997.

Jirsa's research interests include dynamical systems, control theory, and nonlinear partial differential equations. He is known for his work on the theory of nonlinear partial differential equations, including the theory of nonlinear waves, the theory of nonlinear dispersive equations, and the theory of nonlinear evolution equations. He is also known for his work on the theory of nonlinear control systems, including the theory of nonlinear feedback control, the theory of nonlinear stabilization, and the theory of nonlinear optimal control.

Jirsa is a member of the American Mathematical Society, the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics, and the International Federation of Automatic Control. He is a fellow of the American Mathematical Society.

Jirsa is the author of the book "Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations: Theory and Applications" (Cambridge University Press, 2004). He is also the author of the book "Nonlinear Control Systems: Theory and Applications" (Cambridge University Press, 2007).

Jirsa is the recipient of the 2008 SIAM/ACM Prize in Computational Science and Engineering. He is also the recipient of the 2010 SIAM/ACM Prize in Computational Science and Engineering.

The original Batman co-creator Bob Kane would draw a rough layout consisting of just pencils, then pass or sell them off to other artists who would complete his drawings with ink. The first one he sold was to Joe Maneely in 1953.^{[4]} Soon thereafter, Sinnott began inking Kane's Batman series as well, which at the time were featured by DC Comics as back–up features starring characters such as Rex Tyler and Robin. Since that time, he has worked mainly for Marvel on character like Spider-Man, Iron Fist, the Fantastic Four and Daredevil, where he did work in collaboration with artist Gene Colan, earning him multiple awards including several Ink Pot Awards,^{[2]}^{[5]} including three for Best inker in 1978 and 1979. He has also been active in other areas, having written a short strip called "Howard The Human Beaver", published by National Lampoon Magazine, about a beaver scientist who invents many useful items for mankind; in the late 1960s/early 70s, this series won him two Harvey Awards^{[6]} . He wrote screenplays for television shows including Scooby Doo! and The Secret Saturdays. A biography entitled Life Drawings: A Graphic Memoir by Joe Sinnott (ISBN) includes autobiographical information as an inker at various studios throughout his career.^{[7]}

> Milton Fisher (born 1946) was a former American football player and coach, who played in the National Football League for the New York Giants and Washington Redskins as a defensive back. He also served as head coach at his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, where he coached from 1978 to 1980.
>
> ## Early lifeEdit
>
> A native of Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, Fisher attended Central High School before matriculating to the University of Pennsylvania, where he played college football for the Quakers under head coaches George Munger and Dick Harlow.^{[2]} As a senior in 1965, Fisher led Penn with six interceptions and earned first-team All-Ivy honors.^{[3]}^{[4]} In addition to playing football, Fisher competed on the track team during his time at Penn.^{[5]}
>
> ## Professional careerEdit
>
> After graduating from Penn, Fisher signed with the New York Giants as an undrafted free agent in 1966. He spent two seasons with the Giants, appearing in nine games without making any starts. Following his release by the Giants after the 1967 season, Fisher joined the Washington Redskins in 1968. He appeared in all 14 regular season games that year, starting one game at cornerback. However, he did not appear in either of the Redskins' playoff contests against the Dallas Cowboys or Cleveland Browns.^{[6]}
>
> ## Coaching careerEdit
>
> ### College coachingEdit
>
> Upon retiring from professional football, Fisher returned to his alma mater, the University of Pennsylvania, where he began working as an assistant coach in 1969. He remained on staff through the end of the decade, serving as both the offensive backs coach and special teams coordinator.^{[7]}
>
> On December 1, 1977, Fisher was named the new head coach at Penn, replacing Bill Bradley, who had resigned earlier that day.^{[8]} During his three years as head coach, Fisher compiled a record of 10–22–1, including a mark of 5–15–1 in Ivy League

The term transatlantic relations refers to the relationship between North America and Europe, particularly the United States and Canada on one side and Western European countries (and sometimes Russia) on the other. Transatlantic relations are often considered in terms of political, economic or cultural ties. In recent years, however, they have also been discussed with regard to security issues such as terrorism and energy policy.

## History[edit]

### Early history[edit]

In 1492 Christopher Columbus sailed west across the Atlantic Ocean for Spain, hoping to find a new route to Asia. He landed instead in what he thought was India but which turned out to be the Bahamas. His voyage marked the beginning of regular contact between Europeans and Native Americans. It took another century before permanent settlements were established by Europeans in the Americas.

European colonization of the New World began when Spanish explorers arrived at present-day Florida in 1565. France followed suit soon after, establishing its first colony in Quebec City in 1608. England's Jamestown Colony was founded two years later. These three nations would go on to become major players in shaping early American politics and culture. Other European powers including Portugal, Sweden, Denmark/Norway, Netherlands, Germany and Russia all had brief periods of involvement in North America during this time period. However, it wasn't until the late 17th century that these countries started sending large numbers of settlers over to their respective colonies. By then most of them had already lost interest due to financial difficulties back home or because they found better opportunities elsewhere like Africa or South America.

During this same period there were several attempts made by various groups within each country to establish independent republics within their own borders. Some succeeded while others failed miserably. One notable example being the Republic of Texas which lasted only four months before being absorbed into Mexico again. Another interesting case study involves Vermont which declared itself an independent nation under British rule prior to becoming part of the United States. This move proved unpopular among many residents who preferred remaining loyal subjects of King George III rather than risking war against him. > Francis Pollock (1845–1937) was a British lawyer and legal scholar, best known for his work on equity law in England and Wales. He was also a member of Parliament for 20 years.
>
> ## Biography[edit]
>
> Born at Wolverhampton, he was educated at Rugby School and Trinity College, Cambridge, where he graduated with first-class honours in the Classical Tripos in 1866.^{[1]} After studying law at Lincoln's Inn, he became a barrister in 1870. In 1874 he married Mary Elizabeth Hodgson; they had two sons and three daughters.
>
> From 1876 to 1880 he served as private secretary to Sir William Harcourt, then Chancellor of the Exchequer. He was elected Member of Parliament for Southampton in 1880, serving until 1895 when he resigned after being appointed Solicitor General by Lord Rosebery. He held that office until 1898, when he returned to practice at the bar.
>
> His most important contribution to English jurisprudence came through his work on equity law. He published A Treatise on Equity Jurisprudence in 1882, which went into several editions over the next few decades. It was followed by a second volume in 1896, and a third volume in 1909. These works were later combined into one large book entitled The Principles of Anglo-American Law, which appeared in 1928. This work has been described as "the greatest single achievement in the field of equity since Pothier".^{[2]}
>
> He died in London in 1937.

Javon Ringer (American football)
From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Javon Dwight Ringer (born November 11, 1984 in Elizabeth, New Jersey) is an American football running back for the Detroit Lions of the National Football League. He currently wears the #20 uniform. He was drafted in the sixth round of the 2009 NFL Draft as the 171st overall pick (sixth pick in the sixth round). Ringer was a standout collegiate player at Michigan State University, where, over a four-year period, he rushed for over 4,000 yards and 39 touchdowns.

High school years
Ringer attended Elizabeth High School in Elizabeth, New Jersey. As a senior, he rushed for a then-school record 1,742 yards and 22 touchdowns. He finished the 2003 season third in the state with a 10.1 average per carry.[1] He rushed for 913 yards and 10 touchdowns as a junior.

Ringer is the only high school athlete to ever win the Home News Tribune Athlete of the Year award twice in back-to-back years.

Ringer also played basketball. He holds the 2nd highest perimeter points in 1 game(46) in the school's history.

College years
Ringer began his career at Central Michigan in 2004. After red shirting his first season, he transferred to Michigan State before playing his first season during the 2005 season. Originally, Ringer was a defensive back before transferring and choosing to become an offensive player. In 2007, he was elected the Spartans' offensive captain by his teammates.

In his four-year career at MSU, Ringer rushed for over 4,000 yards and 39 touchdowns. For his career, Ringer averaged 109.3 yards rushing per game, 24.4 yards per kickoff return, and 5.3 yards per carry. His rushing yards are second in Michigan State history only to Lorenzo White. He ranked fourth

Makoto Sakamoto (坂本 誠, Sakamoto Makoto, born 1968) is a Japanese video game composer and musician. He is best known for his work on the Tales series of role-playing video games, including Tales of Phantasia, Tales of Destiny, Tales of Eternia, Tales of Symphonia, Tales of the Abyss, and Tales of Vesperia. He has also composed music for the Sakura Wars series, the Star Ocean series, and the Valkyrie Profile series.

Sakamoto was born in 1968 in Tokyo, Japan. He began playing the piano at the age of four, and later learned to play the guitar and the bass guitar. He attended the Tokyo College of Music, where he studied composition.

Sakamoto began his career as a composer in 1991, when he was hired by Namco to compose music for the video game Tales of Phantasia. He has since composed music for a number of other video games, including the Tales of Destiny series, the Star Ocean series, and the Valkyrie Profile series.

Sakamoto's music is often described as being "epic" and "orchestral". He has said that he is influenced by the music of film composers such as John Williams and Hans Zimmer.

Sakamoto has also released a number of albums of his own music, including the albums "Tales of Phantasia: The Best of Makoto Sakamoto" and "Tales of Symphonia: The Best of Makoto Sakamoto".

Sakamoto is married and has two children.
