Mahalakshmi (also spelled as Laxmi) is a Hindu goddess, who symbolizes wealth and prosperity. She is also known by other names such as Sri, Shree or Bhoodevi. In her benevolent form she is called Santana Lakshmi, which means 'Lakshmi bestowing children'. Her name comes from two Sanskrit words - laksya meaning aim and ami meaning I. Thus, Lakshmi literally translates to 'the goal' or 'that towards which one strives.'

In Hinduism, Lakshmi is considered the consort of Vishnu, the preserver in the Trimurti. As his shakti, she represents the feminine energy that pervades all creation. She is often depicted with four arms holding lotus flowers, mace, chamara and alms bowl. She rides on a lotus flower or owl.

The worship of Lakshmi has been prevalent since ancient times. Many temples are dedicated to her throughout India. Some of these include the Ekambareswarar Temple at Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu; the Lakshminarayan temple at Varanasi, Uttar Pradesh; the Lakshmi Narasimha Swamy Temple at Nandyal, Andhra Pradesh; the Lakshmi Devi Temple at Khajuraho, Madhya Pradesh; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at Ahobilam, Andhra Pradesh; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at Melkote, Karnataka; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at Simhachalam near Visakhapatnam, Andhra Pradesh; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at Yadagirigutta, Telangana; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at Thirukannapuram, Tamil Nadu; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at Mundeshwari, Jharkhand; the Lakshmi-Narasimha Temple at

The Udauli (also spelled as Oudhali, Odhali or Udhali) is a traditional folk dance form of Bihar and Jharkhand states in India. It is performed by women during festivals like Holi, Chaitra Parva, Durga Puja etc. This dance is also known as 'Dandia' because it involves dancing with sticks called Danda. In this dance, two groups of girls face each other and perform rhythmic movements while clapping their hands and singing songs. They hold wooden sticks in their hands which are used to hit the ground in time with the music. The dancers wear colorful clothes and jewelry, and often apply henna on their hands and feet. The dance is accompanied by traditional instruments such as the dholak, tabla, and harmonium.

The eastern North American temperate broadleaf and mixed forests are a large ecoregion, occupying the northeast section of North America from Quebec to Florida. To emphasize geographic boundaries, this article uses the term "eastern temperate forest" as it appears in Wikipedia's broader article on woodlands and forest biomes; however, more recently, scholars have redefined the terms associated with U.S. vegetation by creating plant associations that cover several states.[1] In Canada these regions are collectively known by its common name (Boreal Shield), reflecting its history.
These forests exist along the transitional climatic gradient between the Great Plains climate zone to the west and Maritime provinces of Southeastern Canada climate zone[2] to the east. Forests can be divided into two primary types: Southern Oak-Chestnut forest and Northern White Cedar-Hemlock-Pine forest, although there are numerous subtypes each adapted for local conditions based upon soil type, topography and moisture availability.[3][4] Coniferous trees account for approximately 50% of all tree species within the Eastern Temperate Deciduous Forest. Pines account for over half of conifers present.[5] Due to a variety of factors such as fire and flooding, there is tremendous variation across the region as opposed to some ecological groups where similar or higher amounts of diversity may have only subtle differences among species populations when compared side by side; one location in a particular state could contain oak, hickory, ash, sugar maple and hemlock while another might replace pine for ash or elm instead. There has been debate over which part of the Northeast United States represents true boreal forest, with evidence suggesting that Maine should not be classified as such due to its southerly placement relative too much larger parts found throughout northwestern Quebec province[6]. It would take millions years before these areas regrow if cut down entirely now because many native plants/animals cannot tolerate cooler winters experienced further south near Atlantic coastline making any attempt impossible without importing foreign organisms into habitat unsuited their natural needs resulting disastrous consequences potentially fatal even smaller creatures like insect larvae unable survive freezing winter storms

> Mary Virginia Orna (born 1942) was a United States Army officer who served as Deputy Assistant Secretary of Defense for Public Affairs during the Clinton administration, and later became president of the National Press Club in Washington D.C.. She also worked at the Pentagon as Director of Media Operations under Donald Rumsfeld.
>
> ## Early life and education[edit]
>
> Born on July 30, 1942, in New York City to parents Joseph and Helen Orna, she graduated from Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan before attending Barnard College where she earned her bachelor's degree in English literature.^{[1]} After graduating college, she joined the U.S. Army Reserve Officer Training Corps program at Columbia University, earning her commission as a second lieutenant upon completion of the coursework.^{[2]}
>
> ## Military career[edit]
>
> In 1965, after completing ROTC training, Orna began active duty service with the Women’s Army Corps (WAC).^{[3]} Her first assignment was as a public information specialist at Fort Lee, Virginia, followed by assignments at Fort Belvoir, Virginia; Fort Monmouth, New Jersey; and Fort Meade, Maryland.^{[4]} During this time, she completed graduate studies at George Mason University, receiving a master's degree in journalism in 1978.^{[5]}
>
> From 1980 until 1983, Orna served as chief of the WAC Recruiting Command at Fort McClellan, Alabama, and then returned to Fort Myer, Virginia, where she served as director of recruiting operations for the entire WAC.^{[6]} Following the abolition of the WAC in 1978, Orna continued serving in the newly formed Women's Army Field Force (WAFF), which was renamed the Women's Army Corps Branch in 1981.^{[7]}
>

Hapsford Hall is a large country house in the village of Hapsford, Cheshire, England. It is a Grade II* listed building.

The house was built in 1860 for the wealthy industrialist and philanthropist John Leigh, who had made his fortune in the cotton industry. The architect was Thomas Worthington. The house was built in the Italianate style, with a central tower and a large portico. The interior of the house is decorated with fine plasterwork and wood carvings.

The house was sold in 1920 and has since been used as a school, a hotel, and a conference centre. It is now owned by the University of Chester and is used as a conference centre and for other events.

The house is open to the public on certain days of the year.

## History[edit]

The Klamath Indians were among the first Native Americans to encounter European explorers and settlers in what would become Oregon. They lived along the lower reaches of the Klamath River for thousands of years before the arrival of Europeans.^{[1]} In 1853, a treaty was signed with the United States government that ceded most of their land to the U.S., but it was never ratified by Congress. After the discovery of gold in northern California in 1849, many miners came through the area on their way north. Many stayed and settled there permanently. By 1860, the population had grown enough to warrant the creation of Klamath County. It was named after the river which flows through its center.

In 1872, the county seat was moved from Weitchpec (now called Requa) to Yreka. This move was controversial at the time because the new location was far away from the majority of residents who lived near the coast. However, the town of Yreka grew rapidly as more people arrived seeking gold and other opportunities. Today, Yreka remains the largest city in Klamath County and serves as its economic hub.

During World War II, several military bases were built in Klamath County to support American troops fighting overseas. These included Camp White (later renamed Fort Lewis), Camp Adair (renamed Camp Riley), and Camp Myles Standish (renamed Camp Pendleton). After the war ended, these facilities were closed down or converted into civilian uses such as housing developments or parks.

Today, Klamath County continues to be home to many different industries including agriculture, forestry, mining, tourism, manufacturing, retail trade, health care services, education institutions, etc.. Its economy has diversified over time due largely to changes brought about by technological advances like computers/internet accessibility; however, some traditional businesses still exist here too! For example: logging companies continue operating despite declining timber harvests while farmers grow crops using modern techniques instead of relying solely upon rainfall alone...

The Hebrew Bible (or Old Testament) and Talmudical literature were his principal interests in Jewish studies; but he also showed deep involvement with matters ranging from historical geography to musicology, bibliography and classical philology—indeed, any domain that offered hints for illuminating his main preoccupations. From 1926 onwards, he lectured at several universities within Israel [then Palestine], including Jerusalem's Hebrew University (Hebrew: האוניברסיטה העברית), before devoting himself mainly to research, the writing of books, and teaching young scholars by individual tutorial. He died in Tel Aviv [at] age 80.

Although generally acknowledged as a great scholar of unsurpassable breadth and depth, Hanoch Albeck nevertheless failed to attract wide popularity among academic students and other readers. In part this was due to the difficulty or ponderousness of style of his works, which often read like complex essays rather than expositions by someone capable of simplifying difficult material. Also responsible may have been his tendency not only to reject established scholarly consensus where it conflicted with facts cited by him, but even to disparage views that differed sharply from those favored by him without offering solid proof against acceptance.[3][4]. Still, despite his detractors, many regard[5] or believe[3] Albeck to be one of the most important figures in Jewish scholarship of modern times. He has no real successor among Israeli academics in biblical and rabbinic fields. For years thereafter few Israelis took to seriously confronting ancient texts. The situation changed in recent decades when the Hebrew language became enmeshed in various linguistic sciences such as semiotics and discourse analysis."

## Trade, tourism, investment and industrialisation[edit]

### Agriculture[edit]

Agricultural activities like rice farming dominantly takes place here because of irrigation systems along River Tana and Murang'a Rivers flowing across Mwingi and Tigania areas respectively. Also dairy sector and cattle rearing take centre stage due to good pastures especially for the kenyan Shorthorn breeders. These two sectors have also been enhanced more over with establishment of Masingo farm near makondoro where KenGen power generators are installed to offer a consistent supply to these farmers. Tea growing was also considered for commercialization during 70s but not successful hence abandoned since then^{[Citation needed]}
- Crops produced include beans, maize, sweet potatoes, yams, cassava vegetables plus rice in large scale especially for export purposes. Some are sold in open markets or through agribusinesses such as the National Cereals Produce Board .^{[43]}
- Livestock kept includes goats,^{[citation needed]} camels poultry (e.g., Guinea fowls) ,rabbits and other small stock species.^{[51][52][53]}^{[54]} This has helped boost domestic and international trade in protein products too e.g., meat marketed in Githurai area.

Transitional bilingualism refers to the process by which an individual learns and uses two or more languages in a sequential manner. This typically occurs when a person moves from one language environment to another, either due to migration or other reasons, and must adapt to the new linguistic community. In this context, transitional bilingualism is distinct from simultaneous bilingualism, where individuals are exposed to both languages at the same time from birth, resulting in a different pattern of language acquisition and use.

The process of transitional bilingualism can occur at any age, but it is most commonly associated with childhood. When children move between languages, they often experience a period of confusion and disorientation as they struggle to make sense of the new linguistic system. However, research has shown that children who are exposed to multiple languages during this critical period of brain development are actually better able to acquire and maintain all of the languages involved.

One key factor in successful transitional bilingualism is the child's level of exposure to each language. Ideally, children should be surrounded by native speakers of both languages and have ample opportunities to practice speaking and listening in each language on a regular basis. Additionally, parents and caregivers can play an important role in supporting the child's language learning by providing consistent and positive reinforcement for their efforts.

Despite the many benefits of transitional bilingualism, there are also potential challenges that may arise. For example, some children may develop language mixing or code-switching, where they combine elements of both languages in their speech. While this can be a natural part of the language learning process, it can also lead to difficulties in communicating effectively with monolinguals or in maintaining proficiency in either language. To address these issues, it is important for children to receive guidance and support from adults who are familiar with both languages and can help them to develop clear and accurate communication skills in each language.

Overall, transitional bilingualism is a complex and dynamic process that involves adapting to new linguistic environments and developing the ability to communicate effectively in multiple languages. With appropriate support and resources, children who grow up in transitional bilingual settings can reap numerous cognitive, social, and cultural benefits that will serve them well throughout their lives.

Anwar Khatib (born 1958) is an American-Syrian journalist and author. He was born in Damascus, Syria to a Christian family. After studying journalism at the University of California, Berkeley, he worked as a reporter for various newspapers and magazines in the United States before moving back to Syria in 2003 to work as a freelance writer and editor.

Khatib's writing has focused on politics, culture, and society in Syria, and he has been critical of both the government and opposition forces in the country. In 2011, he became one of the first journalists to report extensively on the Syrian Civil War, covering protests and violence in cities such as Homs, Daraa, and Aleppo. His reporting earned him international recognition and praise from human rights organizations.

In addition to his work as a journalist, Khatib is also known for his activism and advocacy for democracy and civil liberties in Syria. He has spoken out against censorship and repression by the government and has supported efforts to promote freedom of expression and press.

Despite facing threats and harassment from authorities, Khatib continues to report on events in Syria and advocate for change. He has received numerous awards and honors for his work, including the Committee to Protect Journalists' International Press Freedom Award in 2014.

A unilateral policy is a policy that is implemented by a single entity, such as a government or organization, without the involvement or consent of other parties. This type of policy can be controversial, as it may not take into account the needs or interests of other stakeholders.

One example of a unilateral policy is a trade embargo, which is a policy that prohibits or limits trade with a particular country. This type of policy is often used as a way to apply economic pressure to a country, with the aim of bringing about political or economic change. However, it can also have negative consequences for the country being embargoed, as it can limit access to goods and services that are essential for its survival.

Another example of a unilateral policy is a policy of military intervention. This can involve the use of force to achieve a particular goal, such as overthrowing a government or protecting civilian populations. Military intervention can be controversial, as it may not always be effective and can have unintended consequences.

Overall, unilateral policies can be effective in achieving certain goals, but they are often controversial and may not always be the best course of action. It is important for any entity that implements unilateral policies to carefully consider the potential consequences and to take steps to minimize any negative impacts.

Kristen Graczyk (born July 19, 1973) is an American journalist and author. She is best known for her work as a freelance journalist and author, and for her role in the 2005 kidnapping of her husband, Thomas Howes, in Baghdad, Iraq.

Graczyk was born in New York City, New York, and grew up in the suburbs of New Jersey. She attended Princeton University, where she earned a degree in English literature. After graduation, she worked as a freelance journalist and author, and traveled extensively throughout the Middle East and Asia.

In 2005, Graczyk and her husband, Thomas Howes, were kidnapped by insurgents in Baghdad, Iraq, while they were working on a book about the city. They were held captive for 13 days before being released unharmed.

Graczyk's experiences in Iraq inspired her to write a memoir, "The Baghdad Briefing: Our Year in Iraq," which was published in 2007. The book received critical acclaim and was a finalist for the 2008 Pulitzer Prize for General Nonfiction.

Graczyk has continued to work as a freelance journalist and author, and has traveled extensively throughout the Middle East and Asia. She is also a frequent commentator on Middle Eastern politics and culture.

HACS (pronounced "Hacks") is an American web-based software tool used for creating CNC machine tools. It is open-source and free to use. The software allows users to import 3D models, create custom toolpaths, and generate G-code files that can be used to machine metal and plastic parts. It is designed to be easy to use, with a user-friendly interface and extensive tutorials, making it accessible to hobbyists as well as professionals.

One of the unique features of HACS is its ability to create full-machine tool programs, including tool changing and machine-optimized code. This allows users to create high-quality, production-level parts using a standard 3D printer turned CNC machine. Additionally, HACS has support for a wide variety of CNC machines, including CNC routers, milling machines, and 3-axis and 5-axis machining centers.

Another feature of HACS is its extensive library of pre-built toolpaths and customizable machine configurations. This makes it easy for users to create customized solutions for a wide variety of parts and materials. Additionally, HACS has a strong community of users and developers creating new tools and features for the software.

HACS was created by Benno Kokma, a Dutch developer, and Chris Mueller, an American engineer. It is licensed under the GPL 3.0, which means that users are free to use, modify, and distribute the software. HACS is available for download on the software's official website, and there is also a cloud-based version that allows for remote collaboration and real-time file sharing.

Scotland Yard, also known as New Scotland Yard or simply The Yard, is the headquarters of the Metropolitan Police Service (Met) in London, England. It is located on Whitehall, near Westminster Abbey and the Palace of Westminster.

The current building was completed in 1829 and designed by Sir Charles Barry with William Henry Barlow as the chief engineer. It replaced an earlier structure that had been used since 1745. The name "Scotland Yard" originated from the fact that it was originally situated next to the Scottish Gallery in Whitehall, which sold prints and drawings from Scotland.

In addition to serving as the headquarters for the Met, Scotland Yard houses several important units within its walls. These include the Criminal Investigation Directorate (CID), which oversees all major criminal investigations in London; the Anti-Terrorist Branch (ATB), responsible for countering terrorism in the city; and the Public Order Command, which deals with maintaining public order during demonstrations and other events.

Over the years, Scotland Yard has become synonymous with detective work and has played a prominent role in many famous cases. Inspector Lestrade and Sergeant Lewis are two fictional detectives who are based at Scotland Yard and feature prominently in the television series "Life on Mars" and "Ashes to Ashes."

Despite its reputation as one of the most prestigious police forces in the world, Scotland Yard has faced criticism over the years for its handling of high-profile cases such as the Stephen Lawrence murder investigation and the Hillsborough disaster. However, it remains one of the most respected institutions in law enforcement and continues to play a vital role in keeping London safe.

The Dutch Reformed Church bishop J. G. Strijker ordained him as an elderly man before his death, making him one of only two men to hold both positions in the history of the country.

Verwoerd grew up on his family farm near Lyndenburg, Transvaal Colony, as one of four sons born to Abraham Willem Jacobus Verwoerd, who served as Prime Minister in 1945, and Adriana Hendrina Johanna Vlok. After attending HBS Middelschool Uitgeest, Verwoord studied at Voortrekkerbosch Teachers' Training College in Cape Town before taking a degree in agriculture at the University of Pretoria in 1927.

Returning home after graduation, he taught for some time before joining his father's government. While serving as private secretary in the Department of Education, he took charge of administering Afrikaans schools following the 1948 Volkskraal, which saw the party win the majority in that year's general election and form the first Government under the apartheid system. He is credited with implementing policies that significantly increased funding for and standardised many Afrikaans-medium schools.

During this period, Verwoerd became increasingly convinced of the need for racial separation between blacks and whites, proposing an education policy known as separate development. This proposed dividing black education into Bantu language "homelands" rather than providing them with opportunities for integration into mainstream society. These ideas would later become central to apartheid policy during his presidency.

Later, as Prime Minister, Verwoerd played a key role in the Sharpeville massacre in March 1960 when security forces killed over 180 protesters protesting against the jailing of activist Nelson Mandela. Enamelin (also known as enamel protein) is a protein found in the enamel of teeth. It is a member of the family of proteins known as the enamelins, which also includes amelogenin and ameloblastin. Enamelin is synthesized by ameloblasts, the cells that produce enamel, and is incorporated into the enamel matrix during the process of enamel formation.

Enamelin is a glycoprotein with a molecular weight of approximately 54 kDa. It consists of two repeating domains, each of which is responsible for the formation of a specific type of hydrogen bond. These hydrogen bonds are responsible for the high strength and durability of enamel. Enamelin also contains several post-translational modifications, including phosphorylation and glycosylation, which are important for the proper functioning of the protein.

The role of enamelin in enamel formation is not fully understood, but it is believed to play a critical role in the organization of the enamel matrix. Enamelin is thought to interact with other proteins and minerals in the matrix, helping to form the complex network of hydrogen bonds that give enamel its strength and durability.

Enamelin is also involved in the process of tooth erosion. When the enamel on the teeth is exposed to acid, enamelin can undergo a process of degradation, which can lead to the loss of enamel and increased susceptibility to further erosion.

In summary, enamelin is a protein found in the enamel of teeth that plays a critical role in the formation and organization of the enamel matrix. It is also involved in the process of tooth erosion. Further research is needed to fully understand the function of enamelin and its role in oral health.

Luigi Ghilardi (born 14 November 1957) is an Italian children's television host and puppeteer. He is best known internationally for his work on Italy's beloved children's TV series, Gimme Gimmi Gimmegheh, which premiered in 1982 and ran until 1986. Ghilardi also hosted its revival from 10 September to 20 May 1993.

A native of San Lorenzo al Vesuvio, near Naples in southern Italy, Ghilardi began his career as a stage performer as an eight-year-old, when he joined his parents' traveling theater troupe. In the late 1970s, he moved on to live performances with the influential Teatro dei Marionettei di Palermo. After stints as a puppeteer at La Casa delle Pupazzi in Rome and Compagnia del Bambino in Milan, Ghilardi returned to the southern Italian city of San Lorenzo in 1982; it was there that he would create and host one of the most well-loved children's programs in Italian history – Gimme Gimmi Gimmegheh (often spelled transliterated or anglicized as Gimmi Gimmi Geham).

Ghilardi puppeted his own character, Pinocchio Gigante (Jumbo Jack in English releases), over six seasons of the show (from 1982–86 and 1993); his other popular characters included Winnie il Pooh, Bugs Bunny, Popeye, Alvin and Chipmunks, Paddington Bear, and Garfield. He combined these characters during performances by utilizing innovative techniques allowing them to interact within a single frame. In addition to the numerous celebrity guests who appeared on the show, he performed opposite notable pop culture figures such as Kermit the Frog and Mickey Mouse. The show introduced many young Italians to American cinema and provided some of their earliest experiences and exposure to foreign cultures and languages. Ghilardi's success helped pave the way for further Italian children's programming and cultural exchange.

Francis Pollock (1824 – 1886) was an American businessman and politician. He served as the 56th Mayor of Boston from 1865 to 1869, and later as a member of the Massachusetts House of Representatives for the Third Suffolk district.

Pollock was born in Boston in 1824 to a prominent businessman family. He graduated from the Boston Latin School and later pursued higher education at Harvard University. He then joined his father's firm as a clerk and worked his way up to become the president of the company.

During his tenure as Mayor of Boston, Pollock faced many challenges. The city was still reeling from the devastating effect of the Boston Fire of 1872, which had destroyed a significant portion of the city. Pollock immediately set to work to rebuild the city, using his business acumen and philanthropy to invest in the recovery efforts.

In addition to his work in recovery, Pollock also focused on improving the state's transportation systems. He was a strong advocate of the Boston and Maine Railroad, which ultimately became a major success due to his leadership.

After his term as Mayor, Pollock continued to serve in the Massachusetts House of Representatives from 1871 to 1873. He was known for his advocacy of the Boston and Maine Railroad and his work in promoting the interests of his home city and state.

Francis Pollock passed away in Boston in 1886. He was remembered as a successful businessman and a devoted public servant, who used his wealth and influence to improve the lives of the people of Boston and Massachusetts.

Roslyn Atkinson (born 1952) is an Australian actress and television presenter. She was born in Adelaide, South Australia, and studied drama at the University of Western Sydney.

Atkinson's acting career began on stage with the National Theatre Company of Australia before moving to television. Her first major role was as Sarah Reeves in the popular soap opera Neighbours from 1986 to 1987. She later appeared in several other successful TV series including Prisoners of Grace, Blue Heelers, All Saints, and Home and Away.

In addition to her work in television, Atkinson has also had a successful film career. She starred alongside Russell Crowe in The Crossing in 1990, and played the lead role in the critically acclaimed film Little Women in 1994. In recent years, she has appeared in several independent films including The Last Dance and The Secret Life of Walter Mitty.

As well as her acting career, Atkinson is also known for her work as a television presenter. She hosted the children's program Play School from 1993 to 1996, and has since presented several other educational programs for young children.

Throughout her career, Atkinson has been widely praised for her talent and dedication to her craft. She has won numerous awards and nominations for both her acting and presenting work, including two Logie Awards for Best Actress and Best Presenter.

Roy Grounds (1892-1979) was an Australian architect, landscape architect, and urban planner. He is best known for designing the Royal Canberra Golf Club and the Sydney Opera House, but his work also includes prominent houses, churches, universities, and shopping centres. He won numerous awards and honours for his designs, and his work is widely admired for its elegance, grandeur, and functional efficiency.

Early life and education

Roy Grounds was born in Adelaide, South Australia on 15 May 1892. His father was a prominent architect and builder, and his mother was a successful artist. From an early age, Grounds displayed a genius for drawing and design, and he studied architecture at the University of Adelaide before moving to London to learn from some of the world's most renowned architects.

Career

Roy Grounds began his career as an architect in South Australia but soon moved to London, where he worked for several prominent architects, including Charles Moore and Reginald Blomfield. He gained recognition for his designs, particularly for the Royal Canberra Golf Club, which he won an international competition in 1927. The club's elegant stone and brick buildings and lush landscaping have become iconic landmarks in the Australian capital.

After returning to Australia, Grounds continued to work on a variety of projects, including houses, churches, universities, and shopping centres. His designs are notable for their use of natural materials, functional efficiency, and attention to detail. Among his most famous works are the Sydney Opera House, which he won an international competition in 1957, and the Seymour Centre for Performing Arts, which he designed in 1966.

The Battle of Jutland, fought on 27 May 1916, was a major naval battle of World War I between the British Royal Navy and the German Kaiserliche Marine. The battle took place off the coast of Jutland in Denmark and was one of the largest naval battles of the war.

British naval forces, under the command of Admiral Sir John Jellicoe, were attempting to intercept a German convoy bound for Sweden when they encountered German forces, under the command of Vice Admiral Reinhard Scheer, off the coast of Jutland. Both sides were attempting to lure the other into a larger battle.

In the early stages of the battle, several naval groups on both sides became separated, leading to confusion and delays. At one point, Jellicoe's flagship, HMS Iron Duke, was attacked by several German torpedo boats, but was able to evade their attacks.

As the battle progressed, reinforcements arrived on both sides, and the fighting became more intense. Late in the afternoon, the German forces launched a massive torpedo attack on the British navy, which were able to defend themselves against the majority of the attacks.

The battle ended in a victory for the British forces, although the German forces suffered fewer casualties and were able to retire to port. The battle was considered a success for the German forces, as they had been able to inflict the most damage on the British navy.

Overall, the Battle of Jutland was a significant naval battle of World War I, and demonstrated the importance of naval warfare in the conflict. The battle also had a significant impact on the outcome of the war, as it forced the German navy to retreat to port, leaving the British with domination of the seas in the North Sea.

Ed Vargo (born 1963) is an American entrepreneur and businessman. He is best known as the founder and CEO of EcoMotors International, Inc., which produces electric motor technology for hybrid vehicles.

Early life and education

Vargo was born in Detroit, Michigan, United States. He attended Eastern Michigan University, where he earned a Bachelor of Science degree in Electrical Engineering in 1985.

Career

After graduating from college, Vargo worked at General Motors for several years before starting his own company, EcoMotors International, Inc., in 2004. The company's mission is to develop and produce high-performance electric motors that can be used in hybrid vehicles. In 2007, EcoMotors received $1 million in funding from the U.S. Department of Energy to further develop its electric motor technology.

In addition to his work with EcoMotors, Vargo has also been involved in various other ventures. He co-founded GreenTech Automotive, LLC, which aims to develop and manufacture electric cars using EcoMotors' electric motor technology. He has also served on the board of directors of several companies, including Electric Power Systems Corporation and Advanced Micro Devices.

Personal life

Vargo is married and has two children. He resides in Ann Arbor, Michigan.

Joseph Flom (born 1941) is an American lawyer and businessman. He is a partner at the law firm Latham & Watkins and serves as its leader. Flom has been consistently ranked as one of the most influential lawyers in the United States by numerous organizations.

Flom was born in New York City and received his Bachelor of Arts degree from Columbia University in 1963. In 1966, he received his Juris Doctor degree from Columbia Law School.

Flom began his career as an associate at the law firm Davis, Polk & Wardwell. He later became a partner at the law firm of Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom. He worked at Skadden for 47 years before joining Latham & Watkins in 2008 as a partner. In 2010, Flom became one of the two managing partners of Latham & Watkins, along with William H. Robinson. In 2016, he replaced Robinson as the sole managing partner of the law firm.

Flom is highly regarded for his experience in mergers and acquisitions, securities, and private equity dealings. He has been ranked as one of the top corporate and mergers and acquisitions lawyers in the United States by Chambers Global, a third-party rating agency. Flom has also been ranked as one of the most powerful people in the world by Bloomberg Businessweek.

Flom is a fellow of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences and a member of the Council on Foreign Relations. He has served on several other boards of directors, including the board of directors of the New York University School of Law.

Flom is known for his philanthropic work. He has donated large sums of money to various organizations, including the University of Chicago Medicine and the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. In 2009, he donated $10 million to the University of Chicago Medicine, which was used to build a new neuroscience institute.

Italianate architecture is an architectural style that emerged in Northern Italy during the Renaissance and subsequently spread throughout Europe. It is characterized by symmetrical facades, steeply pitched roofs, large windows with flat arches, classical orders, pilasters, pediments and entablatures.

The style originated in the city of Florence in the 14th and 15th centuries, where Romanesque houses were renovated to give them a more modern look. This new style was called "Florentine" or "renaissance," meaning "rebirth." In the early 20th century, it became popular again, especially in America, and was often used for urban planning.

Its use can be seen at the University of Bologna, where its iconic Library Archiginnasio building features elements of this revivalist style. The exterior has tall columns with pedimental crowns and a clock tower with four faces and bronze bells. Other notable examples include Statoil House in Norway and Palazzo Molteni in London.

This architectural trend continued into the Baroque period, when other decorative elements such as curved balustrades, domed ceilings, cornices, and illusionistic frescoes were added to make buildings even more grandiose.

In summary, Italianate architecture is a historical style that emerged in Northern Italy during the Renaissance and evolved over time until it reached its peak in the Baroque era. Its main characteristics are symmetrical facades, steeply pitched roofs, large windows with complex arches and intricate stonework, drawing inspiration from ancient Roman architecture.

Isaac Barr is a professional basketball player from the United States. He was born in 1995 and raised in Minneapolis, Minnesota. Barr began playing basketball at a young age and quickly became one of the top players in his age group. After high school, he went on to play basketball at the collegiate level, where he excelled and gained recognition as a top talent.

After college, Barr went on to play professionally in Europe, where he quickly made a name for himself as a standout player. He played for several different teams over the years, but most notably for a team in Italy.

Barr's skills as a basketball player are second-to-none, and he is widely regarded as one of the best players in the world. He is a versatile player who can score from anywhere on the court, and he has a reputation for being a clutch player in big moments.

Emi Sakura (Japanese: 酒々エミ; born December 5, 1986) is a Japanese actress and model. She rose to fame as an idol group member of Hi-IDOL! which was later renamed Hello! Project Pink from 2003 until their disbandment in 2007, after 4 years of activity. During her time with the group she released several well received singles such as "The Beginning" (2004), and starred in many popular drama series including Hikaru no Senaka and Tokumei Densetsu Reimeisen ("Mystery of the Cylindrical Transportation Device").

After leaving Hello! Project Pink Sakura has continued her acting career appearing in many dramas both television and film including Yūgen Sandaika (2008) in which she played Nanako Noda, a yakuza daughter who falls for a rival gangster's son, and Higashi no Eden (2009) playing Akio Kamata's love interest Kaori Aoshima. In addition, she also appeared in various commercials as well as hosting programs for Japanese variety channels including Oha Koko! from GTV and Music Bank on KBS2 among others.

In October 2013, it was announced that Sakura would be joining the cast for Tsurugaoka Art Museum's musical production of Cinderella. She would portray the leading character, Ella, alongside Shinichi Tsuda who would play Prince Henry. The show ran from November 8-24, 2013 and proved extremely successful selling out all tickets throughout its run and becoming the highest grossing event ever hosted by the museum.

Sakura currently continues to act in dramas and appear at events while also pursuing other interests such as fashion design and music.

Edward Blum is an American litigant known for filing high-profile cases in the United States that have affected issues such as voting rights, school prayer, and affirmative action. He has been involved in several landmark legal battles, including Shelby County v. Holder and Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin.

In 2013, Blum filed a lawsuit against the Department of Justice challenging Section 5 of the Voting Rights Act, arguing that it unfairly targeted states with largely white voter rolls which were not experiencing widespread voter discrimination. The case was ultimately decided by the Supreme Court, ruling in Blum's favor and striking down the section.

Blum also challenged the constitutionality of affirmative action policies in higher education through the Fisher v. University of Texas at Austin case. In this case, he argued on behalf of Abigail Fisher, who had applied to the university but was denied admission due to her race. After going through multiple appeals, the Supreme Court upheld UT's admissions policy in its 2016 decision, finding it did not discriminate against non-Hispanic applicants. However, in June 2020, the court ruled in two other affirmative action cases that universities may need to be more transparent about their criteria and be forced to consider individual students rather than racial or ethnic groups.

Most recently, Blum has filed another legal challenge titled Espinoza v. Torres Ramirez, where he seeks to eliminate the requirement that religious institutions must receive federal funds in order to participate government programs. This case challenges California’s AB 844, which prevents religious schools from applying for state education grants or receiving taxpayer money towards facility modernization or repair costs unless they allow all enrolled students regardless of religion, sexual orientation, gender identity, disability status, and national origin to partake in any course or program offered.

Overall, Edward Blum's legal activism has consistently sought to advocate for equal treatment under the law without regard to race or gender, drawing criticism from some groups as disruptive to longstanding social justice initiatives.

Forensic entomology is the application of scientific knowledge of insects to the investigation of crimes, especially those involving death. It is a subfield of forensic science and entomology, the study of insects. Forensic entomologists use insects as biological indicators to help determine the time of death of a deceased person, the cause of death, and the identity of the victim.

Insects are attracted to decomposing organic matter, and their life cycles are closely tied to the decomposition process. By studying the species, stage, and abundance of insects found on or near a body, forensic entomologists can provide valuable information about the time of death. For example, the presence of maggots indicates that decomposition has begun, and the type of maggot can help determine the time of death.

Forensic entomologists can also use insects to help determine the cause of death. For example, the presence of certain insects, such as blowflies, can indicate that the victim died from asphyxiation, while the presence of certain beetles can indicate that the victim died from ingesting poison.

In addition to providing information about the time of death and the cause of death, forensic entomologists can also use insects to help identify the victim. Insects are attracted to certain types of bodies, and the species and abundance of insects found on a body can help identify the victim. For example, the presence of certain types of beetles can indicate that the victim was a farmer or a person who worked with livestock.

Forensic entomology is a relatively new field, and it is still being developed. However, it has already proven to be a valuable tool in the investigation of crimes involving death. Forensic entomologists work closely with other forensic scientists, such as pathologists and odontologists, to provide a complete picture of the death and the victim.

Sociocultural evolution is the gradual process by which human societies change over time due to various internal and external factors. This concept was first introduced by anthropologist Edward Tylor, who proposed that cultures evolve through an accumulation of knowledge, technology, customs, and institutions.

There are several key models used to understand sociocultural evolution:

1. Modernization theory: This model posits that societies become more complex and modern over time as they adopt new technologies, values, and practices from more advanced societies. It suggests that cultural change is driven primarily by economic growth and development.
2. Functionalism: According to functionalist theory, every aspect of culture serves a specific purpose in maintaining social order and cohesion. Therefore, changes in culture must be understood within their broader role in supporting the functioning of society.
3. Conflict theory: This approach emphasizes the role of power imbalances and conflict in shaping social change. Social movements and activism can drive cultural transformations by challenging prevailing power structures and creating opportunities for marginalized groups to gain greater representation and agency.
4. Network analysis: By studying relationships between people, organizations, and ideas, network analysts identify patterns of influence and diffusion that shape cultural evolution. This approach highlights how ideas travel across networks, sometimes via formal channels like markets or religions, and other times through informal connections among friends, family members, or colleagues.
5. Agent-based modeling: This computational method simulates individual agents interacting with one another over time to study emergent behaviors at various scales, including those related to sociocultural evolution. Agent-based simulations allow researchers to test alternative hypotheses about how cultural traits spread and adapt under different conditions.
6. Cultural materialism: Anthony Giddens's theory proposes that cultural change arises out of contradictions within social systems, particularly those related to production and reproduction. His work stresses that cultural transformation often occurs when existing modes of societal organization break down or encounter limits.
7. Symbolic interactionism: Founded by Max Weber

Waldshut-Tiengen is a town in Baden-Württemberg, Germany. It lies on the right bank of the Rhine River and has a population of approximately 40,000 people. The town was first mentioned in documents from 1235 as "Viltesheim" or "Wildeshaim." Over time, it grew into an important center for trade and industry, particularly during the Middle Ages when it became a major producer of wool and cloth.

During the Renaissance period, Waldshut-Tiengen was known for its beautiful architecture, including several churches and castles that still stand today. One of the most famous landmarks in the town is the Waldshut Castle, which dates back to the 12th century and was once home to several German kings and emperors. Another popular attraction is the Church of St. Martin, which features stunning stained glass windows and intricate carvings.

In addition to its rich history, Waldshut-Tiengen also offers plenty of modern amenities and attractions. The town is located near several national parks, making it a great destination for outdoor enthusiasts. There are also several museums and galleries in the area, showcasing the region's art and culture.

Overall, Waldshut-Tiengen is a charming and historic town with much to offer visitors. Whether you're interested in exploring its fascinating past or enjoying its many modern attractions, this is definitely a place worth visiting.

Michael Sayman is an American politician and businessman who currently serves as the Florida Secretary of State. He was previously a member of the Maryland House of Delegates, representing District 28A in Prince George's County from 2015 to 2021. As a member of the Democratic Party, he caucused with both Progressives and Blue Dog Democrats.

Early life and education

Sayman was born on July 30, 1975, in Washington D.C., the son of Elizabeth (Rabinowitz) and Daniel Sayman of the Haredi Jewish community.[1] His father is originally from Ethiopia while his mother is of Russian-Jewish descent. He attended Beth David Ner Amon Synagogue[citation needed]. He received his undergraduate degree from Princeton University in Computer Science and a Master of Business Administration from Georgetown University.[2]

Legislative career

Murphy following his 2010 election to lieutenant governor and subsequent reelection to that office in 2014.[3] Two years later, he won reelection to a two-year term, defeating three other candidates in the primary election with 64% of the vote.[4],[5] After redistricting for the 2022 legislative session, Sayman found himself in newly designated District 28B which included areas of Charles County, Southern Anne Arundel County, Annapolis City limits, Solomon’s Island City Limits and parts of Crownsville, Gambo’s Landing, Lothian, Old Mill Village Community Improvement Association boundaries, Shady Grove East, Westmoreland Manor and Waugh Chapel Crossroads CDU as well as Waugh Chapel. Let's Get Skase is an American television show that first aired on Nickelodeon in 2013. The show follows the adventures of two best friends, Max and Jake, as they navigate their way through middle school while trying to avoid getting into trouble with their parents and teachers.

The show was created by Dan Schneider, who also created Zoey 101 and iCarly. It stars Max Irons and Jake T. Austin as Max and Jake respectively, along with Kelli Marissa as Emily, Jillian Rose Reed as Lucy, and Cody Linley as Tyler.

Each episode typically features Max and Jake coming up with schemes or ideas to have fun, but things always go wrong when they are caught by their parents or teachers. They often try to cover up their mistakes by lying or using fake identities.

Despite its popularity among young viewers, Let's Get Skase has been criticized for promoting reckless behavior and poor decision-making skills. Some critics argue that the show glorifies breaking rules and disobedience, which can lead to negative consequences in real life.

Nevertheless, Let's Get Skase remains a popular choice for many young people who enjoy watching the antics of Max and Jake. The show continues to air on Nickelodeon and has spawned several spin-offs and merchandise lines.

Habib Bourguiba (24 August 1903 – 30 August 2004) was a Tunisian politician who served as the first President of Tunisia from 1957 to 1985. He is widely regarded as the founder of modern Tunisia and played a key role in the country's independence from French colonial rule.

Bourguiba was born in Kairouan, Tunisia, in 1903. He studied law at the Sorbonne in Paris and returned to Tunisia in 1929 to practice law. In 1934, he founded the Destourian Movement, which aimed to unite the Arab world and fight against colonialism.

During World War II, Bourguiba was arrested by the Vichy regime and imprisoned in a labor camp in France. After the war, he returned to Tunisia and continued to lead the Destourian Movement. In 1952, he was elected as the first president of the Tunisian Republic.

Under Bourguiba's leadership, Tunisia underwent a period of rapid modernization and development. The country adopted a new constitution, established a multi-party system, and began to diversify its economy. Bourguiba also played a key role in the country's foreign policy, establishing diplomatic relations with other African countries and promoting Tunisia's membership in the United Nations.

In 1964, Bourguiba suffered a stroke and was forced to step down as president. He continued to play a role in Tunisian politics, however, and was elected as president for life in 1974. In 1981, he was again forced to step down due to health issues, and was succeeded by Zine El Abidine Ben Ali.

Bourguiba died in 2004 at the age of 101. He is remembered as a key figure in Tunisian history and as a champion of African unity and independence.

Quassia (/kæsjæ/; from the Greek κασία, kasia, meaning "brushwood") is a genus of flowering plants in the family Simarinaceae. These plants are native to the Americas, and are commonly known as "quassia trees" or "quassia wood". They are characterized by their distinctive aromatic oils, which are used in various traditional medicinal and culinary applications.

There are two species of quassia trees: Quassia amabilis and Quassia indica. Quassia amabilis is native to Central and South America, while Quassia indica is native to the Caribbean and South America. Both species are widely distributed throughout the region, and have been introduced to other parts of the world, including Africa, Asia, and the Pacific Islands.

Quassia trees are medium-sized trees that can grow up to 20 meters (66 ft) tall. They have a straight trunk, with a wide, spreading crown, and are covered in small, oval-shaped leaves. The flowers of quassia trees are small and white, and are borne on clusters that form on the ends of the branches. The fruit of quassia trees is a small, round berry that is typically red or yellow in color.

The most important feature of quassia trees is their distinctive aromatic oils, which are extracted from the bark, leaves, and flowers. These oils have a strong, pungent smell, and are used in various traditional medicinal and culinary applications. In traditional medicine, quassia oil is used to treat a variety of ailments, including digestive problems, skin conditions, and insect bites. In culinary applications, quassia oil is used as a flavoring agent, and is often used in the preparation of traditional dishes in the Caribbean and South America.

In addition to their medicinal and culinary uses, quassia trees also have a number of other important uses. The wood of quassia trees is highly valued for its durability and resistance to insects, and is used in the construction of furniture, boats, and other wooden structures. The bark of quassia trees is also used to make a natural dye, which is used to color textiles

Hitman: Contracts is a 2004 stealth-action video game developed and published by IO Interactive for PlayStation 2, Xbox, and Microsoft Windows. It is the fourth entry in the Hitman series and was directed by Richard Devine and produced by Paul Purdy alongside Jason Dooley. The game features an improved AI system that reacts to player actions based on risk assessment algorithms, allowing for deeper levels of immersion while engaging in contract completions.

The storyline follows Agent 47 after he has completed his assassination mission in Prague where he narrowly escapes capture by police forces. Recovering from his injuries, he agrees to take up an assignment involving killing three targets by using new methods. Each target represents one of three classes or factions within the hitman world – mafia, government, and crime cartels – each with its own unique set of enemies, agents, markers, weapons, and minigames. Moreover, some of these missions take place in exotic yet dangerous locations such as Sokovia, Istanbul, Argentina, Shanghai, Paris, Malta, Chicago, Sanzha Island (Mauritania), Miami (United States), Budapest, Corsica, India, Omsk (Russia) and Prague (Czech Republic). Aside from various targets, players are also tasked to complete various challenges known as "mini-games," which are integral to the assassinations; they can range from shooting to wielding melee weapons or even disguising oneself.

"The original, though now somewhat uncommon, method of vibration cooking involved the use of two sheets of metal connected by an electromagnet, which generates energy through electromagnetic induction. By cooking a metal container of food which contains a metal object, the magnet could vibrate the container over a hot flame. A more modern method uses a device similar to a stove top, but with a magnetic metal plate which absorbs energy through induction. This method is preferred to the original, because in the original, induction can only occur through contact with the metal plate — when the container is moved, the object contained within cannot, and must still be heated by contact.
In the late 1980s and 1990s, a variety of companies marketed a vibration cooking device that consisted of two metal plates connected by a series of magnets which vibrated at ultrasonic frequencies. An electrically conductive vessel, usually of aluminum, was placed between the plates, which caused energy to be induced into the vessel by inductive heating. This method was promoted for its ability to "cook faster and healthier."
The FDA evaluated the safety and effectiveness of the device and concluded in August 2003 that the device has no significant benefit over conventional cooking methods."[3] This finding followed an earlier review conducted in 1999, shortly after the device was first marketed. The FDA's 1999 report states in part, "... FDA conducted a literature search to determine the scientific validity of the benefits claimed for ultrasonic vibration cooking. Our search revealed no evidence... demonstrating that these [or any other] alternative cooking claims... are scientifically valid"[4]

"Transonic flight, sometimes called supercritical aerodynamics, is the flight regime of an aircraft whose current velocity lies in between the Mach number and sound speed (Mach 1.0 and the speed of sound), where sonic effects influence flight dynamics beyond the Mach disc. [.....]
Flight at transonic speeds poses challenges to aircraft design. To control shocks effectively, designers can shape the wings (using techniques that involve moving the shock waves away from the wing's leading edge) and can equip the airframe with shock absorbers to dissipate the energy of the shock without damaging the aircraft. William Dougherty (born August 15, 1953) is an American composer, conductor, and pianist.
Dougherty was born in New York City. He studied at the Juilliard School, where he received a Bachelor of Music degree in 1975 and a Master of Music degree in 1977. He also studied at the University of Michigan, where he received a Doctor of Musical Arts degree in 1981.
Dougherty's compositions include works for orchestra, chamber ensemble, and solo instruments. He has also written music for film and television.
Dougherty has received numerous awards and honors, including a Guggenheim Fellowship, a Fulbright Fellowship, and a grant from the National Endowment for the Arts. He has also been a resident composer at the MacDowell Colony and the Yaddo artists' community.
Dougherty has taught at several universities, including the University of Michigan, the University of California, Los Angeles, and the University of Southern California. He is currently a professor of composition at the University of California, Santa Barbara.
Dougherty has conducted numerous orchestras, including the Los Angeles Philharmonic, the New York Philharmonic, and the San Francisco Symphony. He has also served as music director of the Santa Barbara Symphony.
Dougherty has recorded several of his own compositions, as well as works by other composers. He has also appeared as a pianist on several recordings.
Dougherty is married to the composer and pianist Margaret Brouwer. They have two children, William and Elizabeth.

Peter Fredrik Schmeichel (Danish: [ˈpæˀteː ˈˌskmæicəl]; born 5 January 1963) is a former Danish footballer who played as a goalkeeper. Born in Gladsaxe, Schmeichel made his debut with Hvidovre IF at the advanced age of twenty-six and was the starting goalkeeper for the Danish national team for over a decade, winning the 1992 European Footballer of the Year award. He spent the bulk of his career playing with several top European clubs and is the current goalkeeping coach for Fulham.
A product of the Brøndby IF academy, Schmeichel played for various teams in the lower tiers of Danish football until 1988, but did not see a single league action for Brøndby until 1990. He was soon sold on to Manchester United, in time to win the 1991 FA Cup. He helped United win the Premier League in 1993 and 1994, the FA Cup in 1994 and 1995, and the FA Community Shield in 1991, 1992, 1993 and 1994. In 1997, he left to play for A.C. Milan before moving on to Sporting CP and Manchester City in 2000 and 2006, respectively. In his second stint at City, he won the Football League Cup and made it to a League Cup final with Sunderland in 2009. He continued his career in the US, playing for LA Galaxy and Toronto from 2009 until 2010. He returned to Manchester City as a goalkeeping coach in late 2010; he has also played as a goalkeeper in the Danish Superliga, the English Premier League and the Football League Championship until 2010.
Schmeichel started his football career with Brøndby IF's youth academy in 1977, but did not make his senior debut until 1988. His first appearance in "the orange" was on 18 June 1988 against SønderjyskE where he was subbed in just past the half-way mark. In the four season from 1988 to 1992 he only saw four league games. His first league goal came on 31 May 1992 against Randers Freja, although he conceded five other goals.
On 10 August 1990, with Brøndby facing liquidation, he joined Manchester United for a reported fee of £1.2million. This would change Schmeichel's fortunes

Dmitry Koptur (born 2 July 1980) is a Russian former cyclist.
Koptur competed in two events at the 2004 Summer Olympics.
Koptur's brother, Pavel, was also a cyclist and the 2007 national road race champion. [1]
A Russian cycling team was in the news in 2016. It was named Katusha Team.
Katusha is the name of a female Russian folk deity. The Russian term "katyusha" is also used to refer to any girl or young woman in a flirtatious way. The Russian word "Katusha" (English: "Katusha") is an affectionate diminutive of "Katarina" (Russian: "Katerina").

Chih-Tang Sah (born in Taiwan, Republic of China) is a Taiwanese-American computer scientist and professor at the University of California, Berkeley. He is known for his work in the area of computer architecture, including the design of the Berkeley RISC processor, the Berkeley MIPS processor, and the Berkeley Out-of-Order processor. He is also known for his work in the area of computer-aided design, including the development of the Berkeley Design Automation System (BDAS).
Sah received his B.S. degree in electrical engineering from National Taiwan University in 1973, and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in electrical engineering and computer science from the University of California, Berkeley in 1975 and 1978, respectively. He joined the faculty of the University of California, Berkeley in 1978, where he is currently a professor of electrical engineering and computer science.
Sah is a member of the National Academy of Engineering, a fellow of the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers, and a fellow of the Association for Computing Machinery. He has received numerous awards, including the IEEE Computer Society Charles Babbage Award, the ACM/IEEE Eckert-Mauchly Award, the ACM/IEEE Turing Award, and the ACM/IEEE Harry H. Goode Memorial Award.
Sah is the author of over 200 papers and has been granted over 50 patents. He is also the co-author of the book "Computer Architecture: A Quantitative Approach" (Morgan Kaufmann, 3rd edition, 2006).
Sah is married to fellow computer scientist and professor at the University of California, Berkeley, Barbara Liskov. They have two children, a son and a daughter.

Stephen West was a British graphic designer who worked with many top advertising agencies in the 1960s and 1970s. He is acknowledged as one of the founding fathers of the Creative Revolution, the term usually given to the period between the late 1960s and early 1980s when creativity became a key element of advertising. West was the first art director for Colin Forbes in his agency, the now defunct Colin Forbes & Partners. Some time after the agency closed, West and Forbes formed the Stephen West Group. Other notable ads include the famous British Telecom ‘Symphony’, the Guinness ‘toucan’, the British Airways ‘performing flamingos’ and the Cadbury’s ‘gorilla’.
West joined the J Walter Thompson (JWT) agency, working for David Ogilvy, and then, briefly, to the Michael Peters Group.
He was a partner in the famous Collett Dickenson Pearce (CDP) agency. Here his work was highly acclaimed internationally, winning many international awards, including a gold in Cannes for his series of posters for British Rail featuring the 'Guinness Toucan'. Later, at Ketchum, another advertising agency, his 'British Airways Dancing Flamingos' won two gold awards in Cannes, and the famous 'Nationwide Building Society 'Gorilla' campaign also won a gold.
Thereafter he moved to Saatchi & Saatchi. Later, after a spell as deputy chairman of Lowe Lintas, he founded the Stephen West Group in 1992 with partner Janey Lowe, which was finally sold to TBWA London in 2000.

Kristina Wagner (born March 16, 1962) is an American film and television actress best known as Nikki Maroser on CBS' The Bold and the Beautiful from 1991 to 2002, which was the second longest span for anyone to play a single character in the series' history (behind Kimberlin Brown as Sheila Carter from 1987-1997). She was the second actress to play the character of Nikki, the first one being Darlene Conley who played the role from the series debut in 1977 (Conley returned in 1986, as Nikki's twin sister, Alexandra Maroser, and played the role for another two years). After leaving the series, Wagner appeared in a number of low-budget films. She starred in the movie The Right One opposite actor Bruce Abbott in the lead role. She also portrayed a young female tennis champion, opposite Michael York in the comedy-drama, Aces. Kristina Wagner is the younger sister of actress, Natalie Wood.
Kristina Wagner is sometimes credited as Kristina Woods. She got her start in television as Gwyneth "Gwynn" Paltrow, the new love interest for the title character on the sitcom, "Kate & Allie".

K.S.K. Ronse is a Belgian football club based in Ronse, East Flanders. The club was founded in 1909 and currently plays in the Belgian Second Division.

History

The club was founded in 1909 as R.C. de Football Club Ronse. In the early years, the club played in the provincial leagues. In the 1930s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the East Flanders. In the 1950s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the West Flanders. In the 1960s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the East Flanders. In the 1970s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the West Flanders. In the 1980s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the East Flanders. In the 1990s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the West Flanders. In the 2000s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the East Flanders. In the 2010s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the West Flanders. In the 2020s, the club was promoted to the provincial leagues of the East Flanders.

Habib Bourguiba (Arabic: حبيب بورقيبة‎, IPA: [ħabiːb burˈqijba]) (11 January 1903 – 6 April 2000) was a Tunisian politician and statesman who served as the first President of Tunisia, from 1957 until 1987, as well as leader of the Neo Destour political party that later ruled the country. Upon independence in 1956, he was chosen as the first president of Tunisia and led the new country to one-party rule. He was credited with establishing an independent legal system for the new nation and in the late 1960s also promoted Islamic values in order to strengthen his position. He was ousted in a 1987 coup d'état after a twenty-one-year rule.
Habib Bourguiba at age five.
Habib Bourguiba was born in Métouia, in the region of Tunis. His father was Abu-Bekr Ben Abdallah, a Tunisian farmer, and his mother was a woman from the local area named Zohra. Bourguiba lived in a small village known as Sidi Kharraz. Although not from the family of Arab slave origin, the Bourguiba family is seen as one from Berber descent. There were five other children besides Bourguiba: a younger brother, Ahmed, and a younger sister, Fatma. His older brother Mohamed was assassinated by a French Army officer in the streets of Métouia.
In addition to his Islamic studies, Bourguiba attended the French lycée in El Kef, Tunisia, and in 1921 entered the University of Carthage Law School in Tunis. He was educated in the principles of European democracy by a French lawyer friend, and studied jurisprudence under a French professor, Pierre Gaudant, who also taught Habib Abdelaziz, the future prime minister of Tunisia.
Bourguiba was an opponent of the French colonisation of his country, which began in 1881 and reached a peak after the conquest of southern Tunisia in 1881. A nationalist movement was formed in Tunisia to oppose colonisation, and Bourguiba joined it in 1936 when he formed the Neoproudhonist Marxist group, a Tunisian section of the International Revolutionary

Deglaciation
One result of deglaciation is that formerly subglacial water now resides in the terrestrial environment. These waters constitute a potential source of fresh water in areas close to glaciers and ice sheets, and also contribute to the ocean surface freshwater budget in regions as far as Antarctica. For example, the Greenland ice sheet is the largest single contributor to sea-level rise, because of its large surface area and slow response to environmental change.
In addition to the above changes to the freshwater cycle, deglaciation affects weather patterns in some regions, particularly in northern Europe and North America. As glaciers withdraw, atmospheric pressure increases in some regions due to removal of the weight of the ice. An example is "glacier fever" or "glacier flu", which has been attributed to the abrupt and large-scale loss of glacial ice. At the same time, an increase of cloud cover and precipitation may occur, with the rain carrying high amounts of the suspended glacial dust which is carried down into the lowlands and deposited by the rain.

Botswana–China relations are the foreign relations between the landlocked Republic of Botswana and the People's Republic of China. Botswana's relations with China are part of the broader Sino-African relations. China has an embassy in Gaborone.[1] Botswana has an embassy in Beijing, and consulates in Guangzhou and Hong Kong.[2]

The Republic of China under President Chiang Kai-shek established diplomatic relations with Botswana in August 1965, and the People's Republic of China (PRC) established diplomatic relations in November 1975.[1] Botswana severed relations with the Republic of China, and transferred those ties to the PRC as of December 3, 1975.[1]

Bilateral trade between China and Botswana was valued at $1.02 billion in 2010.[3] More than 2,000 Chinese businesspeople and traders reside in Botswana as of 2013.[2]

People's Republic of China-Botswana relations

Development assistance 
The PRC is Botswana's largest source of development assistance.[2] In the early 2000s Botswana's government, under president Festus Mogae, was keen to attract development aid from China "to replace any aid it might lose as a result of pressure from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to cut government spending".[4] In 2002 Mogae visited China to attend the Sino-African summit, and in his subsequent government budget speech he singled out China as Botswana's main development aid donor, which was a source of domestic controversy. The Botswanan government subsequently adopted a policy of seeking balanced development assistance from multiple partners,[5] and the PRC has largely refrained from overt interference in Botswana's internal affairs.[6] Development assistance from China is more in the form of infrastructure and investment, rather than humanitarian aid.[7][5]

Infrastructure construction has formed the bulk of the PRC's economic and commercial investment in the country, which amounted to $100 million in the three years leading up to 2005.[8][7] The bilateral trade agreement reached during Chinese leader Hu Jintao's state visit in 2005 committed China to providing more than $350 million in loan financing for a planned railway,
