Brian Schmetzer is an American soccer coach who has had extensive experience in both domestic and international leagues. He was born on February 12, 1963, in Tacoma, Washington, where he grew up playing for local youth teams before going on to play college soccer at Simon Fraser University in British Columbia, Canada. After graduating with a degree in business administration, Schmetzer began his coaching career with various amateur and semi-professional clubs in the Pacific Northwest region.

In 1999, Brian Schmetzer became assistant coach for the Seattle Sounders of the USL First Division, under head coach Chris Henderson. The following year, when Henderson resigned midseason, Schmetzer took over as interim head coach and led the team to a playoff berth. Impressed by his performance, club management appointed him as permanent head coach for the 2001 season. Under Schmetzer's guidance, the Sounders won their first division title that year and went on to reach the conference finals of the playoffs.

Over the next several seasons, Schmetzer continued to lead the Sounders to postseason appearances while also developing young talent such as Fredy Montero and Osvaldo Alonso. In 2009, he guided the team to its first ever MLS Cup appearance, losing to Real Salt Lake in the final. Despite this setback, Schmetzer remained popular among fans and players alike for his positive attitude and tactical acumen.

After parting ways with the Sounders in 2010, Schmetzer spent two years as head coach of Swedish side Malmö FF, winning the league championship in his first season there. Upon returning to the United States, he served briefly as technical director for the Portland Timbers before being rehired by the Sounders in 2014. Over the next five seasons, he helped establish the franchise as one of the most successful in Major League Soccer, including leading them to their first MLS Cup victory in 2016.

Throughout his career, Brian Schmetzer has been known for his innovative tactics and ability to get the best out of his players. His success in both domestic and international leagues has earned him widespread respect within the soccer community, and he remains a beloved figure in Seattle sports history. Off the field, Schmetzer has been involved in numerous charitable initiatives focused on promoting health and fitness in underserved communities.

Bartholomew Frere (1590-1634) was an English merchant and explorer who is best known for his travels to the northern regions of Russia and his involvement in the founding of the English colony of Connecticut.

Frere was born in London to a wealthy merchant family and was educated at Cambridge University. In 1612, he joined the Muscovy Company, a British trade corporation that had a monopoly on English trade with Russia. Over the next several years, he made several trips to the Russian city of Archangel, where he engaged in trade and negotiated with local officials on behalf of the company.

In 1618, Frere became involved in the founding of the English colony of Connecticut, which was established by a group of Puritan settlers led by the Rev. Thomas Hooker. Frere provided financial support for the colony and helped to secure land for the settlers from the local Native American tribes. He also served as a member of the colony's governing council for several years.

In addition to his work in Connecticut, Frere continued to engage in trade with Russia, and in 1633 he led an expedition to explore the eastern coast of Siberia. Unfortunately, the expedition was plagued by difficulties, and Frere and his crew were forced to abandon their ships and undergo a dangerous overland journey to reach safety. Frere died the following year during a return voyage to England.

Frere's contributions to English exploration and commerce were significant, and his legacy continues to be celebrated in his native England as well as in the United States. Several places in Connecticut are named in his honor, including the town of Freestone and the Bartholomew Frere House, a historic home in New Haven that was built by one of his descendants.

Patty Loveless is an American country music singer and songwriter. Born in Pike County, Kentucky in 1957, she began her career in the mid-1980s as a duet partner with her husband, Emory Gordy Jr., before launching a successful solo career in the late 1980s.

Loveless's music is known for its traditional country sound, which draws heavily from the music of the Appalachian region where she grew up. Her vocals have been described as "powerful" and "heartfelt", and she is widely regarded as one of the greatest country singers of her generation.

Loveless has released a total of 17 studio albums, with many of her songs becoming country music standards. Her debut album, "If My Heart Had Windows", was released in 1988 and included the hit singles "Here I Am" and "Timber, I'm Falling in Love". She followed this with a string of successful albums, including "Patty Loveless", "On Your Way Home", and "Stampede", which featured the hit singles "Chains", "You Don't Even Know Who I Am", and "I Try to Think About Elvis".

In addition to her successful solo career, Loveless has also collaborated with other artists, including George Jones, Dwight Yoakam, and Alison Krauss. She has won numerous awards throughout her career, including the Country Music Association's Female Vocalist of the Year award in 1991 and the Academy of Country Music's Top Female Vocalist award in 1992.

Loveless has been praised for her traditional sound and her commitment to preserving the heritage of country music. She has been inducted into the Grand Ole Opry and the Kentucky Music Hall of Fame, and she continues to perform and record music to this day.

The Moskvitch 2140 is a Soviet compact car produced between 1963 and 1987. It was designed by the Moskvitch automobile plant and was the successor to the Moskvitch 412.

The 2140 was built with a unibody design and featured a 1.5-liter four-cylinder engine that produced around 50 horsepower. It had a top speed of around 100 km/h (62 mph) and could accommodate up to five passengers.

The 2140 was popular in the Soviet Union and was considered a reliable mode of transportation. It was also exported to other Eastern Bloc countries and was even assembled in China until the 1990s.

However, production of the 2140 ceased in 1987 due to the increasing demand for more modern and fuel-efficient vehicles. Today, the 2140 is a collector's item and can be seen in vintage car shows and parades.

Charles Edward Lindblom (1921-1994) was an American political scientist who made significant contributions to public administration and governance studies, particularly in relation to policymaking processes within democratic societies. Born on October 22nd, 1921, he grew up in Chicago before attending college at Northwestern University where he earned his undergraduate degree.[1] After serving as an officer during World War II,[2]Lindblom went on to obtain both master's[3]and doctoral degrees from HarvardUniversityin 1949 [4]. 

Throughout his academic career, CharlesE. Troy Grant is an American actor, director and producer. He was born on August 15, 1970 in Los Angeles, California. Troy began his career as an actor appearing in various television shows such as ER, The West Wing and NYPD Blue. In 2005, he made his feature film directing debut with the critically acclaimed Hustle & Flow which won him the Best Director Award at the Sundance Film Festival. The film also received multiple nominations including an Academy Award for Best Original Song. 

Grant has since directed several other films including Notorious, Acrimony and Nobody's Fool starring Tiffany Haddish. As a producer, some of his notable productions include Moonlight, Get Out and If Beale Street Could Talk. His work behind the camera has earned him numerous accolades throughout his career. 

Outside of filmmaking, Trojan is involved in philanthropic efforts focusing on education and mentorship programs aimed towards young people from underprivileged backgrounds. He serves as a board member for organizations that support arts education initiatives across the United States. 

In recognition of his contributions to the entertainment industry and charitable works, Mr. Grant been honored by many prestigious institutions over the years. Most notably being awarded the Humanitarian award at BET’s Black Girls Rock! Ceremony in 2017. 

As one of Hollywood most sought-after filmmakers today, it seems like there will be no slowing down anytime soon for this accomplished artist/entrepreneur who continues make impactful content while inspiring future generations creatives through his passion project initiative #RebelForChange.

Joseph William Foster (born March 15, 1985) is an American politician who has served as the 24th White House Chief of Staff since January 2023. Prior to his current position, he served as the 27th United States Secretary of State, from 2021 to 2023, and as the 28th United States Secretary of Defense, from 2017 to 2021.

Foster was born in Omaha, Nebraska, and grew up in a politically active family. After receiving a degree in political science from the University of Nebraska–Lincoln, he worked as an aide to several members of Congress before serving as the National Security Advisor to President Barack Obama from 2013 to 2017.

As Secretary of Defense, Foster implemented several reforms aimed at improving the efficiency and effectiveness of the Department of Defense. He also played a key role in shaping the administration's foreign policy, including its response to the Russian invasion of Ukraine and its efforts to negotiate a nuclear deal with Iran.

Foster was appointed Secretary of State in 2021, and quickly emerged as a key player in the administration's diplomacy. He played a central role in negotiating the Paris Agreement on Climate Change and the Iran Nuclear Deal, both of which were signed into law during his tenure. Foster was also instrumental in strengthening ties with key allies such as Japan and South Korea, and in building new partnerships with emerging powers such as India and China.

In January 2023, Foster was appointed White House Chief of Staff, replacing Mark Meadows. As Chief of Staff, Foster has been credited with bringing a sense of order and discipline to the West Wing, and with helping to shepherd through Congress several key pieces of legislation, including a major infrastructure bill and a comprehensive immigration reform package.

Foster is married to Dr. Jennifer Rashell, a physician and public health expert, and they have two children. In his spare time, Foster enjoys playing basketball and reading history books.

"Old Boys"[edit]

 The Old Boy Network, also referred to as the Elder's Club or Alumni Networks is an informal association consisting mostly of former students who maintain strong ties with their alma mater. These networks are usually formed by private schools and elite universities where graduates have access to considerable resources that allow them to stay connected through events such as reunions or social gatherings. 
 Often accused of being exclusive,[1](https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2017/jun/19/old-boy-network-elite) these groups often offer job opportunities exclusively for members which has fueled criticisms towards its existence.<ref name=":0">[https://webarchive.nationalarchives.gov.uk/+/http:/www.epsrc.ac.uk/newsevents/news/2013/Pages/alumninetworks.aspx Government investment in alumni networks]. Engineering & Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC). 20 November 2013.</ref> As it’s considered nepotism this phenomenon can be found across several sectors not only limited to education field, thus limiting diversification possibilities within certain areas of society.[2]
 

 
 Critics argue that old boy network perpetuates privilege on hereditary basis promoting mediocrity rather than meritocracy since people tend to hire individuals from similar backgrounds; therefore reducing diversity among employees while propelling homogeneity instead.[3][4]( https://hbr.org/) 
 There  are various studies suggesting positive correlation between diverse workforce and higher performance indicators[[5][6](https://hbswk.hbs.edu/item/why-diversity-matters)]. On contrary absence of variety hinders creativity leading to narrow perspectives consequently stagnating growth capabilities.
 
 Some governments took steps to mitigate presence of “old boys” clubs emphasizing fairness stating benefits brought about when everyone had chance regardless background [[7](ttps://assets.publishing.service.go)]. Despite those regulations existent lingering issue remains enforcing rules thereby encouraging trustful relationships based credibility founded prior connections strengthening influence already enjoyed inside circle<([8](https ://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1111/pops.12053))>. It leads challenging situation balancing interests preserving legacy benefactors ensuring neutrality indispensable maintaining respect universal principles justice equity."

Bhola Thapa is a Nepalese politician who served as Minister for Education, Science and Technology in Nepal from 2015 to 2017. He was appointed by Prime Minister Khadga Prasad Oli after the Communist Party of Nepal (Maoist Centre) and the United Marxist Leninist formed a government following the 2013 elections. 

Thapa had previously served as Deputy Mayor of Kathmandu Metropolitan City and was known for his work in education reform.[1] As minister, he oversaw several initiatives aimed at improving access to education and increasing investment in science and technology.[2][3] However, his tenure was marked by controversy,[4] including allegations of corruption[5] and disputes with teachers' unionsover educational reforms [6].

After leaving office, Thapa joined the facultyat Tribhuvan University where he teaches politicalscienceand public administration.[7]He also remains activein politics[,8]serving asthe Central Committee memberof theCommunistParty ofNepal(Unified Socialist).

Susan McCann is an American writer and editor, best known for her work in speculative fiction. Born on October 15, 1980, in Chicago, Illinois, she grew up in nearby Lombard and began writing stories at an early age. After studying English literature at DePaul University, she went on to pursue a career in publishing.

McCann's first published works were short stories appearing in various small press magazines and anthologies. She made her debut as a novelist with "<The Groves>", a dark fantasy novel set in a decaying estate haunted by malevolent supernatural forces. The book received positive reviews from critics who praised its atmospheric setting and creepy mood. It was followed by several other novels, including "</Noon>", which explores themes of memory and identity through the eyes of a woman suffering from chronic fragmented unilateral neglect, and "</Counted>", a horror story about a family terrorized by a sinister presence that manifests inside their home. Her latest publication "", consists of interconnected novellas exploring different interpretations of Hell.

Throughout her career, Susan McCann has won numerous awards for her fiction, including the Shirley Jackson Award, the Bram Stoker Award, and the Locus Award. In addition to her own writing, she has also worked as an acquisitions editor for various publishers such as ChiZine Publications and Prime Books. As an editor,she co-edited two critically acclaimed original anthology series: ","which showcase new voices in weird fiction, and,"," which feature unique takes on fairy tales and folklore. Currently she edits and publishes "" magazine, focused on showcasing diverse perspectives within genre fictions. 

When not working on her own books or editing others', Susan McCann teaches creative Writing workshops across America and delivers lectures regarding Horror Literature. Critics have described her style as evocative and disquieting. With distinct tones ranging from psychological suspense to all out cosmic horrors,her oeuvre expands what readers may expect Out Of Speculative Fiction Genre. Susan lives near Detroit, Michigan with husband Christopher Slatsky, artist, illustrator, comic maker, they together share love dogs named after famous scientists and writers.

William Charles Fahie (born 1952) is an attorney and politician who has served as Premier of the British Virgin Islands since 2019. He was first elected to the House of Assembly in the 1995 general election, representing the district of Tortola West. 

Fahie became Leader of the Opposition following the 1999 general election, which saw his National Democratic Party lose power to the United Progressive Party led by Ralph T. O'Neal. In the 2003 general election, he regained his seat in the House of Assembly and subsequently succeeded Orlando Smith as leader of the NDP. The NDP won a landslide victory in the 2007 general election, with Fahie becoming Premier for the first time. His government was defeated in the 2011 general election but returned to power in the 2015 general election.
 
As Premier, Fahie focused on economic development, tourism promotion, and hurricane recovery efforts. He also advocated for greater self-governance and autonomy for the British Virgin Islands within the wider UK overseas territories system. Despite some controversies and criticism during his tenure, Fahie remained popular among many voters and was reelected in the 2019 general election.
 
In 2020, Fahie faced impeachment proceedings over allegations of misconduct related to COVID-19 relief funds; however, he survived the attempt and remains in office as of 2021. He is widely regarded as one of the most influential political figures in the BVI and has been recognized for his contributions to public service both locally and regionally.

Born on September 15, 1964, in Toledo, Ohio, Klinger grew up with a passion for reading and writing, eventually earning a degree in English literature from the University of Michigan[1].

Klinger's professional writing career began in 1995 when she sold her first short story to _Astrology_ magazine.[2] Since then, she has published dozens of works across various publications including Analog Science Fiction and Fact, Asimov's Science Fiction, The Magazine of Fantasy & Science Fiction_, among others._Star Wars: The Clone Warsthe animated television series_, where she served as a consulting producer and writer. In addition to her accomplishments in prose writing and editing, Leslie Klinger has dabbled in screenwriting, most notably contributing to several episodes of HBO's hit show Game of Thrones during its fifth season. The term can also refer to the process by which migrants adapt to new environments and societies. Migration has been occurring throughout history but it gained increased attention in recent times due to globalization and political changes. This led to growth in research on this topic across various fields such as sociology, anthropology, economics, geography, psychology, demography, law, cultural studies, international relations, public policy, etc.

The main objectives of migration studies are to understand why individuals or groups move; how they experience their journey during transit and upon arrival at destination points; what factors influence integration into host communities including social policies related thereto; analyzing impacts caused because immigration/emigration patterns have economic consequences not only for sending countries (labor market effects) receiving ones too - known collectively under rubric 'brain drain' when highly skilled workers leave less developed nations seeking better opportunities elsewhere while leaving behind lesser qualified workforce who may struggle finding employment leading further stagnation development progress within these regions among other issues like remittances sent back home helping alleviate poverty levels there albeit sometimes creating dependency culture where recipients become reliant handouts rather than striving self-sufficiency.”

Kwak Jae-yong (Korean: 곽재용; born May 30, 1988), commonly known as ZICO (Korean: 주아쿠), is a South Korean rapper, songwriter, and producer. He debuted as a member of the hip-hop trio Block B in 2011 and has since established himself as a solo artist and producer.

Born and raised in Seoul, South Korea, ZICO displayed an interest in music from a young age and began rapping in high school. He attended Seoul Institute of the Arts and made his debut with Block B in 2011 with the album "Block B: The Initial" and the single "Kick It". The group quickly gained popularity and ZICO began to gain recognition as a talented rapper and songwriter.

In addition to his work with Block B, ZICO has also established himself as a solo artist. He released his first solo album, "Scene," in 2015, which debuted at number six on the Korean Album Chart. The album features a mix of hip-hop and electronic music and includes the hit singles "Aww," "Ice Cream," and "Heart is Moving". ZICO has also collaborated with many other Korean artists, including IU, Dynamic Duo, and Crush.

As a producer, ZICO has worked with many artists, including Dynamic Duo, Nell, and B.I. He has also created songwriting and production for various television and film soundtracks. In 2016, he founded his own music production company, AOA Entertainment, under which he manages and produces music for new artists.

ZICO has won numerous awards for his music, including the Mnet Asian Music Award for Best New Artist in 2012 and the Melon Music Award for Best New Artist in 2011. He has also been involved in various philanthropic activities, including supporting the "Happy U Fund" to help underprivileged children and participating in the Green Umbrella Children's Fund charity concert.

In 2020, ZICO left his label, Seven Secrets, and announced that he would be taking a break from music to focus on his health. He was diagnosed with anxiety and depression and has been open about his struggles with mental health.

Botswana–China relations refer to the international relations between Botswana and China. Botswana is one of the few African countries that recognize China's government in 1949 instead of the Republic of China (Taiwan). Since then, the two countries have maintained cordial diplomatic relations, with China becoming one of Botswana's most important partners in economic and infrastructure development.

Botswana's relationship with China dates back to the 1960s when China provided technical and financial assistance to Botswana's mining sector. In the 21st century, China has become Botswana's largest trade partner and largest source of foreign investment. In 2010, Chinese companies invested in several large-scale infrastructure projects in Botswana, including the construction of the Botswana-Zimbabwe-South Africa (BZS) Regional Interconnection Project and the upgrade of the Sir Seretse Khama International Airport.

In recent years, Botswana has also strengthened cultural ties with China. In 2016, Botswana's First Lady, Neo Masisi, led a delegation to China to promote cultural exchange and cooperation between the two countries. Botswana has also participated in several cultural exchange programs sponsored by the Chinese government, including the China-Africa Culture and Art Festival.

Overall, Botswana-China relations have been characterized by mutual respect and cooperation, with both countries working to strengthen economic, cultural, and political ties.

Jum Jainuddin Akbar (born June 12, 1956) is an Indonesian politician who served as Minister of Administrative and Bureaucratic Reform in President Joko Widodo's cabinet. He was appointed to this position on October 23, 2019, following the resignation of his predecessor, Pramono Anung. Prior to becoming minister, he had held various positions within the government, including serving as Deputy Secretary General for Political Affairs at the Presidential Palace from 2014 to 2016.

Akbar began his political career in the Golkar party, one of Indonesia's largest political parties, where he rose through the ranks to become Chairman of the Central Board of Trustees between 2012 and 2015. During his tenure as chairman, he played a key role in resolving internal disputes within the party and helped pave the way for the election of Joko Widodo as president in 2014.

In addition to his work in politics, Akbar has also been active in business and academia. He holds a doctorate in law from the University of Indonesia and has published numerous articles and books on legal and political issues. He is currently a professor at Parahyangan Catholic University in Bandung, West Java.

As Minister of Administrative and Bureaucratic Reform, Akbar oversaw efforts to streamline and modernize Indonesia's bureaucracy, which is widely regarded as one of the most corrupt and inefficient in the world. His initiatives included implementing electronic systems to reduce corruption and improve transparency, as well as promoting greater accountability among public officials. Despite facing challenges such as entrenched resistance from bureaucrats and lawmakers, Akbar remained committed to reforming the system and improving the lives of ordinary Indonesians.

After completing his term as Minister of Administrative and Bureaucratic Reform, akbar returned to academic life and became rector of Syiah Kuala University in Aceh, indonesia. Under his leadership, the university achieved significant progress in several fields, including research, innovation, and community service. He stepped down as rector in 2022 after finishing his term. 

Throughout his career, Jum Jainuddin Akbar has been recognized for his contributions to Indonesian politics and governance. He received multiple awards, including the Bintang Mahaputra Adipradana, awarded by the President of Indonesia for his outstanding services to the nation.

Spafford is an American progressive rock band formed in 2007 in Decatur, Illinois. The band consists of brothers Niko Sparks (guitar, vocals) and Aaron Redfield (drums), along with Josh Stepper (bass), and Scott thorn (keys). Spafford's music is known for its intricate instrumental work, complex time signatures, and dynamic song structures, often drawing comparisons to bands such as Umphrey's McGee and The Contortionist.

The band first gained a following in their hometown of Decatur, where they regularly performed at local venues such as The Cowboy Monkey and Horseshoe Lounge. In 2010, Spafford began touring nationally, eventually becoming a regular act at festivals such as Summer Camp Music Festival, Electric Forest, and Roaring Creek Ranch Music Festival.

Spafford has released five studio albums, including "Waterbird" (2016), "Goodnight, Planet" (2018) and "Diviner" (2021). The band is known for their energetic and improvisational live shows, often incorporating elements of jam band culture and electronic music.

In addition to their original music, Spafford has also gained a following for their improvisational skills, often taking fan requests and incorporating elements of other songs into their performances.

Despite the band's success, they have maintained a strong connection to their roots in Decatur, often returning to perform at local venues and support the community.

Spafford's music has been described as a blend of progressive rock, jam band, and electronic music, with complex instrumental work and dynamic song structures.

Cognitive Behavioral Training (CBT) is a type of psychological therapy that focuses on identifying and changing negative patterns of thinking in order to improve emotional regulation, behavior change, and overall well-being. CBT aims to help individuals recognize their own thought processes so they can better understand how these thoughts contribute to feelings of anxiety or depression. Through this process, clients learn new coping strategies for managing difficult emotions and situations. 

The goal of CBT is not only to alleviate symptoms but also to promote long term changes in an individual's way of thinking.[1] This approach has been found effective across various mental health disorders including major depressive disorder,[2] generalized anxiousness condition[3], panic problem [4][5]. It may be used as monotherapy however it’s more frequently utilized being a complement with other types treatments like medication treatment method because combination remedy provides far better outcomes than either one particular alone does.[6] The effectiveness associated with cognitive conduct instruction continues to be demonstrated within youngsters along with adults alike; research shows which children who receive Cognitive Behaviour Therapy demonstrate significant improvements inside mood plus functioning after just 12 weeks involving cure compared those people treated having placebo remedies such since sugar pills..[7] Additionally there are studies demonstrating efficacy regarding internet based mostly cbt pertaining to treating several conditions similar to nervousness problems together with melancholy among others.[8]
 
In general practice sessions usually consist of 1:1 interaction between therapist client where patient learns skills through guided discovery by answering questions prompts given during session. Happy Flowers is a colorful and lighthearted animated television series aimed at young children. The show follows the adventures of a group of cheerful flowers who live in a whimsical garden filled with magical creatures and surprising surprises.

The main character is Happy, a bright yellow sunflower who is always full of energy and eager to explore the world around her. She is joined by her best friend, Bloom, a cute pink tulip who loves to sing and dance. Together, these two flower friends go on exciting adventures and learn important lessons about friendship, teamwork, and creativity.

Each episode of Happy Flowers takes place in a different part of the garden, from the whirling dervish of the windflower to the floating island of the lily pads. The characters encounter various challenges and obstacles along the way, but they always find a way to work together and overcome them.

The show's colorful animation and catchy songs make it a popular choice for young viewers. The characters are lovable and relatable, and the messages about friendship and teamwork are positive and inspiring. Happy Flowers is a fun and entertaining show that is sure to bring smiles to the faces of its young viewers.

Ulric Cross, also known as "Mr. Villain," was an American comedian and actor. He was best known for his deep, gravelly voice and his comical portrayal of stereotypical villains in various films and television shows.

Cross was born in Brooklyn, New York in 1933. He began his career as a comedian in the 1960s, performing in clubs and theaters across the United States. In the 1970s, he transitioned to acting, landing small roles in various films and television shows. However, it wasn't until the 1980s that he gained widespread recognition for his portrayal of villains in movies such as "Ghostbusters" and "Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom."

Cross's comedic timing and larger-than-life personality made him a favorite among audiences and fellow actors. He continued to act throughout the 1990s and early 2000s, appearing in films such as "Lethal Weapon 4" and "Charlie's Angels."

In addition to his acting career, Cross was also a vocal advocate for mental health awareness. He struggled with depression and bipolar disorder throughout his life and sought to raise awareness about the importance of seeking help for mental health issues.

Cross passed away in 2004 due to complications from diabetes. He left behind a legacy of comedic and dramatic performances that continue to delight audiences to this day. His contributions to the world of entertainment and his advocacy for mental health awareness continue to be celebrated by fans and colleagues alike.

Margaret O'Carroll was an Irish revolutionary and politician who played a significant role in the Easter Rising of 1916. Born in Dublin in 1883, she was the daughter of a prominent Irish nationalist and was educated at the University of Dublin, where she became involved in the Irish suffrage movement.

In 1915, O'Carroll joined the Irish Volunteers, a nationalist militia that was preparing for an uprising against British rule. She was assigned to the St. Stephen's Green garrison during the Easter Rising and played a key role in the defence of the area. Despite being wounded in the leg, she continued to fight until the surrender of the garrison on Saturday, 29 April.

After the rising was crushed by British forces, O'Carroll was imprisoned in Kilmainham Gaol along with other leaders of the rebellion. She was sentenced to death, but this was later commuted to penal servitude for life. She was released in 1917 as part of a general amnesty and went on to become a prominent figure in the Irish independence movement.

In 1918, O'Carroll was elected to the first Dáil Éireann, the revolutionary parliament of the Irish Republic. She served as the Secretary of the Dáil and was a member of the Executive Council, which acted as the government of the fledgling state. She was also involved in the negotiation of the Anglo-Irish Treaty in 1921, which ultimately led to the partition of Ireland and the creation of the Irish Free State.

After the establishment of the Free State, O'Carroll remained an active politician and was a member of both the Dáil and Seanad Éireann. She was a strong advocate for women's rights and social justice, and was particularly concerned with the plight of unemployed workers during the Great Depression. She retired from politics in 1948 and died in Dublin in 1953.

Overall, Margaret O'Carroll was a significant figure in the Irish revolutionary movement and played a crucial role in the Easter Rising and the struggle for Irish independence. Her contributions to politics and social justice continue to be celebrated by those who value the ideals of freedom and equality.

Josh Klinghoffer is an American musician, songwriter, and producer. He was born on December 5, 1975, in Santa Monica, California. Klinghoffer is best known as the current guitarist and keyboardist for the Red Hot Chili Peppers, one of the most successful rock bands of all time.

Klinghoffer first gained recognition as a member of the jazz-rock band The Dot Hacker, which he joined in 1999. The band released two albums before going on hiatus in 2005. During this time, Klinghoffer also worked as a session musician, contributing to albums by artists such as Beck, Aimee Mann, and John Frusciante.

In 2009, Klinghoffer joined the Red Hot Chili Peppers as the replacement for John Frusciante, who had left the band for the second time. Klinghoffer's first album with the band was "I'm with You", which was released in 2011 and became their most successful album in over a decade. Klinghoffer's distinctive guitar style and keyboard playing were a major contribution to the album's sound.

Since joining the Red Hot Chili Peppers, Klinghoffer has become a prominent figure in the rock music scene. Klinghoffer is also known for his work as a producer, having worked with artists such as The Kills, The Last Shadow Puppets, and The Smiths' frontman Morrissey.

Klinghoffer is known for his eclectic musical tastes and his ability to blend different styles into his own unique sound. He has been praised for his versatility as a musician and his contributions to the Red Hot Chili Peppers' sound. In addition to his music career, Klinghoffer is also an avid artist and has exhibited his work in galleries and museums around the world.

The Britons in Turkey are a small but growing community of expatriates and immigrants from the United Kingdom who have made their home in Turkey. Many Britons in Turkey are attracted by the country's rich history, culture, and vibrant economy.

The community is made up of a diverse range of individuals, including businesspeople, teachers, students, and retirees. Many Britons in Turkey are also attracted by the country's low cost of living and the opportunity to experience a different culture.

The British Embassy in Ankara provides consular assistance and support to Britons in Turkey, and there are several British-run businesses and organizations in the country.

The relationship between the United Kingdom and Turkey is strong, with both countries being members of NATO and the G20. The UK is also a major investor in Turkey, with many British companies operating in the country.

Overall, the Britons in Turkey are an important and integral part of the country's diverse and vibrant community, and their presence has helped to strengthen the relationship between the UK and Turkey.

Barney Frank is an American politician who served as a U.S. Representative for Massachusetts's 4th congressional district from 1981 to 2013, and was one of the most prominent openly gay members of Congress during his tenure. He first gained national attention in 1987 when he successfully led the fight to repeal a provision of the Defense Authorization Act that would have prohibited funding for local governments that refused to discriminate against homosexuals. Throughout his career, Frank was a strong advocate for LGBT rights, affordable housing, financial regulatory reform, and healthcare access. In addition to his work on Capitol Hill, Frank also taught at several universities and authored two books about politics and policy-making. After retiring from Congress, Frank became a distinguished fellow at the Center for American Progress, where he continued to engage in public policy discussions and advocacy.

The Pan American Games, also known as the Pan Am Games, is a multi-sport event that is held every four years among athletes from countries in the Americas. The games feature a variety of sports, including athletics, basketball, swimming, soccer, and many others. The event is organized by the Pan American Sports Organization (PASO), which is the governing body for sports in the Americas.

The first Pan American Games were held in Buenos Aires, Argentina in 1951. Since then, the games have been held every four years, with the exception of the years when the Summer Olympic Games are held. The games serve as a qualifying event for the Olympics, and athletes who finish in the top eight in their event at the Pan Am Games are eligible to compete in the Olympics.

The Pan American Games have been held in various cities throughout the Americas, including Mexico City, Winnipeg, Indianapolis, and Rio de Janeiro. The games typically last for two weeks and feature competitions in a variety of sports. The games also include an opening and closing ceremony, which feature cultural performances and celebrations of the host country.

The most recent Pan American Games were held in Lima, Peru in 2019, with over 6,000 athletes from 41 countries competing in 36 sports. The next Pan American Games are scheduled to be held in Santiago, Chile in 2023.

Rob Derksen (born January 1, 1970) is a Canadian politician who has served as the Member of Parliament for Calgary Heritage since 2015. He was first elected as a member of the Conservative Party of Canada but later crossed the floor and joined the Liberal Party of Canada in 2019.

Derksen was born and raised in Calgary, Alberta, and attended the University of Calgary where he earned a degree in political science. Prior to entering politics, he worked as a consultant and business owner.

Derksen was first elected to Parliament in the 2015 federal election, defeating incumbent Conservative MP James Baker. He was re-elected in the 2019 federal election, this time running as a Liberal and defeating Conservative candidate Peter Singh.

As a member of Parliament, Derksen has served on several committees, including the Standing Committee on Finance and the Standing Committee on Human Resources, Skills and Social Development and the Status of Persons with Disabilities. He has also been an advocate for issues related to small business, employment insurance, and disability rights.

In 2019, Derksen crossed the floor and joined the Liberal Party of Canada, citing concerns over the direction of the Conservative Party under the leadership of Andrew Scheer. He has since been a vocal critic of the Conservative Party and its policies, particularly on issues related to the environment and climate change.

Derksen has been married to his wife, Kristen, since 1996 and they have two children together. In his spare time, he enjoys skiing, hiking, and playing hockey.
